Title: Settings -> Install page fails to open
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: <https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode>
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: <https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/>
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: <https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq>
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: <https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom>
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: <https://atom.io/packages>

### Description

Install does not work when on fresh install under WSL/Ubuntu/VcXsrv/LXDE

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install Atom under WSL/Ubuntu/VcXsrv/LXDE environment

<!-- What you expect to happen -->

Can navigate to Install page of settings


<!-- What actually happens -->

Cannot navigate to install page of settings, error thrown

<!-- What percentage of the time does it reproduce? -->
100% of the time

### Versions

**Atom**: 1.26.1 x64
**Electron**: 1.7.11
**OS**: Ubuntu 18.04.2
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

### Additional Information


Error: 

Given:
1.Run WSL (Windows Serving Linux) with Ubuntu using VcXsrv (portable version)
3. Run LXDE
4. Fresh Install of Atom
5. Go to Settings
6. Click Install
Expected:
Package install page appears
Actual:
Error flashes, and install page is not navigated to.


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: undefined is not a function

```
At /opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/install-panel.js:385

TypeError: undefined is not a function
    at InstallPanel.addPackageViews (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/install-panel.js:385:30)
    at /opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/install-panel.js:456:26
    at /opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/atom-io-client.js:68:26
    at AtomIoClient.module.exports.AtomIoClient.fetchFromCache (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/atom-io-client.js:159:22)
    at AtomIoClient.module.exports.AtomIoClient.featuredPackages (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/atom-io-client.js:65:25)
    at InstallPanel.loadFeaturedPackages (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/install-panel.js:450:27)
    at new InstallPanel (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/install-panel.js:124:16)
    at /opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/settings-view.js:247:22
    at SettingsView.getOrCreatePanel (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/settings-view.js:371:25)
    at SettingsView.showPanel (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/settings-view.js:429:30)
    at HTMLDivElement.clickHandler (/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/lib/settings-view.js:190:24)
```

### Commands
Click +INSTALL in the settings menu

### Non-Core Packages

None

Title: Create issue button not working: ERR_INSECURE_RESPONSE
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: <https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode>
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: <https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/>
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: <https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq>
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: <https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom>
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: <https://atom.io/packages>

### Description

"Create issue on atom/atom" button does not work

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Produce an error, e.g. (atom/tree-view#1282):
  1a. create a file with a comma in its name
  1b. drag it in the tree view to a different folder
2. In the dialog that opens, click "Create issue on atom/atom" 

No browser window is opened. Console (ctrl+shift+i) shows two new errors:
```
POST https://is.gd/create.php?format=simple net::ERR_INSECURE_RESPONSE
```
and
```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Error processing argument at index 0, conversion failure from null
    at C:\Users\sternlab\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.38.2\resources\app\static\<embedded>:11:905732
    at <anonymous>
```

**Reproduces how often:**

Always

### Versions

Atom    : 1.38.2
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
Windows 10

Title: Fail to generate an Atom build in Ubuntu 19.04 64bit
Body:
I have created a new fork of the repository for Atom 1.40.0-dev. Following these [instructions](https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/hacking-on-atom-core/#platform-linux) for generating an Atom build, I have run â€œscript/bootstrapâ€? in order to install all required dependencies.

When trying to generate the Atom build using a Linux 19.04 64bit enabled computer by executing the â€œscript/buildâ€?, I am getting an error message in the terminal when the building process stops. The error message is the following:

```
Node:	v10.16.0
Npm:	v6.2.0
Installing script dependencies
Installing apm
apm  2.3.1
npm  6.2.0
node 10.2.1 x64
atom unknown
python 2.7.16
git 2.20.1
Installing modules âœ“
Wrote Dependencies Fingerprint: /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/node_modules/.dependencies-fingerprint cbfce05d767b0c926487b711109ed54461b24ed0
Cleaning /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/out
Copying assets to /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/out/app
Transpiling packages with custom transpiler configurations in /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/out/app
 transpiling for package github
Installing modules âœ—
> superstring@2.3.6 install /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/node_modules/github/node_modules/superstring
> node-gyp rebuild


Aborted (core dumped)
gyp: Call to 'node -e "require('nan')"' returned exit status 134 while in binding.gyp. while trying to load binding.gyp
gyp ERR! configure error
gyp ERR! stack Error: `gyp` failed with exit code: 1
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.onCpExit (/home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/configure.js:345:16)
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:182:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:237:12)
gyp ERR! System Linux 5.0.0-17-generic
gyp ERR! command "/home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin/node" "/home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "rebuild"
gyp ERR! cwd /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/node_modules/github/node_modules/superstring
gyp ERR! node -v v10.2.1
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v3.7.0
gyp ERR! not ok
Aborted (core dumped)
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno 134
npm ERR! superstring@2.3.6 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
npm ERR! Exit status 134
npm ERR!
npm ERR! Failed at the superstring@2.3.6 install script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /home/dev-xr/.atom/.apm/_logs/2019-06-18T20_30_29_748Z-debug.log
child_process.js:650
    throw err;
    ^

Error: Command failed: /home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin/apm install
  at checkExecSyncError (child_process.js:629:11)
  at Object.execFileSync (child_process.js:647:13)
  at module.exports (/home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/script/lib/run-apm-install.js:14:16)
  at module.exports (/home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/script/lib/transpile-packages-with-custom-transpiler-paths.js:44:7)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/home/dev-xr/gitprojects/atom/script/build:74:3)
  at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:776:30)
  at Object.Module._extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:787:10)
  at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:653:32)
  at tryModuleLoad (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:593:12)
  at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:585:3)
  at Function.Module.runMain (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:829:12)
  at startup (internal/bootstrap/node.js:283:19)
  at bootstrapNodeJSCore (internal/bootstrap/node.js:622:3)
```
I have been doing research about this issue and found this issue [#15203](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15203), where a very similar problem is described.

The issue got comments suggesting that the clang-3.3 package should be installed in order to fix the issue, nevertheless, because of the Ubuntu version I am using didnâ€™t allow me to install that clang version so I had to install the clang-8.0 package. The clang package version (8.0)  was updated in the .travis.yml file in the local Atom project.

The build generation process was run again with the above-mentioned changes applied, but the error persists.

Alternatively, before running the building process I manually, and separately, installed the nodejs *superstring* package, which is described in the previously shared error message I got. For this, I executed `npm install superstring@2.3.6`. I did this in order to define if the dependency installed separately works when running the building process. But the results were also unsuccessful.

Would anyone have experienced a problem similar to this and has suggestions on how to solve it?

Title: libdbus-1.so.3: no version information available
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you launch Atom v1.39.0-beta0 on an older Linux distribution, such as the Trusty based images on Travis CI, you get an error message printed.

This doesn't prevent Atom from running, simply spams `stderr` whenever it is launched from a system with an older version of `libdbus`. Unfortunately this can cause issues with packages that launch Node.js processes using Atom's built in Node.js version, as the output of the tasks includes this message as well.

Unfortunately this is a low enough level library that many distributions can't update it without updating most of the rest of the system as well, for Travis CI's images for example this will require a minimum of Xenial (Ubuntu 16.04).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom on a Linux system with an older `libdbus` version (such as `libdbus-1.so.3.7.6`)
2. Do something that involves communication with an external process (such as loading Atom enough to attempt to resolve environment variables from the shell)

**Expected behavior:**

No warning message to be printed.

**Actual behavior:**

The following warning message is printed for each invocation of Atom:
```
/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdbus-1.so.3: no version information available (required by /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom)
```

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: Travis CI's Trusty based image:
```
Atom    : 1.39.0-beta0
Electron: 3.1.10
Chrome  : 66.0.3359.181
Node    : 10.2.0
apm  2.2.4
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.39.0-beta0
python 2.7.6
git 2.21.0
```

### Additional Information

This was previously reported as a side issue in https://github.com/atom/teletype/pull/437, which leads to https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/16364, leading us finally to [cr783468](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=783468) which unfortunately was closed without a link to the final solution to the issue. We have to assume that this has been fixed in some later build of Chrome, or simply ignored by requiring a newer `libdbus` version.

You can see a build from [shortly before the new beta landed](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/jobs/544253657), the [first failing build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/jobs/544449213) of that package, and after https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/pull/751 updated it to Xenial the builds were green again.

Note that the message being printed doesn't _necessarily_ mean the build will fail, most packages I maintain follow the pattern of [this build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-bootlint/jobs/544472517), where it is printed but the build still passes.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

### Description

Unfortunately this can cause issues with packages that launch Node.js processes using Atom's built in Node.js version, as the output of the tasks includes this message as well.

Unfortunately this is a low enough level library that many distributions can't update it without updating most of the rest of the system as well, for Travis CI's images for example this will require a minimum of Xenial (Ubuntu 16.04).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom on a Linux system with an older `libdbus` version (such as `libdbus-1.so.3.7.6`)

No warning message to be printed.

**Actual behavior:**

The following warning message is printed for each invocation of Atom:
```
/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdbus-1.so.3: no version information available (required by /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom)
```

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: Travis CI's Trusty based image:
```
Atom    : 1.39.0-beta0
Electron: 3.1.10
Chrome  : 66.0.3359.181
Node    : 10.2.0
apm  2.2.4
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.39.0-beta0
python 2.7.6
git 2.21.0
```

### Additional Information

This was previously reported as a side issue in https://github.com/atom/teletype/pull/437, which leads to https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/16364, leading us finally to [cr783468](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=783468) which unfortunately was closed without a link to the final solution to the issue. We have to assume that this has been fixed in some later build of Chrome, or simply ignored by requiring a newer `libdbus` version.

Note that the message being printed doesn't _necessarily_ mean the build will fail, most packages I maintain follow the pattern of [this build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-bootlint/jobs/544472517), where it is printed but the build still passes.

Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you launch Atom v1.39.0-beta0 on an older Linux distribution, such as the Trusty based images on Travis CI, you get an error message printed.

This doesn't prevent Atom from running, simply spams `stderr` whenever it is launched from a system with an older version of `libdbus`. Unfortunately this can cause issues with packages that launch Node.js processes using Atom's built in Node.js version, as the output of the tasks includes this message as well.

Unfortunately this is a low enough level library that many distributions can't update it without updating most of the rest of the system as well, for Travis CI's images for example this will require a minimum of Xenial (Ubuntu 16.04).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom on a Linux system with an older `libdbus` version (such as `libdbus-1.so.3.7.6`)
2. Do something that involves communication with an external process (such as loading Atom enough to attempt to resolve environment variables from the shell)

**Expected behavior:**

No warning message to be printed.

**Actual behavior:**

The following warning message is printed for each invocation of Atom:
```
/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdbus-1.so.3: no version information available (required by /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom)
```

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: Travis CI's Trusty based image:
```
Atom    : 1.39.0-beta0
Electron: 3.1.10
Chrome  : 66.0.3359.181
Node    : 10.2.0
apm  2.2.4
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.39.0-beta0
python 2.7.6
git 2.21.0
```

### Additional Information

This was previously reported as a side issue in https://github.com/atom/teletype/pull/437, which leads to https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/16364, leading us finally to [cr783468](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=783468) which unfortunately was closed without a link to the final solution to the issue. We have to assume that this has been fixed in some later build of Chrome, or simply ignored by requiring a newer `libdbus` version.

You can see a build from [shortly before the new beta landed](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/jobs/544253657), the [first failing build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/jobs/544449213) of that package, and after https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/pull/751 updated it to Xenial the builds were green again.

Note that the message being printed doesn't _necessarily_ mean the build will fail, most packages I maintain follow the pattern of [this build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-bootlint/jobs/544472517), where it is printed but the build still passes.
Label: triaged

Title: libdbus-1.so.3: no version information available
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you launch Atom v1.39.0-beta0 on an older Linux distribution, such as the Trusty based images on Travis CI, you get an error message printed.

This doesn't prevent Atom from running, simply spams `stderr` whenever it is launched from a system with an older version of `libdbus`. Unfortunately this can cause issues with packages that launch Node.js processes using Atom's built in Node.js version, as the output of the tasks includes this message as well.

Unfortunately this is a low enough level library that many distributions can't update it without updating most of the rest of the system as well, for Travis CI's images for example this will require a minimum of Xenial (Ubuntu 16.04).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom on a Linux system with an older `libdbus` version (such as `libdbus-1.so.3.7.6`)
2. Do something that involves communication with an external process (such as loading Atom enough to attempt to resolve environment variables from the shell)

**Expected behavior:**

No warning message to be printed.

**Actual behavior:**

The following warning message is printed for each invocation of Atom:
```
/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdbus-1.so.3: no version information available (required by /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/atom)
```

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: Travis CI's Trusty based image:
```
Atom    : 1.39.0-beta0
Electron: 3.1.10
Chrome  : 66.0.3359.181
Node    : 10.2.0
apm  2.2.4
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.39.0-beta0
python 2.7.6
git 2.21.0
```

### Additional Information

This was previously reported as a side issue in https://github.com/atom/teletype/pull/437, which leads to https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/16364, leading us finally to [cr783468](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=783468) which unfortunately was closed without a link to the final solution to the issue. We have to assume that this has been fixed in some later build of Chrome, or simply ignored by requiring a newer `libdbus` version.

You can see a build from [shortly before the new beta landed](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/jobs/544253657), the [first failing build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/jobs/544449213) of that package, and after https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-jshint/pull/751 updated it to Xenial the builds were green again.

Note that the message being printed doesn't _necessarily_ mean the build will fail, most packages I maintain follow the pattern of [this build](https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-bootlint/jobs/544472517), where it is printed but the build still passes.

Title: [Feature] Ctrl + Left / Right for CJK words / ä¸­æ–‡è¯?è¯­å…‰æ ‡ç§»åŠ¨
Body:
## Summary

In libreoffice, MS word or even chrome, <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>left</kbd> / <kbd>right</kbd> moves the cursor past one CJK word. I really hope atom can implement this.

## Motivation

For example, the following is a Chinese (zh-CN) sentence with `I` denoting the cursor location:
```
Iè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚
```
Starting from the far left, press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> in succession, we get in chrome (within any input area):
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™Iæ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚`
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™æ˜¯Iä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚`
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µIä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚`
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡Iç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚`
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹Iã€‚`
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚I`

This is a very convenient way to navigate within long sentences. However, in atom, <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> moves the cursor past the whole sentence, as if it is a single word:
* Starting with - `Iè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚`
* <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> - `è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µä¸­æ–‡ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚I`

I hope atom can adopt the same behavior as in chrome, libreoffice or MS word. It would be a great boost of productivity for me. Thank you very much!

## Describe alternatives you've considered

There has been a lot of discussions about word navigation, e.g. #1982, but it seems to me that none of them addresses the CJK issue. There is a Japanese plugin to achieve similar behavior (see https://github.com/kaitoy/japanese-word-selection), but it does not work with zh-CN.

## Additional context

Chinese word segmentation is a highly non-trivial task, I have no idea how chrome implemented it. But since atom is an electron app, maybe it can _inherit_ this feature from chromium? :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye: 

If word segmentation is too difficult, it's good enough for me if <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>left</kbd> / <kbd>right</kbd> simply moves over a fixed length of Chinese characters (e.g. 2 or 3 characters, configurable in settings). This should be relatively easy to implement, I guess.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: go to line changes scroll even if the target line is already in view
Body:
### Description

When using the `go to line` functionality, atom occasionally scrolls the buffer to move the target line towards the bottom of the window. I can understand if this is done when the target line is not currently visible and so the buffer needs to be scrolled to make it visible. But this occurs even if the line is already visible.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open buffer with 231 lines
2. Change zoom/window size so that 126 lines are visible
3. go to line 1
4. go to line 199
5. go to line 135

**Expected behavior:** on step 5, line 135 is already well in view, no scrolling is necessary after going to that line.

**Actual behavior:** on step 5, the buffer is scrolled unnecessarily.

**Reproduces how often:** this particular buffer size/window size/line number combination reliably reproduces the problem, however slight modifications result in different behavior. For example:

1. Open buffer with 231 lines
2. Change zoom/window size so that 126 lines are visible
3. go to line 1
4. go to line 231
5. go to line 135

In this case, the window buffer scroll positions up until step 5 are exactly the same as the first example, but the jump to line 135 doesn't scroll the buffer in that case.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.36.1
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
OS X: 10.14.4 (18E226)
```
Label: packages/go-to-line

Title: TextMate Grammar scope specifications with multiple scopes is incorrectly handled
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If a TextMate grammar scope specifier (`name` or `contentName`) specifies multiple scopes, they are not correctly handled, and thus highlighting fails.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26179051/58852662-09712000-865d-11e9-9920-6fba209631ad.png)

The above image shows a region which should have 6 scopes, but three of them are specified on a single specification, and so they appear as a single scope.

In addition to highlighting failing, automated tests using `atom-grammar-test` also fail.

The scope specifier in the grammar file is just the list of scopes separated with spaces.

I know VSCode-TextMate explicitly accepts this, as I have seen the code that makes sure to break up the specification list at the spaces, and so my grammar file works correctly in VS Code.  I am certain I saw this in another textmate grammar file, and given enough time I will find it.

(VS Code, same grammar file)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26179051/58853078-9c5e8a00-865e-11e9-986d-f7bfd8d050e5.png)

I'll get a link posted to the grammar file in question, if its needed.  These specific changes are not yet posted online.

(snippet of one repository item)
```CSON
	interpolation:
		begin: "(\\$)(\\()"
		beginCaptures:
			"1":
				name: "keyword.other.substatement.powershell punctuation.definition.substatement.powershell punctuation.section.embedded.substatement.begin.powershell"
			"2":
				name: "punctuation.section.group.begin.powershell punctuation.section.embedded.substatement.begin.powershell"
		contentName: "interpolated.complex.source.powershell"
		end: "\\)"
		endCaptures:
			"0":
				name: "punctuation.section.group.end.powershell punctuation.section.embedded.substatement.end.powershell"
		name: "meta.embedded.substatement.powershell"
		patterns: [
			{
				include: "$self"
			}
		]
```

The purpose of these multiple scopes to that there are alternate ideas as to how the content should be scoped and themed, and this is the best to support them all.  The last scope in the specification would have the highest priority if the theme has a selection for it.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.37.0
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

Windows 10 1903 18908

Title: Uncaught AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: 6122 == 0
Body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. Click on package update icon
2. Settings section opened and also this error comes up.

**Atom**: 1.37.0 x64
**Electron**: 2.0.18
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 10 Home Single Language
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: 6122 == 0

```
At assert.js:42

AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: 6122 == 0
    at ClientRequest.onConnect (/app.asar/node_modules/tunnel-agent/index.js:160:14)
    at Object.onceWrapper (events.js:319:30)
    at emitThree (events.js:136:13)
    at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:217:7)
    at Socket.socketOnData (_http_client.js:472:11)
    at emitOne (events.js:116:13)

    at addChunk (_stream_readable.js:263:12)
    at readableAddChunk (_stream_readable.js:250:11)

```

     -0:25.3.0 settings-view:check-for-package-updates (atom-workspace.workspace.scrollbars-visible-always.theme-one-dark-syntax.theme-one-dark-ui)
```

### Non-Core Packages

```

busy-signal 2.0.1 
intentions 1.1.5 
linter 2.3.0 
linter-ui-default 1.7.1 
prettier-atom 0.56.4 
```

Title: Needs to use openat() with gvfs so that stale but remounted connections work.
Body:
### Description

If you try to save to a file over gvfs where the connection has been closed, and the remounted it reports a fuse error. This is because it is holding a state file handle, instead of using openat() and letting the kernel traverse the directories each time. Sometimes you would want the functionality where it holds on to the fds, but in this case I do not want that.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file on GNOME from over gvfs to a ssh host (sftp)
2. disconnect the sftp connection
3. reconnect the sftp connection
3. try to save a file

**Expected behavior:**
works

**Actual behavior:**
can't save over socket

**Reproduces how often:**
100%

### Versions

apm  2.1.7
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.37.0
python 2.7.16

Ubuntu disco x86_64

Title: Enabling @atom/notify by default causes CI failures with electron v3
Body:
We're getting some CI failures on the [`electron-3.1` branch](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18916/) on Windows:

```
Error: async hook stack has become corrupted (actual: 5580, expected: 0)
 1: v8::RetainedObjectInfo::~RetainedObjectInfo
 2: node::RemoveEnvironmentCleanupHook
 3: node::InternalCallbackScope::Close
 4: uv_run
 5: 0140999B
 6: 0140A236
 7: 015738DC
 8: 015AF71E
 9: 015AF892
10: 015AFA54
11: 015B04B3
12: 015B00F5
13: 01581448
14: GetHandleVerifier
15: GetHandleVerifier
16: IsSandboxedProcess
17: IsSandboxedProcess
18: IsSandboxedProcess
19: GetHandleVerifier
20: 01404AB6
21: IsSandboxedProcess
22: BaseThreadInitThunk
23: RtlInitializeExceptionChain
24: RtlInitializeExceptionChain
Error! The 'core-main-process' test step finished with a non-zero exit code
```

The issue seems to be caused by `@atom/notify`
Label: electron-3

Title: We should reuse the electron-link cache between builds on Azure DevOps
Body:
When building Atom, we [generate a v8 startup snapshot](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/1edf94a24032a8a0e555c3db7aa7de01e5b00633/script/lib/generate-startup-snapshot.js) by transforming every source file in the code base and concatenating them all into one giant `startup.js` script. I don't have exact timings, but this takes a decent percentage of the 10 minutes we spend on the `Build Atom` step of every build on every platform.

The `electron-link` tool includes a caching facility, which skips transformation of any file that hasn't changed. If we could take advantage of that on Azure Pipelines, we'd save a significant chunk of time on every build.

@jasonrudolph co-authored this issue.

cc @daviwil

Title: Reopen Project in safe/dev mode opens existing project in normal window
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you have Project A open in a normal Atom window and want to open it as well using the Reopen Project command in a safe/dev window, the existing Atom window will be focused.
This does _not_ happen using Add Folder.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `atom some-project`
2. `atom --safe`
3. `application:reopen-project`
4. Select `some-project`

**Expected behavior:** `some-project` to open in the safe window

**Actual behavior:** The normal window is focused

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.39.0-dev-d35e39605
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
```

### Additional Information

/cc @smashwilson
Label: d â¬‡ï¸?

Title: First context menu to be opened after Atom starts closes on its own
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The first context menu to be opened after Atom starts closes on its own.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom.
2. Right-click (either inside the editor or on an open file tab) to open the context menu.
3. Wait without clicking anything.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Nothing.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
The context menu closes on its own after a few seconds.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
Only the first context menu opened after a fresh start of Atom. Happens 100% of the time in that scenario.

### Versions

This is happening in Atom on Windows 10.

```
$ atom --version

Atom    : 1.36.1
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
```

Title: Atom environment accessible from the main process
Body:
Turns out that the main process has access to the `atom` global variable and there are some usages of it across the codebase (which are unreliable since the environment available in the main process has the state of the snapshot).

List of identified usages:

* `path-watcher.js`
  * https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/path-watcher.js#L185
  * https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/path-watcher.js#L223
  * https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/path-watcher.js#L232
  * https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/path-watcher.js#L547-L548
* `atom-application.js`
  * https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/main-process/atom-application.js#L33
  * https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/main-process/atom-application.js#L37

As [discussed in Slack](https://github.slack.com/archives/G2LCNPXBP/p1557406371287600), we should remove all usages of the `atom` global object from the main renderer, and then remove that global object from it in order to avoid relying on it in the future.

To find all potential usage, we can add a big warning every time the `atom` object is accessed by creating some kind of interceptor at the startup of the main process:

```js
const originalAtom = global.atom

Object.defineProperty(global, 'atom', {
  get() {
    console.error('Warning! Using the global atom variable from the main process')
    console.trace()
    return originalAtom
  }```

Title: Reduce the number of modules loaded by the main process on startup
Label: FY2019Q5 atom perf

Title: In split pane update line numbers instead of scrolling in second pane when editing code in first pane
Body:
## Summary

This is probably the same feature request as #10447 (which got closed because no activity).  In split pane, when you are editing code in first pane and adding/removing lines then in the second pane you see it scrolling up/down, even if the second pane is in another location in the code outside of where the cursor is in the first pane.  I would be nice to have the code stay stationary in the second pane and move the line numbers instead.

*Edit by @rsese to add GIF showing current behavior*

![split-pane-scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/734194/57154052-829b0000-6d9d-11e9-8c77-ed8174b0c91b.gif)

## Motivation

A lot of times you are reading code in the second pane as you are editing code in the first pane and the constant scrolling makes it more difficult.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

None yet

## Additional context

Will add if needed
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Drag-and-drop events use nonstandard `path` property on File objects
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

To open a new tab when a file is drag-and-dropped onto a pane, we check the `path` property of all the `File`s associated with the drag event and pass them to `atom.open`: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/2a7ddf0d224aa8941dd523eabc2c19e012054da1/src/pane-element.js#L63-L66

This would be fine, except `path` is not one of the attributes defined by the [File API Spec](https://w3c.github.io/FileAPI/#file-attrs).

In fact, after searching around, I have no clue how this code works, as it seems like the reason the full path is intentionally not supposed to be exposed is because of security concerns.

While this works now, I'm not sure how long it'll stay working...
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Opening file causes system to lock for ~10 seconds on Ubuntu 19.04
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: [snip]

### Description

After upgrading from Ubuntu 18.10 to 19.04, certain simple operations in Atom cause the system to lock/hang for up to 10 seconds.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open `atom-beta --safe`.
2. Open a small text file (Ctrl+O).

**Expected behavior:** The file opens more or less instantly and is available for editing. This was the behaviour under Ubuntu 18.10.

**Actual behavior:**
- Keyboard input locks and the screen (including other visible windows) freezes for about 10 seconds. 
- The mouse cursor is movable if under the default Ubuntu `gdm3` session; or also locks if under the Ubuntu Wayland session.
- `gnome-shell` CPU usage (from `top` or `htop`) spikes to 100% and settles back to a low value after the screen unfreezes.
- The lock is usually long enough that Ubuntu/Gnome/apport offers to kill Atom after the screen unfreezes.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
$ atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.37.0-beta1
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
$ apm-beta --version
apm  2.1.7
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.37.0-beta1
python 2.7.16
git 2.20.1
$ lsb_release -rd
Description:    Ubuntu 19.04
Release:        19.04
$ apt-cache policy atom-beta | head -n11
atom-beta:
  Installed: 1.37.0-beta1
  Candidate: 1.37.0-beta1
  Version table:
 *** 1.37.0-beta1 500
        500 https://packagecloud.io/AtomEditor/atom/any any/main amd64 Packages
        100 /var/lib/dpkg/status
     1.37.0-beta0 500
        500 https://packagecloud.io/AtomEditor/atom/any any/main amd64 Packages
     1.36.0-beta2 500
        500 https://packagecloud.io/AtomEditor/atom/any any/main amd64 Packages
```

### Additional Information

- See [this Ubuntu bug](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-shell/+bug/1826219) for further description.
- Saving a file causes a similar lock, though much shorter (~1 second).
- Google Chrome seems to cause similar locks (though much shorter in duration: â‰¤1 second, and not as repeatable), which maybe points to something underlying Electron/Chromium?

Title: macOS: cmd+backtick stopped working between 1.35.1 and 1.36.0
Body: *edit by @rsese: repro-ed by @rafeca https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/19168#issuecomment-485939257 :* > I've just been able to reproduce the issue with my british laptop keyboard. > 1. I've forced the "British - PC" keyboard layout: > 2. Then, clicking on `Cmd + Â±` on my keyboard (the correspondant to `Cmd + \`` on that layout) allows to switch app windows in other apps like Google Chrome or the Finder, but it does not work in Atom. --- ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description I use `cmd+backtick` to switch windows. After upgrading from 1.35.1 to 1.36.0 this behaviour stopped working. Instead, the key combination is interpreted as `cmd+\` and toggles the visibility of the tree view. This works in all other applications. It also works if I revert to Atom 1.35.1 which I have done for now. I am using an external keyboard which has a British PC layout with the backtick key in the top-left. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/609579/56214874-8bc66600-6056-11e9-9566-1201c320e404.png) The key binding resolver says this: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/609579/56215473-a9e09600-6057-11e9-9391-36718694b2a3.png) I have nothing in my `keymap.cson`. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open Atom 2. Open multiple windows (`cmd+shift+n`) 3. Press `cmd+backtick` **Expected behavior:** switch window **Actual behavior:** tree view visibility is toggled **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions macOS Sierra 10.12.6 Atom 1.36.0 Electron 2.0.18 Chrome 61.0.3163.100 Node 8.9.3 ### Additional Information I saw the following related issues but felt this one was different enough to warrant a separate issue: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11531 - old, closed https://github.com/atom/keyboard-layout/issues/39 - new, different behaviour
Label: d â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Support Semantic Highlighting on Tree-Sitter Grammars
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

---

Keep in mind that Atom is highly customizable in a number of ways and we strongly prefer that you consider these options before filing this issue:

* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/basic-customization/: tweak Atom's configuration, styles, and keybindings.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/atom-packages/: install a community package.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/: use the Atom API in your init script, to create a package, or to enhance an existing package.

If you're convinced that none of these options are appropriate for the feature you want, please explain why that's the case by completely filling out the issue template below.

Also note that the Atom team has finite resources so it's unlikely that we'll work on feature requests. If we're interested in a particular feature however, we'll follow up and ask you to submit an RFC to talk about it in more detail.

-->

## Summary

Please make token text available to Tree-Sitter grammars when requesting scope information, and possibly create a way to return different scopes for each lexical token.

## Motivation

The current implementation of [semanticolor](https://atom.io/packages/semanticolor) doesn't work with Tree-Sitter grammars. I'd like to be able to take advantage of Tree-Sitter, but this requires the grammar to be aware of the text a scope is being requested for, and to be able to return separate scopes for each lexical token in a scope.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

By changing `tree-sitter-language-mode.js` line 1060 from this:

```
return this.languageLayer.languageMode.grammar.idForScope(scopeName)
```

to this:

```
return this.languageLayer.languageMode.grammar.idForScope(scopeName, this.treeCursor.nodeText)
```

I was able to produce somewhat reasonable results, but this doesn't give me a way to assign different scopes to each lexical token, so the results aren't perfect:

![example](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/digitallyserviced/semanticolor/master/tree-sitter.png)

Title: Atom crashes with "buffer overflow detected" occasionally without doing anything
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom closes unexpectedly.

Following information is printed to linux terminal:

```
*** buffer overflow detected ***: /usr/share/atom/atom --executed-from=/home/ervin --pid=1581 terminated
/usr/bin/atom: line 157:  1594 Aborted                 (core dumped) nohup "$ATOM_PATH" --executed-from="$(pwd)" --pid=$$ "$@" > "$ATOM_HOME/nohup.out" 2>&1
```

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Fresh installation of Atom
2. Execute command "atom" to open Atom
3. Do nothing for a while. After some time the editor closes. Or, actually, it doesn't really matter, the crash also happens when using Atom normally, but minimal example would be to just open freshly installed Atom and do nothing.

**Expected behavior:** Not crash.

**Actual behavior:** Crash.

**Reproduces how often:** 

After opening the editor, it takes sometimes quite long time (hour or more) before it crashes. The time it takes to crash seems to be random, and sometimes is also just a few minutes.

NOTE: I have not been able to reproduce this crash with --safe. I'm not sure if this is due to the random nature of the bug or not. I figured it is still a bug that should be reported as the editor is crashing without literally any changes after a fresh install.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.35.1
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
$ apm --version
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.35.1
python 2.7.15rc1
git 2.17.1
$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	LinuxMint
Description:	Linux Mint 19 Tara
Release:	19
Codename:	tara
```

### Additional Information

I have the Apport crash report (including core dump) available for additional information.
Label: crash

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Invalid Point: (459, NaN)
Body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. In some larger .json files (~50+ kb?) the cursor would eventually stop moving forward about five characters from the end of a line.  It would not move forward using either the arrow keys or the mouse.
2. Moving the cursor down a line, then backwards to wrap back to the previous line throws the Invalid Point error.

Worth noting that restarting Atom made the problem stop occurring.  Haven't had it show up in any documents since.

**Atom**: 1.35.1 x64
**Electron**: 2.0.18
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 10 Home
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

```

Title: Invisible window when Atom starts on Elementary OS
Body:
### Description

I've taken invisible window when Atom starts, this behavior occurs when the Atom has closed in maximized window mode.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom normally
2. Put in maximized window mode
3. Close the Atom
4. Re-open the Atom

**Expected behavior:**
Expected the Atom's window displayed.

**Actual behavior:**
Atom's window don't displays.

To get the window back, I click on top-left of desktop (bellow "Application menu") and drag to some direction to unmaximize the window.

### Versions
**Atom version**
```
Atom    : 1.35.1
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
```

**OS version**
```
Distributor ID:	elementary
Description:	elementary OS 5.0 Juno
Release:	5.0
Codename:	juno
Linux 4.15.0-46-generic #49-Ubuntu SMP Wed Feb 6 09:33:07 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Additional Information
**My partial solucion**
To prevent maximized window during Atom loading, I put this snippet of code in `init.coffee`  file:
```coffeescript
if atom.applicationDelegate.isWindowMaximized()
    atom.applicationDelegate.unmaximizeWindow();
```
Sorry for my bad english.

Title: Feature Request: Allow files/directories to be ignored by Atom Helper process.
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

---

Keep in mind that Atom is highly customizable in a number of ways and we strongly prefer that you consider these options before filing this issue:

* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/basic-customization/: tweak Atom's configuration, styles, and keybindings.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/atom-packages/: install a community package.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/: use the Atom API in your init script, to create a package, or to enhance an existing package.

If you're convinced that none of these options are appropriate for the feature you want, please explain why that's the case by completely filling out the issue template below.

Also note that the Atom team has finite resources so it's unlikely that we'll work on feature requests. If we're interested in a particular feature however, we'll follow up and ask you to submit an RFC to talk about it in more detail.

-->

## Summary

Create a way to exclude directories from the project index, maybe use .gitignore or allow files/directories to be manually selected.

I noticed a CPU usage spike from the Atom Helper process every time I loaded a Rails page. The page load caused updates to the ./log/development.log file along with updates to ./tmp/cache/assets/sprockets... Both of these directories (./log and ./tmp) are in my .gitignore. I was able to avoid the CPU usage spike by moving my log and tmp directories out of the Atom project directory. The CPU spike was caused by updates to files that I never open in atom, but lived in my project directory. 

In some worst-case testing, I held cmd+shift+r on my rails page to constantly refresh the page. With rails writing to ./log and ./tmp, I observed an Atom Helper Energy impact of 55-60 (system power draw of 38.8w). With rails writing to directories outside of the Atom project, I observed an Atom Helper Energy impact of 0.1-0.4 (system power draw of 32.5w).
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Enhance CI build to "fail fast"
Body:
As one part of resolving https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18990, let's enhance the CI build script so it terminates immediately if a package's tests fail.

### Background

https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18990 reported problems with CI builds failing when running tests for the `language-yaml` package. The end of the CI build logs reported the following results:

```
...
Executing language-yaml tests
##[error]Bash exited with code '1'.
##[section]Finishing: Run tests
```

Upon investigation, we realized that the failures aren't happening in `language-yaml` after all. The failures are happening in other packages, but the test suite doesn't exit until it has run _all_ package tests. Since `language-yaml` is the last package whose tests are run as part of the build, we see the rather misleading output shown above.

If we look higher up in the build log, we see the real source of the failure. For example, in [this build log](https://github.visualstudio.com/Atom/_build/results?buildId=35579&view=logs&jobId=a5e52b91-c83f-5429-4a68-c246fc63a4f7&taskId=bde16fc7-7659-5b1c-12aa-0110866d993c&lineStart=2446&lineEnd=2454&colStart=1&colEnd=1), we see that the failure occurs while running the tests for the `autosave` package:

```...
Executing autosave tests
Package tests failed for autosave:
...
Autosave > when the buffer is modified > when a pane loses focus > suppresses autosave if the file does not exist 2019-03-14 14:09:45.013 Atom Dev[84832:130522] Renderer process crashed, exiting
Executing background-tips tests
...
Executing language-yaml tests
##[error]Bash exited with code '1'.
##[section]Finishing: Run tests
```

### Proposed improvement: Teach atom/atom builds to fail fast

Currently, if the tests fail for package _x_, the build continues running the tests for all the other packages. This approach has two undesirable consequences:

1. **Developers have to wait longer than necessary to discover that their build failed.** Today, atom/atom builds are s-l-o-w. (Fixing that is a separate issue. :innocent:) If a build takes 60 minutes to run, and the tests failed 30 minutes into the build, developers currently have to wait the full 60 minutes before they learn that the build failed.

2. **The cause of the build failure is buried in the middle of the build log.** If you read the end of the build log, it _looks_ like `language-yaml` is the culprit. To find the real culprit, you have to search the build log for the word "failed".

If a package's tests fail, let's teach the atom/atom build to terminate the build immediately (to resolve # 1 above) and ensure that the cause of the failed build is present at the end of the build log (to resolve # 2 above).
Label: FY2019Q5 deterministic builds

Title: #! in package.json breaks package install: npm ERR! path /usr/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/node_modules/sntp/package.json
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description



### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start Atom
2. Select Edit > Preferences > + Install
3. Search for a package, e.g. _ansible_
4. Click desired blue [Install] button on matching package, e.g. _language-ansible_

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Package installs.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Pink error box reports, `Installing â€œlanguage-ansible@0.2.2â€? failed.Show outputâ€¦`
Clicking `Show outputâ€¦` reveals

    npm ERR! path /usr/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/node_modules/sntp/package.json
    npm ERR! Error parsing /usr/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/node_modules/sntp/package.json: Unexpected token # in JSON at position 0

    npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
    npm ERR!     /home/cainesaj/.atom/.apm/_logs/2019-03-18T16_34_52_243Z-debug.log

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%.

### Versions

    $ cat /etc/redhat-release ; atom --version ; atom --safe
    Fedora release 29 (Twenty Nine)
    Atom    : 1.34.0
    Electron: 2.0.16
    Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
    Node    : 8.9.3

and

    $ cat /etc/lsb-release ; atom --version ; atom --safe
    DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
    DISTRIB_RELEASE=18.04
    DISTRIB_CODENAME=bionic
    DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS"
    Atom    : 1.35.1
    Electron: 2.0.18
    Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
    Node    : 8.9.3


### Additional Information

Removing the first line, `#!/usr/bin/node`, from `/usr/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/node_modules/sntp/package.json` results in the package installing as expected.

Note that this file is part of the installed atom package and that having a #! on the first line of any interpreted script is always appropriate (though `#!/usr/bin/env node` would be more portable).

    $ rpm -qf /usr/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/node_modules/sntp/package.json
    atom-1.34.0-2.fc29.x86_64

Title: Package specs can't use external packages
Body:
### Prerequisites

Not applicable.

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18801 changed how the Atom profile for spec runs works, making it use an entirely new profile folder. This had the unintended side-effect of breaking the specs of packages that rely on loading other packages in while testing, since the external packages can no longer be loaded.

### Steps to Reproduce

#### In general

1. Run `apm install <external package>`
2. Run `atom --test spec` on a _different_ package, that calls `atom.packages.activatePackage('<external package>');`

#### Exact steps

1. Start a container with `docker run --rm -it arcanemagus/atom-docker-ci:v1.36.0-beta1 bash`
  * All subsequent steps are run within the container
2. `git clone https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-bailey.git && cd linter-bailey`
3. `git checkout c502b71`
4. `${APM_SCRIPT_PATH} install "language-bailey"`
5. `${APM_SCRIPT_PATH} install`
6. `${ATOM_SCRIPT_PATH} --test spec`

Compare with running the same steps in a container started with:
`docker run --rm -it arcanemagus/atom-docker-ci:v1.35.1 bash`

**Expected behavior:**

External packages that were installed before the specs were ran are able to be resolved and loaded in the specs.

**Actual behavior:**

The external packages can no longer be resolved.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

Example failure: https://circleci.com/workflow-run/18b1cb01-c82e-4e7f-8a5b-861bdacf5936

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.36.0-beta1
Electron: 2.0.18
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.36.0-beta1
python 2.7.15rc1
git 2.17.1
```

OS: Tested in Linux containers and locally on Windows.


### Additional Information

Potential solutions outlined in chats with @smashwilson:

* If `ATOM_TEST_PACKAGES` is set in the environment, symlink all of those into the temporary profile folder
  * This will work for _most_ configurations that have followed the example of `atom/ci`, but doesn't account for manual configurations that are just running the commands directly
* Create some API to mark packages for including in the temporary profile explicit
  * This won't work for existing setups, but is a nice solution for the future
* Disable using a temporary profile in CI environments
  * This brings us back to the risk of corruption/non-reproducibility that the original PR was meant to solve

I verified locally that #18801 was the culprit by running a build that exhibited the issue at first, running `git revert 8e6d833`, and checking that the issue was gone.
Label: regression

Potential solutions outlined in chats with @smashwilson:

* If `ATOM_TEST_PACKAGES` is set in the environment, symlink all of those into the temporary profile folder
  * This will work for _most_ configurations that have followed the example of `atom/ci`, but doesn't account for manual configurations that are just running the commands directly
* Create some API to mark packages for including in the temporary profile explicit
  * This won't work for existing setups, but is a nice solution for the future
* Disable using a temporary profile in CI environments
  * This brings us back to the risk of corruption/non-reproducibility that the original PR was meant to solve

I verified locally that #18801 was the culprit by running a build that exhibited the issue at first, running `git revert 8e6d833`, and checking that the issue was gone.
Label: triaged

Title: Reassigned shortcut is not removed from the menu
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Reassigned shortcut is not removed from the menu. Even after restarting Atom it shows the shortcut next to the new and old entry.

### Steps to Reproduce

None

Title: Provide Option to Enable 'darkTheme' Option of BrowserWindow
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Description

This has come up multiple times, but all issues regarding this problem I could find have been locked because of low activity, so Iâ€™m opening a new one.
On Linux many GTK themes provide a dark variant of the theme for windows with predominantly dark contents. Electron allows windows to request this dark variant through the "darkTheme" option of the BrowserWindow class, but Atom provides no way to set that option for a user.
This is an issue because if title bars are generally light, they stick out like a sore thumb if the user chooses to use a dark UI / syntax theme and are very distracting. In such cases it would be ideal for the user to be able to set an option to have Atom use the dark theme variant.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom on a Linux system with a light gtk theme with a dark variant
2. See the light title bar of Atom and be distracted by it
3. Look for an option to set Atom to use the dark theme variant and not find it

**Expected behavior:** Finding an option to have Atom use the dark theme variant, set it and restart Atom, now without a distracting light titlebar.
**Actual behavior:** There's no such option.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom: 1.34.0
APM: 2.1.3

### Additional Information

Perhaps this could be implemented similiarly to how the custom title bar styles on macOS are handled, i.e. during the initialisation of a BrowserWindow, check the configuration whether the option for 'darkTheme' is set and if it is, set it to `true` in the BrowserWindow options. 

Thank you all for your hard work and for considering this issue.

Title: Add an event for text backspace and deletion
Body:
## Summary

Add a new event for text backspaces and deletions. Something like `TextEditor::onWill/DidBackspace/Delete()`.

## Motivation

Events exist for inserting text, but not for deleting text. Packages that need to act when text is deleted need to resort to methods such as monkey-patching the delete and backspace methods.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

The new event could be `TextEditor::onWill/DidDelete(backspace)` rather than having two separate events for backspace and delete.

## Additional context

bracket-matcher currently has to monkey-patch backspace: https://github.com/atom/bracket-matcher/blob/8a3bd1e347b02d8ad0c30ffa1a80836d9625a234/lib/bracket-matcher.js#L19
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Add `options` parameter to TextEditor::onWillInsertText
Body:
## Summary

[`TextEditor::onWillInsertText`](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.34.0/TextEditor#instance-onWillInsertText) currently provides the `text` to be inserted and a `cancel` function. I propose that the `options` object is passed to this event as well, making the new signature `TextEditor::onWillInsertText(text, cancel, options)` to be backwards-compatible.

## Motivation

Sometimes, we may want to only call `cancel()` if certain options are set. For example, `bracket-matcher` needs to know if the `select` or `undo` options are set in order to determine whether or not to auto-insert brackets.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

An alternative solution would be a way to determine if `insertText` is called due to manual user input.

## Additional context

bracket-matcher currently monkey-patches `TextEditor::insertText` so that it can access its options: https://github.com/atom/bracket-matcher/blob/8a3bd1e347b02d8ad0c30ffa1a80836d9625a234/lib/bracket-matcher.js#L17
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Atom built from source (v1.34) crashes when opening a folder with git repository
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add extra notes*

Reproduced on Ubuntu 16.04 but couldn't reproduce on 18.04. 

On 16.04, used node 8.9.3 and npm 6.2.0:

```
$ apm -v
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.12
```
Used the same node and npm versions on 18.04.

---

### Description

Atom crashes when opening a folder containing a git repository

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build Atom from source (v1.34) "./script/build --create-debian-package"
2. Install your build
3. Start Atom
4. Open a folder containing git repository

**Expected behavior:** 

**Actual behavior:** 
Crashes

**Reproduces how often:**
Always 

### Versions
OS: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

building with:
Node:	v8.9.3
Npm:	v5.5.1

checks during build:
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

after installing built package: 
_atom --version_
Atom    : 1.34.0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

_apm --version_
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

### Additional Information
Seems related to nsfw package.
Noticed that my build produces different(bigger) nsfw.node file than the one from official release (118K vs 102K)
./resources/app.asar.unpacked/node_modules/@atom/nsfw/build/Release
Instructions from manual were followed.

Crash log:
[_usr_share_atom_atom.1000.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/2915706/_usr_share_atom_atom.1000.zip)
Label: crash

Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add extra notes*

Reproduced on Ubuntu 16.04 but couldn't reproduce on 18.04. 

On 16.04, used node 8.9.3 and npm 6.2.0:

```
$ apm -v
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.12
```
Used the same node and npm versions on 18.04.

---

### Description

Atom crashes when opening a folder containing a git repository

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build Atom from source (v1.34) "./script/build --create-debian-package"
2. Install your build
3. Start Atom
4. Open a folder containing git repository

**Expected behavior:** 

**Actual behavior:** 
Crashes

**Reproduces how often:**
Always 

### Versions
OS: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

building with:
Node:	v8.9.3
Npm:	v5.5.1

checks during build:
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

after installing built package: 
_atom --version_
Atom    : 1.34.0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

_apm --version_
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

### Additional Information
Seems related to nsfw package.
Noticed that my build produces different(bigger) nsfw.node file than the one from official release (118K vs 102K)
./resources/app.asar.unpacked/node_modules/@atom/nsfw/build/Release
Instructions from manual were followed.

Crash log:
[_usr_share_atom_atom.1000.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/2915706/_usr_share_atom_atom.1000.zip)
Label: triaged

Title: clean install of atom on osx fails to open a new window
Body:
A clean install of atom on osx fails to open a new window.

**step 1 - remove your configs:**

```
rm -rf ~/.atom
rm -rf /usr/local/bin/atom
rm -rf /usr/local/bin/apm
rm -rf /Applications/Atom.app
rm -rf ~/Library/Preferences/com.github.atom.plist
rm -rf ~/Library/Application Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt
rm -rf ~/Library/Application Support/Atom
rm -rf ~/Library/Saved Application State/com.github.atom.savedState
rm -rf ~/Library/Caches/com.github.atom
rm -rf ~/Library/Caches/Atom
```

**step 2 - download a fresh copy of atom**

**step 3 - start atom**

either via the CLI or by clicking the app

actual:

the atom icon shows up
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/265409/53205561-e493f800-35eb-11e9-8273-ee35ac2c227e.png)

expected:

a new atom window to open

expected 2:

a way to debug why atom fails to start

Title: Virtual memory leak, while executing make
Body:
Atom allocates huge amounts of memory without freeing it while a make process is running in a project directory of atom. Memory allocation stops when make exits and starts over when make is called. This happens for me on **linux** in **safe mode**.

### Steps to Reproduce

I'm checking out the linux repo and compile it with a default config. Other projects with some make load are working as well!

1. `git clone https://github.com/torvalds/linux.git `
2. `cd linux`
3. `make clean distclean`
4. `yes "" | make oldconfig`
5. `atom --safe ./`
6. `make`

**Expected behavior:**
Atom should not allocate huge amounts of memory.

**Actual behavior:**
While make is running atom allocates around 150 MB per second. After make is finished atom uses around 50 GB virtual memory on my system. 

**Reproduces how often:**
100% of the time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.34.0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

at least from 1.32.0 this issue was present.

### Additional Information

Linux Mint Tara 19 (Ubuntu 18.04) @ 4.19.4-041904-generic
Dell XPS 15 9570 @ 32 GB RAM

Title: GrammarRegistry links in API docs wrong location
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Description

The API docs for GrammarRegistry point at the [First Mate GrammarRegistry](https://github.com/atom/first-mate/blob/v7.1.3/src/grammar-registry.coffee#L11), when Atom uses it's [own GrammarRegistry](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/d3a3859305892780b0d163841383afc32f7c5462/src/grammar-registry.js#L20) in the `atom.grammars` global.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click any go-to-source link in the [GrammarRegistry API docs](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.34.0/GrammarRegistry)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Go to the registry used by Atom

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Goes to the registry implemented by First Mate, which is used internally by the Atom implementation.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.34.0/GrammarRegistry

### Additional Information

This may apply to more entries, I've only checked this one.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: macos: opening multiple files from the command line could be improved
Body:
I'm using Atom on macos,

Sometimes I want to open multiple files from the command line.
This needs improvement, it does not yet work as expected.

Three ways to open multiple files (on macos):
- atom file file ...
- open -a Atom file file ...
- for f in file file ...;do;open -a Atom $f;done


To make that short:
Atom on macos should respond to the Finder 'open' event.

The 'atom' script should be rewritten,
to send the Finder 'open' event when given one or multiple file names.

It should not start a new full blown instance of Electron,
just to find out that Atom is already running.

--

added bonus, caveat:

opening files at a specific line should still work,
aka: open file:line is a bonus

---
and a new feature:
opening files at a regexp would be nice

I suggest:
open file:/foo

which should open the file
with the cursor positioned
on the first match of foo

Title: Atom never detects that updates are available
Body:
### Description

My system never detects Atom updates and always requires me to manually check and update.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click "Check for Update"

**Expected behavior:**

It should say an update is available.

**Actual behavior:**

It says I have the current version (1.31.2 at the moment)

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.31.2
Electron: 2.0.7
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm  2.1.1
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.31.2
python 3.7.2
git 2.20.1

This is on OSX.

### Additional Information

While I did mention a specific version (1.31.2) this is a recurring issue for me.
Label: installer
