Title: Redundant tree-sitter grammar scoring
Body:
## Summary

We seem to be doing a lot of grammar scoring with tree-sitter grammars that we shouldn't. Not doing this would shave off some startup time.

## Motivation

Faster startup time.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: Preload tree-sitter grammars
Body:
## Summary

@as-cii did some work to preload TextMate grammars early in the startup sequence for better performance. Can we do something similar for tree-sitter grammars?

We can likely require the binary lazily and save a lot of time.

## Motivation

Faster startup time.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: Support asynchronous package loading
Body:
## Summary

We have almost all of core prepared for third-party packages to activate asynchronously, but we're still doing the final package activations synchronously, in serial. Let's add a `package.json` key for packages that _really_ need to load sync and load the rest async in parallel.

## Motivation

Faster startup time.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: TextEditorElement forces a reflow on DOM attachment
Body:
## Summary

`TextEditorComponent::didAttach()` calls `this.isVisible()`, which reads a written CSS property and results in a forced reflow. We may be able to avoid this during initial attachment.

## Motivation

Faster startup time.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: KeymapManager::onDidLoadUserKeymap does a lot of synchronous stat calls
Body:
## Summary

The `KeymapManager::onDidLoadUserKeymap` makes a number of synchronous stat() calls that are likely avoidable.

## Motivation

Faster startup time.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: Investigate any requires happening in safe mode
Body:
## Summary

Any `require` calls happening in `--safe` mode, either from core or from bundled packages, should be investigated to determine if they _should_ be happening during snapshotting.

## Motivation

Faster renderer process startup time.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: Consolidate divergent dependency versions of non-snapshottable dependencies
Body:
## Summary

When versions of dependencies that cannot be included in the snapshot, like `fs-extra`, diverge among bundled packages and core, we pay the cost to require them at runtime multiple times. Consolidating our dependency versions would result in us making better use of the module cache.

## Motivation

Faster renderer process time startup.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

Note that atom/github is currently locked to an older version of `fs-extra` because `copyFiles` wasn't working when copying from an `.asar`. We may need to resolve that first.
Label: startup-time

Title: GitRepository::openSubmodules() is called synchronously during startup
Body:
## Summary

The `GitRepository::openSubmodules()` method is fairly costly and is called synchronously during renderer process startup, even when no submodules are present. It can likely be deferred or called lazily.

## Motivation

Faster renderer process initialization.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

_N/A_

## Additional context

_N/A_
Label: startup-time

Title: [Debian] Not working when configured in alternatives for editor
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When atom (beta) is configured using the alternatives system for the default editor, it is not working.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Check the current setup for `editor` to be able to undo in case of errors.
   Keep the info of `update-alternatives --display editor` in a separate terminal output or note it down.
2. In a separate terminal execute:
   `sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/editor editor /usr/bin/atom-beta 200`
   - I used `200` as priority as it was higher as anything listed in step 1, so it would be automatically choosen as current alternatve.
3. In a separate terminal execute `update-alternatives --display editor`, to check it is now listed as default for `editor`.
   1. If step 3 is positive we can continue to step 4, **otherwise** you made a mistake and might want to undo your error and start over.
   1. To undo step 2 execute `sudo update-alternatives --remove editor /usr/bin/atom-beta`.
5. We can continue in the same terminal as step 3.
   1. Execute `select-editor` to change the preferred editor for the current user.
   2. Select the option in which `/usr/bin/atom-beta` is listed.
   3. Execute `sensible-editor -h` to display the help of the preferred editor, which is by now the atom editor. **This should work.**
   4. Execute `editor -h` to display the help of the default editor, which is by now the atom editor. **This will NOT work.**

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
That you would see the same output in step `4.iv` as you see in step `4.iii`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Step `4.iii` gives proper help output of the atom editor, which indicates it is working.
Step `4.iv` gives **no output at all**, which indicates it is **not working**.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%, eg. every time.

### Versions
```console
~/ atom-beta --version 
Atom    : 1.35.0-beta0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
~/ apm-beta --version 
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.35.0-beta0
python 2.7.15+
git 2.20.1
~/ neofetch --stdout
OS: Debian GNU/Linux buster/sid x86_64 
Model: Manual build Rev:xxx 
Mainboard: X99-PRO/USB 3.1 Rev 1.xx (ASUSTeK COMPUTER INC.) 
Bios: 2017-08-10 AMI Ver:3801 
Kernel: 4.19.0-1-amd64 
Uptime: 1 day, 2 hours, 6 mins 
Packages: 2278 (dpkg) 
Shell: zsh 5.7 
Resolution: 1680x1050 @ 59.88Hz 
DE: Cinnamon 3.8.8 
WM: Mutter (Muffin) 
WM Theme: Adapta-Nokto (Adapta-Nokto) 
Theme: Adapta-Nokto [GTK2/3] 
Icons: Papirus [GTK2/3] 
Terminal: xterm 
Font: DejaVu Serif Semi-Condensed 10 [GTK2/3] 
Locale: en_US.UTF-8 
Memory: 17301MiB / 32143MiB [--------=======] 
CPU: i7-5820K (12) @ 3.6GHz [43.0Â°C] 
GPU: GeForce GTX 1080 Ti 
GPU: GeForce 210 
GPU Driver: NVIDIA 390.87 
CPU Usage: 7% 
```
### Additional Information
It is vital to be able to set atom as the default editor using the alternatives system(ref) in debian related distributions (or any other that uses the alternatives system) if atom wants to become the defacto editor on linux :flags: :1st_place_medal: 
You might try to do the same steps with every occurrence of `atom-beta` replaced by `atom` or any other version...
Nothing more i can think of at moment :wink: 

ref:

Title: [Debian] Not working when configured in alternatives for editor
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When atom (beta) is configured using the alternatives system for the default editor, it is not working.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Check the current setup for `editor` to be able to undo in case of errors.
   Keep the info of `update-alternatives --display editor` in a separate terminal output or note it down.
2. In a separate terminal execute:
   `sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/editor editor /usr/bin/atom-beta 200`
   - I used `200` as priority as it was higher as anything listed in step 1, so it would be automatically choosen as current alternatve.
3. In a separate terminal execute `update-alternatives --display editor`, to check it is now listed as default for `editor`.
   1. If step 3 is positive we can continue to step 4, **otherwise** you made a mistake and might want to undo your error and start over.
   1. To undo step 2 execute `sudo update-alternatives --remove editor /usr/bin/atom-beta`.
5. We can continue in the same terminal as step 3.
   1. Execute `select-editor` to change the preferred editor for the current user.
   2. Select the option in which `/usr/bin/atom-beta` is listed.
   3. Execute `sensible-editor -h` to display the help of the preferred editor, which is by now the atom editor. **This should work.**
   4. Execute `editor -h` to display the help of the default editor, which is by now the atom editor. **This will NOT work.**

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
That you would see the same output in step `4.iv` as you see in step `4.iii`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Step `4.iii` gives proper help output of the atom editor, which indicates it is working.
Step `4.iv` gives **no output at all**, which indicates it is **not working**.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%, eg. every time.

### Versions
```console
~/ atom-beta --version 
Atom    : 1.35.0-beta0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
~/ apm-beta --version 
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.35.0-beta0
python 2.7.15+
git 2.20.1
~/ neofetch --stdout
OS: Debian GNU/Linux buster/sid x86_64 
Model: Manual build Rev:xxx 
Mainboard: X99-PRO/USB 3.1 Rev 1.xx (ASUSTeK COMPUTER INC.) 
Bios: 2017-08-10 AMI Ver:3801 
Kernel: 4.19.0-1-amd64 
Uptime: 1 day, 2 hours, 6 mins 
Packages: 2278 (dpkg) 
Shell: zsh 5.7 
Resolution: 1680x1050 @ 59.88Hz 
DE: Cinnamon 3.8.8 
WM: Mutter (Muffin) 
WM Theme: Adapta-Nokto (Adapta-Nokto) 
Theme: Adapta-Nokto [GTK2/3] 
Icons: Papirus [GTK2/3] 
Terminal: xterm 
Font: DejaVu Serif Semi-Condensed 10 [GTK2/3] 
Locale: en_US.UTF-8 
Memory: 17301MiB / 32143MiB [--------=======] 
CPU: i7-5820K (12) @ 3.6GHz [43.0Â°C] 
GPU: GeForce GTX 1080 Ti 
GPU: GeForce 210 
GPU Driver: NVIDIA 390.87 
CPU Usage: 7% 
```
### Additional Information
It is vital to be able to set atom as the default editor using the alternatives system(ref) in debian related distributions (or any other that uses the alternatives system) if atom wants to become the defacto editor on linux :flags: :1st_place_medal: 
You might try to do the same steps with every occurrence of `atom-beta` replaced by `atom` or any other version...
Nothing more i can think of at moment :wink: 

ref:
  - https://debian-administration.org/article/91/Using_the_Debian_alternatives_system
  - https://wiki.debian.org/DebianAlternatives
  - https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/229373/debian-alternatives-system-programs-with-the-same-name-and-priorities
Label: needs-reproduction

Title: Tree Sitter Parser sometimes crashes Atom on large file
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Tree Sitter Parser sometimes crashes Atom on large file

### Steps to Reproduce

*Edit by @rsese to clarify repro steps and expected/actual behavior*

1. `atom --safe`
1. Make Tree-sitter is enabled at `Settings > Core > Use Tree Sitter Parsers`
1. Open and copy <https://github.com/stdio2016/shapeclear-html/blob/3d23132d07dbff365be4dc1ab3a9bebfeefd40d1/lib/phaser.js>
1. Create a new file and paste
1. Save the file as a JavaScript file e.g. `test.js`
1. Close the file
1. Reopen the file

If there's no crash, repeat steps 6 and 7.

**Expected behavior:** 
No crash.

Syntax highlighting on phaser.js, or just no syntax highlighting because the file is too large

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Sometimes a crash at step (5) or if the save succeeds at step (7).  

sometimes crashes, even on safe mode

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

maybe 50%, random crash

### Versions

Atom    : 1.34.0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.15
git 2.16.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015

### Additional Information

On windows 10 version 1803.
Visual Studio says the crash is in tree sitter parser.
Label: crash

Title: Bitmap fonts break GTK menus
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When the global gtk font is set to a bitmap font (with `lxappearance`), GTK dialogs render all characters as squares. This only happens in Atom (even chromium works fine). If I set the font to something like Roboto, start Atom, then change it back, the Atom dialogs will display fine.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use a bitmap font for gtk applications ([zevv-peep](http://zevv.nl/play/code/zevv-peep/) in my case)
2. Start Atom, open the "Open File" dialog
3. all text is rendered as squares

**Expected behavior:** 
All text gets displayed in the bitmap font

**Actual behavior:**
it's just squares
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23422690/51682447-bec50480-1fe7-11e9-917e-cf0b0dd99447.png)


**Reproduces how often:**
always

### Versions
```
atom --version

Atom    : 1.34.0
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm --version

apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.15+
git 2.20.1
```
Running on Debian Sid

### Additional Information

Font used is http://zevv.nl/play/code/zevv-peep/

Title: Incorrectly Saving a file in a FUSE folder (cryptomator vault)
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I want to save a new file to a [cryptomator](https://cryptomator.org/) vault folder. But often the file content is changed automatically after saving it. I found one example that I can reproduce every time, shared below.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create and unlock a [cryptomator](https://cryptomator.org/) FUSE vault folder.
2. Open Atom editor and create test.txt inside the cryptomator FUSE vault folder.
3. Enter the following contents in the file:
```
1
2
3
4
```
4. Save the file.
5. Delete the line 2 and 3 so that you see the following content:
```
1
4
```
6. Save the file.
7. The content has automatically changed to and saved into the file:
```
1
4
3
4
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
After the second save (step 6), the file content should have remained as described in step 5.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
The content changed as described in step 7.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%. Tested it 5 times. On two different machines.

### Versions

atom 1.34.0
apm  2.1.3
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.34.0
python 2.7.15rc1
git 2.17.1

OS: Ubuntu 18.04
Cryptomator 1.4.1

### Additional Information
Cannot reproduce the issue with other editors like gedit and sublimetext.

Screenshot:
![atom-cryptomator-vault-save](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14300004/51538172-83d89a80-1e48-11e9-8d1e-4dc6fc33c860.gif)

Title: Subpixel anti-aliasing stops working if CSS is used to add smooth scrolling
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I wanted to add smooth scrolling to text editors because Atom seems to not have this option and isn't smooth by default, it only is in the settings editor. But doing so breaks subpixel anti-aliasing, which makes font a bit blurry compared to other text editors.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Put this in your stylesheet, based on a comment on another issue https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10276#issuecomment-323538272:
```less
atom-text-editor.editor > div > .scroll-view > div,
atom-text-editor.editor > div > .gutter-container > div {
    transition: -webkit-transform .09s ease;
}
```
2. Open Atom in safe mode
3. Open any file big enough to be scrolled (it can be plain text)
4. Take a screenshot and zoom it: see subpixel anti-aliasing works
5. Scroll through about half the visible height, and go back to the top. Take another screenshot: notice there is no subpixel anti-aliasing anymore.

It comes back if the file is reopened, but the same steps make it break everytime.

**Expected behavior:**

I expected subpixel antialiasing to just work.
There is another issue with this way of adding smooth scrolling (text lags behind when scrolling), but I did not expect this to affect subpixel antialiasing at all. Those features sound fairly unrelated, but I'm not an expert.

**Actual behavior:**

Subpixel antialiasing stops working.

**Reproduces how often:**

99% (everytime a text editor gets scrolled by more than about a few lines)

### Versions

Atom: 1.33.1 x64
Electron: 2.0.16
Chrome: 61.0.3163.100
Node: v8.9.3
OS: Windows 7 64 bits

Title: Precision scrolling on Linux with Wayland
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

First to clarify some definitions that often get conflated:

* smooth scrolling - adding animated transitions between scroll positions to smooth out the document motion. This is usually the best you can do with mouse wheels, which themselves usually have fixed rotation increments.
* Precision scrolling - touchpads can provide scroll events that are tied directly to your finger position, so the user has continuous control of the document position. This is also sometimes called "pixel-perfect" scrolling (but that seems like a misnomer to me because there isn't a 1-to-1 mapping from touchpad pixels to screen pixels, and AFAICT scroll events are reported as floating-point values).

This issue is about precision scrolling, not smooth scrolling.

There's [an issue](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5359) that's mostly focused on "smooth scrolling", but I wanted to try to extract the precision scrolling, which is a separate issue.

In [this comment](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5359#issuecomment-340161559) @damianmoore says that precision scrolling is working on Linux but that he hasn't tested Wayland. I'm using Wayland and it does not seem to be working.

If you're interested in how Wayland / GTK handle scroll events I did a pretty deep dive [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/issues/1308#note_336954). Not sure how much is relevant to Atom though.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set up a linux machine with Gnome-Shell / Wayland (I'm using Arch Linux)
2. Install atom 
3. scroll a document with a touchpad

**Expected behavior:** scrolling should precisely follow my fingers

**Actual behavior:** document scrolls in fixed step sizes

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.33.0
Electron: 3.0.11
Chrome  : 66.0.3359.181
Node    : 10.2.0
```

Wayland 1.16.0
Gnome-shell 3.30.2
Label: linux

Title: Tree-sitter won't allow single-line comment block folding
Body:
*Edit by @rsese: copied over https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/issues/607 since the problem doesn't apply to a single language.  Original issue opened by jbrew138, made some edits to provide a few more details.  Also reported for Go at https://github.com/atom/language-go/issues/165 and affects other languages like C, Java, and Ruby.*

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After updating to Atom 1.32.0, single line comment blocks ("//") over multiple lines can no longer be folded, manually or using folding from the edit menu. Multi-line comments ("/* ... */") can still be folded.

I assume it's related to the new tree-sitter setting that was enabled by default starting with the latest version. Disabling "Use Tree Sitter Parsers" restores the old behavior, and the single-line comment blocks can be folded again. The same goes when running in safe mode as well.

I'm not aware if this is the new behavior intended with the new tree-sitter grammar, so I'm reporting it as a bug.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a JavaScript file with this content:

```js
// hello
// world
```
2. Try to fold the comment block

### Expected behavior

You can fold the comment block at `// hello`.

### Actual behavior

You can't fold the comment block.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.32.0
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
Windows: 10 Pro, v1709 16299.547
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Tree-Sitter: Tree-Sitter parser is not used with "non-default" extensions
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

For some file extensions, when I open a file with Tree-Sitter parsers enabled, the old parser is used. Selecting the current language/grammar again re-parses the file using Tree-Sitter.

I have tested this on the following file extensions/grammars:

- `.mjs`, `.es` - JavaScript
- `.erb`, `.ruby` - Ruby

This problem **does not** occur when opening a file with the following ("default") extensions, meaning that Tree-Sitter is used immediately after opening the file (expected behaviour):

- `.js` - JavaScript
- `.rb` - Ruby

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable Tree-Sitter parsers
2. Create a file with any of the "offending" file extensions listed above and write some valid code for that language ([example file with offending extension here](https://github.com/strvcom/atlas.js/blob/master/packages/atlas/src/atlas.mjs))
3. Observe old parsing system being used
4. Select the currently-selected syntax using the `Set Syntax` command
5. Observe the tree-sitter parsing system being used (some colouring changes will occur in buffer)

**Expected behavior:** Tree-Sitter parsers being used all the time for all extensions associated with a language

**Actual behavior:** Tree-Sitter parsers are only being used after manually re-selecting the syntax of the currently opened file

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time for all "non-default" file extensions

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.33.0-beta3
Electron: 2.0.11
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
```

### Additional Information

> **NOTE**: The term "non-default" has no meaning beyond what seems as "default" for Atom for the given language, based solely on which file extensions are properly parsed using Tree-Sitter on first opening. No further meaning implied.

I made an ugly gif showcasing the problem. ðŸŽ¨ 

![atom tree-sitter not being used](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3058150/49023672-0110c780-f198-11e8-9920-0112e86ac7bd.gif)
Label: d â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Error when running `atom -version` instead of `atom --version`
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I made a typo atom `-version` for atom `--version` , the following error dialog was displayed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
```
atom -version
```

Title: TextMate grammar API to get ranges of matching scopes in selection
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

---

Keep in mind that Atom is highly customizable in a number of ways and we strongly prefer that you consider these options before filing this issue:

* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/basic-customization/: tweak Atom's configuration, styles, and keybindings.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/atom-packages/: install a community package.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/: use the Atom API in your init script, to create a package, or to enhance an existing package.

If you're convinced that none of these options are appropriate for the feature you want, please explain why that's the case by completely filling out the issue template below.

Also note that the Atom team has finite resources so it's unlikely that we'll work on feature requests. If we're interested in a particular feature however, we'll follow up and ask you to submit an RFC to talk about it in more detail.

-->

## Summary

Add a grammar API call to get an array of ranges of all scopes that match the given scope in the given selection.

The scope is not a selector; instead, it supports selector like syntax for a single scope. So `a.*.c` works like normal, but not things like negation (basically whatever relies on knowing more than the scope for a given tag).

E.g., where `|` is the selection end, and we look for `string` in
```js
let foo = |"bar"
let baz = ["quux", "wib|ble"]
```
it would return an array of the ranges of all three strings.

## Motivation

~~Overengineering~~ a TextMate solution to https://github.com/atom/toggle-quotes/issues/36. To toggle quotes for all strings in the selection, it wants to get the ranges of all strings in that selection. This feature request is an attempt to provide the functionality, as well as possibly being generally useful.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

Supporting true scope selectors is technically possible, but probably slows it down a lot. My current implementation balances scope tags, and only inspects tags one at a time and caches the result.

Alternatively, that issue could be resolved by doing a similar thing to this request in the `toggle-quotes` package itself, but not have it as part of any API.

## Additional context

I've got a probably working version ready for TextMate, so this issue is more to see if it's good to add as part of the API.

A similar feature would probably be good for Tree-sitter too, but I haven't got that yet.


The method could also be extended to take multiple selections (e.g., all selections in the TextEditor) and take multiple scopes, even blacklisted and whitelisted scopes (so it's more like a selector).

Title: Add Mac Services support to File/Folder context menus
Body:
## Summary

While #10213 has the highly useful goal of providing text-based Mac Services, I'd also like to see file/folder-based Mac Services to be available upon context menu clicks of tab and Project Tree files and folders.

## Motivation

I'd like to be able to right-click a tab to have the repository of that file be opened in SourceTree (version control app) or use other services (including Automator-created ones) based on a clicked file/folder without leaving Atom.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

A package could be designed for a one-off solution, but without integrating with Mac's cross-application Services system, one would be forced to design solutions which can't leverage this Mac-standard means of inter-app communication.

## Additional context

I want to do the equivalent to this within Atom file context menus:
![screen shot 2018-11-23 at 8 45 27 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20234/48925224-42854680-eefc-11e8-992b-f96b2a6b195c.png)

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After using any shortcut key, the input may get no respond with Microsoft Pinyin IME.

### Steps to Reproduce

1.Switch to Microaft PinYin
2.Use any shortcut key (such as Ctrl + S , backspace and so on..)
3.type something

**Expected behavior:** The floating window of IME shows up

**Actual behavior:** nothing happended. After several keys were pressed down, it came normal.

**Reproduces how often:** 80%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.32.2
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.2
python
git
visual studio

OS : Windows 10 1803

### Additional Information

The number of keys before it came normally is not sure. Seems that just pressing Ctrl or Alt or waiting for a while will avoid this problem.
Label: needs-reproduction

Title: Specific project keeps project pane from opening more than two files
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On Ubuntu 18.04, [this repo](https://github.com/open-craft/configuration) when opened in Atom, allows me to click on two files in the sidebar. Both will open but a third won't. The filename I click highlights, but nothing opens.

There is nothing in the console log. Additionally, when trying this outside of safe mode, if I press ctrl-alt-p to bring up my project switcher, it can't find any projects.

Other repos work fine.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone [this repo](https://github.com/open-craft/configuration)
2. Open in Atom
3. Try to open files

**Expected behavior:** Files to open when clicked on

**Actual behavior:** Nada

**Reproduces how often:** Always for me

### Versions

Atom    : 1.32.1
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.1
python 2.7.15rc1
git 2.17.1
Label: needs-reproduction

Title: Allow regex based tree-sitter injection selectors
Body:
## Summary

Tree-sitter grammars can set [injections for a given file scope](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/a384dde3f5978d804306bc2033b7aae8570ceeb2/src/grammar-registry.js#L422), but cannot apply themselves to arbitrary grammars. They should be allowed to use a regex like syntax (possibly even a ScopeSelector) to target multiple file root scopes.

## Motivation

Writing a `tree-sitter-todo` package, but can't apply it to all grammars cleanly. Ideally, it would use `*` to target all grammars, though a blacklist / whitelist of targets is even better.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

I can iterate through all loaded grammars and add it like that, but I don't think this is particularly reliable or robust.

## Additional context

I've got the [`language-todo`](https://github.com/Aerijo/language-todo) and [`tree-sitter-todo`](https://github.com/Aerijo/tree-sitter-todo) stuff mostly worked out, but this prevent it from being applied to all files like the TextMate version is.

Also, apologies for the excessive use of the external scanner. It was the easiest way to do it, and allows for customisation (separate issue).
Label: tree-sitter

Title: Overlapping text in editor
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

We're noticing funky text overlapping...

![image 5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7910250/48657039-6834bc00-e9e1-11e8-9b85-130ba6cc4075.png)
![pasted_image_at_2018-11-16__10_54_pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7910250/48657040-6a971600-e9e1-11e8-8a6b-0c69da7ba0d9.png)

This might have to do with the fact that we are heavily using block decorations... we might be hitting some kind of line measurement race condition?

### Steps to Reproduce

Haven't found a way to reproduce this consistently. @vanessayuenn seems to see it a lot.

apm dev-link the github package and check out the `commit-preview` branch (currently head is at https://github.com/atom/github/pull/1767/commits/d33f3e945030a013db972fae4f4f75d70d354281), view a changed file with multiple changed lines, and try staging/unstaging lines a bunch.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

No funky text overlapping

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Text overlapping

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

@vanessayuenn seems to get it fairly frequently. Maybe 25% of the time?

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

@vanessayuenn can you update this issue with the versions you're on?

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld any thoughts? ðŸ’­ Does this look familiar to you at all?
Label: editor-rendering

Title: Writing tests for Tree-sitter grammars
Body:
## Summary

Requesting API methods to easily parse text and access the scopes it's given when using a Tree-sitter grammar. I.e., a `tokenizeLine` equivalent.

## Motivation

The TS grammar has a large set of tests already, but we are currently not testing how the tree is translated into scopes by Atom. While the tree is generally more useful, the scopes are important for syntax highlighting and backwards compatibility with existing scope based packages.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

I tried accessing it in a test as follows (for `language-javascript`), but it's ugly and the scope is just reported as `source.js` for everything
```cson
# spec/tree-sitter-javascript-spec.js
fs = require 'fs'
path = require 'path'
{ Range } = require 'atom'
TextEditor = null
buildTextEditor = (params) ->
  if atom.workspace.buildTextEditor?
    atom.workspace.buildTextEditor(params)
  else
    TextEditor ?= require('atom').TextEditor
    new TextEditor(params)

describe "JavaScript grammar", ->
  grammar = atom.grammars.grammarForScopeName("source.js")
  languageMode = atom.grammars.languageModeForGrammarAndBuffer(grammar, buildTextEditor({}).buffer)


  beforeEach ->
    atom.config.set('core.useTreeSitterParsers', true)

    waitsForPromise ->
      atom.packages.activatePackage("language-javascript")

    runs ->
      grammar = atom.grammars.grammarForScopeName("source.js")
      languageMode = atom.grammars.languageModeForGrammarAndBuffer(grammar, buildTextEditor({}).buffer)

  it "parses the grammar", ->
    expect(grammar).toBeTruthy()
    expect(grammar.scopeName).toBe "source.js"

  describe "assignment", ->

    it "tokenizes", ->
      languageMode.buffer.buffer.setText("let foo = 5;")
      tree = languageMode.parse(grammar.languageModule, null, new Range([0,0], [Infinity, Infinity]))

      expect(tree.rootNode.type).toBe "program" # no point to this; just confirming it's as expected

      expect(languageMode.scopeDescriptorForPosition({row: 0, column: 1}).scopes).toEqual ["source.js", "storage.type"]
```

## Additional context

/cc @maxbrunsfeld. I did try to get it working before resorting to this issue.

Title: Can't type in Chinese using the Windows software keyboard
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Steps to Reproduce

1. With focus in Atom, bring up the windows software keyboard.
	a. If not on a touch device, right click the windows taskbar and turn on 'Show touch keyboard button'
	b. Click the newly added button to bring up the software keyboard.
2. Switch the input language to Microsoft Pinyin (Chinese, Simplified)
3. Hit Enter on the software keyboard to create a new line.
4. Start typing normally to begin a composition.

**Expected behavior:** Composition starts and I can type in Chinese.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing is inserted into the editor.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.32.2
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
Windows : 1809 (October update)

### Additional Information

This is due to the following `if` block:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/d2c38ac36a46c067b7f1fe1edc41bcf7b4b13e73/src/text-editor-component.js#L1716-L1728

The code block is gated on `lasKeydown` whose logic is maintained in the following:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/d2c38ac36a46c067b7f1fe1edc41bcf7b4b13e73/src/text-editor-component.js#L1672-L1690

In this scenario Chromium/Atom does not receive a `keydown` before the composition starts.
The first code block then incorrectly associates the composition event with the previous keydown (Enter Key) and then cancels the user action as that key was previously `defaultPrevented`.

The main issue is that there isn't a guarantee for there to be a key event before the compositionstart event (See W3C for [compositionstart](https://w3c.github.io/uievents/#event-type-compositionstart)).
> When a keyboard is used to feed an input method editor, this event type is generated after a keydown event, but speech or handwriting recognition systems MAY send this event type without keyboard events.

I believe resetting `lastKeydown` on keyUp would prevent the composition event form being associated to the incorrect key event.

*Edit by @rsese: Based on the pointer above, I see that code was added in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/15266 and it looks like it landed in 1.20 where I could still reproduce.  But then going back to 1.19.0, the touch keyboard using Microsoft Pinyin worked ok.)*
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: File rendering breaks with some files after folding
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add specific repro steps /cc https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16078#issuecomment-370791712 and https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18415#issuecomment-481195317*

Rendering of a file can break (the bottom portion of the file doesn't render) with some files after folding:

1. Open a new file and copy/paste https://raw.githubusercontent.com/atom/tree-view/154b1e0e237b15bed1b0b6bc0803ddf071eb43fb/spec/tree-view-package-spec.coffee - make sure to leave the cursor at the bottom of the file
2. Scroll up to 4347 and fold
3. Fold 4372

Note that the bottom part of the file no longer renders as you scroll up/down:

![fold-render-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/734194/55907175-9f2b8a00-5b9b-11e9-9a77-f0a2cf770a87.gif)

Reproduced on macOS 10.12.6 with 1.37.0-nightly32.

Don't see a `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined` error as originally reported but the original report was a while ago...

---

[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. Open some file with code, the files that cause this for me are .js
2. Start collapsing a couple or ALL functions or objects so you see all 500 lines or so reduced to about the appearance of 50 lines.
3. Start messing with the code a bit, for me things start getting sketchy where some lines are longer than the IDE is interpreting. Meaning I click my mouse cursor at the end of a line, but the IDE will only let me move the keyboard cursor to somewhere in between the end of the line and the front and will only let me move to the next line and not the remainder of that line. This is fixed by editing the line a bit. (Shown here: https://gfycat.com/IllinformedFemaleBubblefish)
4. Eventually somehow this leads into scrolling up or down in the editor to spit out an endless stream of errors like this one. (Shown Here: https://gfycat.com/GlumMassiveChipmunk)

**Atom**: 1.32.2 x64
**Electron**: 2.0.9
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.11.6
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:14

TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined
    at DisplayLayer.collapseHardTabs (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:14:87524)
    at DisplayLayer.translateScreenPosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:14:85217)
    at DisplayMarkerLayer.t.exports.DisplayMarkerLayer.translateToBufferMarkerLayerFindParams (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:14:1099894)
    at DisplayMarkerLayer.t.exports.DisplayMarkerLayer.findMarkers (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:14:1097459)
    at decorationCountsByLayer.forEach (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:514669)
    at Map.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at DecorationManager.decorationPropertiesByMarkerForScreenRowRange (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:514643)
    at TextEditorComponent.queryDecorationsToRender (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:81701)
    at TextEditorComponent.updateSyncBeforeMeasuringContent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:69794)
    at TextEditorComponent.updateSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:67306)
    at TextEditorComponent.didMouseWheel (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:92055)
```

### Commands

```
  8x -2:16.1.0 core:move-up (input.hidden-input)
  2x -2:09.4.0 core:move-right (input.hidden-input)
  3x -2:08.8.0 core:move-left (input.hidden-input)
  2x -2:07.8.0 core:move-right (input.hidden-input)
     -2:06.5.0 core:move-left (input.hidden-input)
     -2:06.3.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
  4x -2:04.7.0 core:move-right (input.hidden-input)
     -1:59.4.0 core:move-left (input.hidden-input)
     -1:59.1.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
  2x -1:58.2.0 core:save (input.hidden-input)
     -1:34 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
  7x -1:33.6.0 core:move-right (input.hidden-input)
  3x -1:32 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
  2x -1:30.4.0 core:save (input.hidden-input)
  2x -1:20.1.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
  2x -1:16.5.0 core:copy (input.hidden-input)
```

### Non-Core Packages

```
atom-clock 0.1.16 
npm-install 4.0.4 
platformio-ide-terminal 2.8.4 
```
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

![fold-render-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/734194/55907175-9f2b8a00-5b9b-11e9-9a77-f0a2cf770a87.gif)

Reproduced on macOS 10.12.6 with 1.37.0-nightly32.

Don't see a `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined` error as originally reported but the original report was a while ago...

---

[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. Open some file with code, the files that cause this for me are .js
2. Start collapsing a couple or ALL functions or objects so you see all 500 lines or so reduced to about the appearance of 50 lines.
3. Start messing with the code a bit, for me things start getting sketchy where some lines are longer than the IDE is interpreting. Meaning I click my mouse cursor at the end of a line, but the IDE will only let me move the keyboard cursor to somewhere in between the end of the line and the front and will only let me move to the next line and not the remainder of that line. This is fixed by editing the line a bit. (Shown here: https://gfycat.com/IllinformedFemaleBubblefish)
4. Eventually somehow this leads into scrolling up or down in the editor to spit out an endless stream of errors like this one. (Shown Here: https://gfycat.com/GlumMassiveChipmunk)

**Atom**: 1.32.2 x64
**Electron**: 2.0.9
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.11.6
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

```
    at TextEditorComponent.updateSyncBeforeMeasuringContent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:69794)
    at TextEditorComponent.updateSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:67306)
    at TextEditorComponent.didMouseWheel (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/<embedded>:11:92055)
```

Title: Wrap anonymous nodes in quotes in the log cursor syntax tree scope command
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

It's confusing to know if a node is anonymous or not when logging the cursor syntax tree scope. Anonymous nodes are selected with a different syntax in the grammar files so it's useful to know.

Also some nodes like `>` are not escaped in the notification so it starts a markdown quote.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/48225677-c5a38a00-e39d-11e8-868d-4229f3ef3a09.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open an untitled tab in Atom
2. Change the language mode to `c++`
3. Enter the following contents
```c++
template <class myType>
myType GetMax (myType a, myType b) {
 return (a>b?a:b);
}
```
4. Place the cursor in front of a `>` character for example on the first line.
5. Run `editor:log-cursor-syntax-tree-scope`

**Expected behavior:** The last line in the notification to be `">"` instead of a markdown quote.

**Actual behavior:** 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/48225677-c5a38a00-e39d-11e8-868d-4229f3ef3a09.png)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18411/commits/32d632ba9e8c35bae83f516c09ab2dcd6f67e11d

### Additional Information

No

Title: Alt+LMB (Left Mouse Button) double click for subword selection
Body:
## Summary

Alt+LMB (Left Mouse Button) double click for subword selection.

## Motivation

You can select words via `ctrl-left` and `ctrl-right`, also subwords via `alt-`. And you can select words via mouse by double click, but you can't select subwords via mouse.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

I saw #2306, but it's about single click, as I understood.

Anyway, it can be configurable (I don't need for suggested selection there).

For now I don't see something (`lmb`, `mouse`, `click`) with mouse in Keybindings Settings.

## Additional context

It's very handy for snake_cased syntax, like Ruby, without `_` in Non Word Characters. I think for camelCased it's also handy.

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The license type of the official DEB package build is shown as "Proprietary" in Ubuntu gnome-software
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5124946/47747379-9fc00c00-dc5e-11e8-9df1-8d2d979c10a6.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download official atom deb (stable or beta)
2. Open with Software Install (Ubuntu Software)

**Expected behavior:** MIT license ? https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/LICENSE.md

**Actual behavior:** License shown as "Proprietary"

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

atom 1.32.0 and 1.33.0-beta
Ubuntu 18.04
gnome-software 3.28.1

Title: Reopen Project includes redundant folders when adding multiple folders.
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After adding multiple folders to a project, either in one hit, or one after the other (with no intervening activity) the Reopen Project list contains an entry for each folder added. It ends up looking like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8662551/47738144-bbf88480-dc2f-11e8-83ae-327e7d58129c.png)

But what I'd expect to see is just the final entry, at the top, as this is the net state of my project. The negative effect is that other projects are then pushed off the end of the list prematurely.

I believe it should not do this. A possible mitigating ability might be to allow right-click and delete of items on the list.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new session.
2. Use Add Project Folder to add several folders.
3. Immediately use Add Project Folder to add several more folders.

A single entry in the Reopen Project list with the cumulative set of folders.

An entry for every additional folder added; 6 folders, results in 6 entries.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

`````
Windows : 10.0.17134
Atom    : 1.32.0
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
`````
### Additional Information

None.
Label: d â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Uncaught (in promise) Error: Git status failed
Body:
*Edit by @rsese: [tracked down](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18323#issuecomment-433202517) to libgit2 issue with split indices, blocked on libgit2/libgit2#4857

---

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When inside a specific git repository, the git status is not shown (no modified files in the tree view, `git-diff` does not show in the gutter). The console shows the message **Uncaught (in promise) Error: Git status failed** - first without backtrace, then repeatedly from `refreshStatus`.

![screenshot from 2018-10-25 10-48-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/719105/47487899-a48e5580-d843-11e8-9cce-1eacff0e0347.png)

When doing a new clone of the repo, this error goes away. However, the original repo behaves correctly as far as actual git is concerned. "git status" and friends work fine, "git fsck" only complains about a few dangling commits.

The problem is still present in a pristine configuration when `~/.atom` is moved.
How can I help debug this?

### Versions

Atom    : 1.32.0
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.0
python 2.7.15+
git 2.19.1

Running on Ubuntu cosmic.

### Additional Information

While trying to track down the problem, I've created two virtually identical repositories (config, refs, logs, ...): Atom has problems in d1, but d2 works fine:

~~~
$ diff -rq d1 d2
Files d1/.git/index and d2/.git/index differ
Only in d1/.git/objects: 11
Only in d1/.git/objects: 5f
Only in d1/.git/objects: 68
Only in d1/.git/objects: b4
Files d1/.git/objects/info/packs and d2/.git/objects/info/packs differ
Only in d1/.git/objects/pack: pack-20a94249e63269d7b59974d0d529c07a5e29807d.idx
Only in d1/.git/objects/pack: pack-20a94249e63269d7b59974d0d529c07a5e29807d.pack
Only in d2/.git/objects/pack: pack-8aff7d7262227cb2a24cf3f65e1f30c400c55ab6.idx
Only in d2/.git/objects/pack: pack-8aff7d7262227cb2a24cf3f65e1f30c400c55ab6.pack
Only in d1/.git: sharedindex.16d97c0a7524fd1b515c287d74b47367e57c221f
Only in d1/.git: sharedindex.a4ce308bc375047ee0159e068e3feaab60f3c98f
Only in d1/.git: sharedindex.ec671bc7c8d35eead5907da03e51948439ad3c7d
~~~
Label: blocked

Title: Uncaught (in promise) Error: Git status failed

*Edit by @rsese: [tracked down](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18323#issuecomment-433202517) to libgit2 issue with split indices, blocked on libgit2/libgit2#4857

---

### Description

When inside a specific git repository, the git status is not shown (no modified files in the tree view, `git-diff` does not show in the gutter). The console shows the message **Uncaught (in promise) Error: Git status failed** - first without backtrace, then repeatedly from `refreshStatus`.

When doing a new clone of the repo, this error goes away. However, the original repo behaves correctly as far as actual git is concerned. "git status" and friends work fine, "git fsck" only complains about a few dangling commits.

The problem is still present in a pristine configuration when `~/.atom` is moved.
How can I help debug this?

### Versions

### Additional Information

~~~
$ diff -rq d1 d2
Files d1/.git/index and d2/.git/index differ

Only in d1/.git/objects/pack: pack-20a94249e63269d7b59974d0d529c07a5e29807d.pack
Only in d2/.git/objects/pack: pack-8aff7d7262227cb2a24cf3f65e1f30c400c55ab6.idx
Only in d2/.git/objects/pack: pack-8aff7d7262227cb2a24cf3f65e1f30c400c55ab6.pack
Only in d1/.git: sharedindex.16d97c0a7524fd1b515c287d74b47367e57c221f
Only in d1/.git: sharedindex.a4ce308bc375047ee0159e068e3feaab60f3c98f
Only in d1/.git: sharedindex.ec671bc7c8d35eead5907da03e51948439ad3c7d
~~~

Title: Grammar prioritization changed in 1.32
Body:
### Prerequisites

*Edit by @rsese: not reproduced in safe mode because the repro steps need `language-babel`*

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I upgraded Atom to v.1.32.0 and I noticed that custom grammars do not persist anymore.
According to:

https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/grammar/
> When the grammar of a file is changed, Atom will remember that for the current session.

### Steps to Reproduce

Here's an example with [`language-babel`](https://atom.io/packages/language-babel)

1. Open a JavaScript file
2. Press CTRL + SHIFT + L to change the grammar to "Babel ES6 JavaScript"
3. Close and reopen the same file

![atom-bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1186409/47448497-77e52a00-d7c0-11e8-9e04-74968a303598.gif)

**Expected behavior:**

The new file should be opened with the "Babel ES6 JavaScript" grammar

**Actual behavior:**

The new file is opened with the "JavaScript" grammar instead

### Versions

Mac OS 10.14

apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.0
python 2.7.15
git 2.17.1

### Workaround

Uncheck "Use Tree Sitter Parsers" from Settings -> Core
![screenshot_20181029_183818](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1186409/47668925-fa4b6080-dba9-11e8-883b-743449cef099.png)
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Pressing COMMAND+A in the mac help menu search field closes it and selects all the code in the active editor]

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Press SHIFT+COMMAND+? to bring up the help search box.
2. Type something.
3. Press COMMAND+A

**Expected behavior:** Select all text in the search box.

**Actual behavior:** Close search box and select all text in editor.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.31.2
Electron: 2.0.7
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm  2.1.1
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.31.2
python 2.7.5
git 1.9.5

Mac OS X Mavericks (10.9.5)

### Additional Information

1. The standard keyboard shortcuts âŒ˜C, âŒ˜V, and âŒ˜X are also affected. They close the search menu and instead act on the current document/selection.
2. Firefox exhibits the same bug. Finder, TextMate, and iTerm are examples that behave correctly.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Migrate core package 'wrap-guide' into Atom repo
Body:
This issue tracks the steps necessary to migrate the [`wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) package into the core `atom/atom` repository under the `packages` path:

## Migration Checklist

### Phase 1 - Prepare repo for migration

- [ ] Merge or close existing pull requests on the [`atom/wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) repository

Some guidelines for merging vs closing PRs:

- **Merge** when the PR is small, useful, has no merge conflicts with `master`, and has passing tests
- **Close** when the changes are non-trivial, the PR has conflicts with `master`, or there are failing tests in CI

If you close a PR, let the user know that we are currently moving the repository over to `atom/atom` so they should feel free to reopen the pull request there once the package code has been migrated.

### Phase 2 - Migrate the package code

- [ ] Create a fresh branch off `master` in your local clone of `atom/atom` with the name `migrate-wrap-guide-package`
- [ ] Delete Atom's `node_modules`, `script/node_modules`, and `apm/node_modules` folders if they exist
- [ ] Make sure Atom's `package-lock.json` file is unmodified, use `git checkout -- package-lock.json` if it isn't
- [ ] Clone the [`atom/wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) repo into the `packages` path of your local Atom repository and then delete its `.git` subfolder
- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/wrap-guide` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Open `packages/wrap-guide/package.json` and change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Open Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `wrap-guide` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "wrap-guide": "file:./packages/wrap-guide",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `wrap-guide` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
- [ ] Open `packages/README.md` and perform the following edits:
  - [ ] Update the second column of the **wrap-guide** row to reflect the new local path for the package:
    ```
    [`./wrap-guide`](./wrap-guide)
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the following line toward the end of the file:
    ```
    [wrap-guide]: https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide
    ```
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'wrap-guide' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` with the title "âž¡ Migrate core package 'wrap-guide' into ./packages".  For convenience, you may use the following message in your PR body:
  ```
  ### Description of the Change

  This PR migrates the core [`wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) package into `atom/atom`.  See issue #18286 for more information.
  ```
- [ ] If any CI tests fail, investigate and fix the failures until CI goes green
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/wrap-guide` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/wrap-guide), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`wrap-guide`](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.  You can use the following PR description text:
  ```
  As of **INSERT MIGRATION PR LINK**, the `wrap-guide` package is now a part of the core Atom repository. This pull request updates `README.md` to reflect that fact. We'll be archiving this repository shortly.

  /cc atom/atom#18286
  ```
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:
Label: package-migration

Title: Migrate core package 'status-bar' into Atom repo
Body:
This issue tracks the steps necessary to migrate the [`status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) package into the core `atom/atom` repository under the `packages` path:

## Migration Checklist

### Phase 1 - Prepare repo for migration

- [ ] Merge or close existing pull requests on the [`atom/status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) repository

Some guidelines for merging vs closing PRs:

- **Merge** when the PR is small, useful, has no merge conflicts with `master`, and has passing tests
- **Close** when the changes are non-trivial, the PR has conflicts with `master`, or there are failing tests in CI

If you close a PR, let the user know that we are currently moving the repository over to `atom/atom` so they should feel free to reopen the pull request there once the package code has been migrated.

### Phase 2 - Migrate the package code

- [ ] Create a fresh branch off `master` in your local clone of `atom/atom` with the name `migrate-status-bar-package`
- [ ] Delete Atom's `node_modules`, `script/node_modules`, and `apm/node_modules` folders if they exist
- [ ] Make sure Atom's `package-lock.json` file is unmodified, use `git checkout -- package-lock.json` if it isn't
- [ ] Clone the [`atom/status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) repo into the `packages` path of your local Atom repository and then delete its `.git` subfolder
- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/status-bar` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Open `packages/status-bar/package.json` and change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Open Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `status-bar` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "status-bar": "file:./packages/status-bar",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `status-bar` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
- [ ] Open `packages/README.md` and perform the following edits:
  - [ ] Update the second column of the **status-bar** row to reflect the new local path for the package:
    ```
    [`./status-bar`](./status-bar)
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the following line toward the end of the file:
    ```
    [status-bar]: https://github.com/atom/status-bar
    ```
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'status-bar' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` with the title "âž¡ Migrate core package 'status-bar' into ./packages".  For convenience, you may use the following message in your PR body:
  ```
  ### Description of the Change

  This PR migrates the core [`status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) package into `atom/atom`.  See issue #18282 for more information.
  ```
- [ ] If any CI tests fail, investigate and fix the failures until CI goes green
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/status-bar` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/status-bar), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`status-bar`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.  You can use the following PR description text:
  ```
  As of **INSERT MIGRATION PR LINK**, the `status-bar` package is now a part of the core Atom repository. This pull request updates `README.md` to reflect that fact. We'll be archiving this repository shortly.

  /cc atom/atom#18282
  ```
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/status-bar/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:
Label: package-migration
