Title: Migrate core package 'open-on-github' into Atom repo
Body:
This issue tracks the steps necessary to migrate the [`open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) package into the core `atom/atom` repository under the `packages` path:

## Migration Checklist

### Phase 1 - Prepare repo for migration

- [ ] Merge or close existing pull requests on the [`atom/open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) repository

Some guidelines for merging vs closing PRs:

- **Merge** when the PR is small, useful, has no merge conflicts with `master`, and has passing tests
- **Close** when the changes are non-trivial, the PR has conflicts with `master`, or there are failing tests in CI

If you close a PR, let the user know that we are currently moving the repository over to `atom/atom` so they should feel free to reopen the pull request there once the package code has been migrated.

### Phase 2 - Migrate the package code

- [ ] Create a fresh branch off `master` in your local clone of `atom/atom` with the name `migrate-open-on-github-package`
- [ ] Delete Atom's `node_modules`, `script/node_modules`, and `apm/node_modules` folders if they exist
- [ ] Make sure Atom's `package-lock.json` file is unmodified, use `git checkout -- package-lock.json` if it isn't
- [ ] Clone the [`atom/open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) repo into the `packages` path of your local Atom repository and then delete its `.git` subfolder
- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/open-on-github` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Open `packages/open-on-github/package.json` and change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Open Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `open-on-github` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "open-on-github": "file:./packages/open-on-github",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `open-on-github` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
- [ ] Open `packages/README.md` and perform the following edits:
  - [ ] Update the second column of the **open-on-github** row to reflect the new local path for the package:
    ```
    [`./open-on-github`](./open-on-github)
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the following line toward the end of the file:
    ```
    [open-on-github]: https://github.com/atom/open-on-github
    ```
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'open-on-github' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` with the title "âž¡ Migrate core package 'open-on-github' into ./packages".  For convenience, you may use the following message in your PR body:
  ```
  ### Description of the Change

  This PR migrates the core [`open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) package into `atom/atom`.  See issue #18278 for more information.
  ```
- [ ] If any CI tests fail, investigate and fix the failures until CI goes green
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/open-on-github` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/open-on-github), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`open-on-github`](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.  You can use the following PR description text:
  ```
  As of **INSERT MIGRATION PR LINK**, the `open-on-github` package is now a part of the core Atom repository. This pull request updates `README.md` to reflect that fact. We'll be archiving this repository shortly.

  /cc atom/atom#18278
  ```
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/open-on-github/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:
Label: triaged

Body:
This issue tracks the steps necessary to migrate the [`keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) package into the core `atom/atom` repository under the `packages` path:

## Migration Checklist

### Phase 1 - Prepare repo for migration

- [ ] Merge or close existing pull requests on the [`atom/keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) repository

Some guidelines for merging vs closing PRs:

- **Merge** when the PR is small, useful, has no merge conflicts with `master`, and has passing tests
- **Close** when the changes are non-trivial, the PR has conflicts with `master`, or there are failing tests in CI

If you close a PR, let the user know that we are currently moving the repository over to `atom/atom` so they should feel free to reopen the pull request there once the package code has been migrated.

### Phase 2 - Migrate the package code

- [ ] Create a fresh branch off `master` in your local clone of `atom/atom` with the name `migrate-keybinding-resolver-package`
- [ ] Delete Atom's `node_modules`, `script/node_modules`, and `apm/node_modules` folders if they exist
- [ ] Make sure Atom's `package-lock.json` file is unmodified, use `git checkout -- package-lock.json` if it isn't
- [ ] Clone the [`atom/keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) repo into the `packages` path of your local Atom repository and then delete its `.git` subfolder
- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/keybinding-resolver` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Open `packages/keybinding-resolver/package.json` and change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Open Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `keybinding-resolver` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "keybinding-resolver": "file:./packages/keybinding-resolver",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `keybinding-resolver` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
- [ ] Open `packages/README.md` and perform the following edits:
  - [ ] Update the second column of the **keybinding-resolver** row to reflect the new local path for the package:
    ```
    [`./keybinding-resolver`](./keybinding-resolver)
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the following line toward the end of the file:
    ```
    [keybinding-resolver]: https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver
    ```
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'keybinding-resolver' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` with the title "âž¡ Migrate core package 'keybinding-resolver' into ./packages".  For convenience, you may use the following message in your PR body:
  ```
  ### Description of the Change

  This PR migrates the core [`keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) package into `atom/atom`.  See issue #18275 for more information.
  ```
- [ ] If any CI tests fail, investigate and fix the failures until CI goes green
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/keybinding-resolver` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/keybinding-resolver), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`keybinding-resolver`](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.  You can use the following PR description text:
  ```
  As of **INSERT MIGRATION PR LINK**, the `keybinding-resolver` package is now a part of the core Atom repository. This pull request updates `README.md` to reflect that fact. We'll be archiving this repository shortly.

  /cc atom/atom#18275
  ```
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:
Label: package-migration

If you close a PR, let the user know that we are currently moving the repository over to `atom/atom` so they should feel free to reopen the pull request there once the package code has been migrated.

### Phase 2 - Migrate the package code

- [ ] Create a fresh branch off `master` in your local clone of `atom/atom` with the name `migrate-bookmarks-package`
- [ ] Delete Atom's `node_modules`, `script/node_modules`, and `apm/node_modules` folders if they exist
- [ ] Make sure Atom's `package-lock.json` file is unmodified, use `git checkout -- package-lock.json` if it isn't
- [ ] Clone the [`atom/bookmarks`](https://github.com/atom/bookmarks) repo into the `packages` path of your local Atom repository and then delete its `.git` subfolder
- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/bookmarks` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Open `packages/bookmarks/package.json` and change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Open Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `bookmarks` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "bookmarks": "file:./packages/bookmarks",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `bookmarks` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
- [ ] Open `packages/README.md` and perform the following edits:
  - [ ] Update the second column of the **bookmarks** row to reflect the new local path for the package:
    ```
    [`./bookmarks`](./bookmarks)
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the following line toward the end of the file:
    ```
    [bookmarks]: https://github.com/atom/bookmarks
    ```
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'bookmarks' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` with the title "âž¡ Migrate core package 'bookmarks' into ./packages".  For convenience, you may use the following message in your PR body:
  ```
  ### Description of the Change

  This PR migrates the core [`bookmarks`](https://github.com/atom/bookmarks) package into `atom/atom`.  See issue #18273 for more information.
  ```
- [ ] If any CI tests fail, investigate and fix the failures until CI goes green
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`bookmarks`](https://github.com/atom/bookmarks) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`bookmarks`](https://github.com/atom/bookmarks) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/bookmarks` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/bookmarks), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`bookmarks`](https://github.com/atom/bookmarks) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.  You can use the following PR description text:
  ```
  As of **INSERT MIGRATION PR LINK**, the `bookmarks` package is now a part of the core Atom repository. This pull request updates `README.md` to reflect that fact. We'll be archiving this repository shortly.

  /cc atom/atom#18273
  ```
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/bookmarks/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:
Label: triaged

Title: Show each grammar's responsible package & link to its settings
Body:
_From @saizai on April 17, 2018 11:21_

Sometimes multiple packages provide very similar (or identically named) items. Or you forget what you installed that provides this and don't want it any more.

So, always show (right-aligned) the package responsible for this entry, and a gear button linking to its settings page.

crosslink: https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/issues/60

_Copied from original issue: atom/grammar-selector#56_
Label: packages/grammar-selector

Title: Document not focused when go-to-line dialog launched from status bar.
Body:
*@DI-john commented on Jun 30, 2017, 8:25 PM UTC:*

### Description

Launching the go-to-line dialog from the clickable `line:column` number presented in the [status bar](https://github.com/atom/status-bar) updates the cursor position, but fails to re-focus the editor window properly so that the cursor is rendered in the new location.

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Open a file in the editor
2.  Click on the `line:column` number to launch the go-to-line dialog
    [![status-bar](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3628420/27752737-9072b870-5db0-11e7-8d6a-06be7f223675.png)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3628420/27752737-9072b870-5db0-11e7-8d6a-06be7f223675.png)
3.  Enter a destination line and column number
4.  Observe that the cursor is not focused in the text document

**Expected behavior:**

Cursor is focused at the desired position.

**Actual behavior:**

Cursor is still hidden.

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

```

```
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

```

```
macOS Sierra Version 10.12.5

```

*This issue was moved by [daviwil](https://github.com/daviwil) from [atom/go-to-line#46](https://github.com/atom/go-to-line/issues/46).*
Label: packages/go-to-line

Title: [tree-sitter] Scope level grammar injections
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

---

Keep in mind that Atom is highly customizable in a number of ways and we strongly prefer that you consider these options before filing this issue:

* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/basic-customization/: tweak Atom's configuration, styles, and keybindings.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/atom-packages/: install a community package.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/: use the Atom API in your init script, to create a package, or to enhance an existing package.

If you're convinced that none of these options are appropriate for the feature you want, please explain why that's the case by completely filling out the issue template below.

Also note that the Atom team has finite resources so it's unlikely that we'll work on feature requests. If we're interested in a particular feature however, we'll follow up and ask you to submit an RFC to talk about it in more detail.

-->

@maxbrunsfeld thanks for the great work on tree-sitter. Especially the correct codefolding is huge. 

## Summary

~~Is it possible create scope level grammar injections for tree sitter grammars not tied to a specific language?~~ It would be great to create scope level grammar injections for tree sitter grammars not tied to a specific language.

## Motivation

The [hydrogen](https://atom.io/packages/hydrogen) package allows interactive code execution in a language agnostic way using [jupyter kernels](http://jupyter.org). To define breakpoints or code cells, it supports a custom syntax inside line comments motivated by IDEs like Spyder or Matlab.
It would be great to be able to highlight these breakpoints in all tree sitter languages.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

Currently this is easily possible using legacy first mate grammars. We ship a small custom grammar with hydrogen to support the highlighting in a language agnostic way:

```cson
'scopeName': 'hydrogen.breakpoints'
'name': 'Hydrogen breakpoints'
'injectionSelector': 'comment.line'
'patterns': [
  {
    'match': '%%| %%| <codecell>| In\\[[0-9 ]*\\]:?'
    'name': 'entity.name.section.breakpoint'
  }
]
```

Tree sitter grammars solved some long standing issue we were having due to incorrect code folding. It would be excellent if we could still support highlighting in of custom selectors inside comment strings. Currently injections seam to be only possible for a specific language.
Label: regression

## Motivation

The [hydrogen](https://atom.io/packages/hydrogen) package allows interactive code execution in a language agnostic way using [jupyter kernels](http://jupyter.org). To define breakpoints or code cells, it supports a custom syntax inside line comments motivated by IDEs like Spyder or Matlab.
It would be great to be able to highlight these breakpoints in all tree sitter languages.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

Currently this is easily possible using legacy first mate grammars. We ship a small custom grammar with hydrogen to support the highlighting in a language agnostic way:

```cson
'scopeName': 'hydrogen.breakpoints'
'name': 'Hydrogen breakpoints'
'injectionSelector': 'comment.line'
'patterns': [
  {
    'match': '%%| %%| <codecell>| In\\[[0-9 ]*\\]:?'
    'name': 'entity.name.section.breakpoint'
  }
]
```

Tree sitter grammars solved some long standing issue we were having due to incorrect code folding. It would be excellent if we could still support highlighting in of custom selectors inside comment strings. Currently injections seam to be only possible for a specific language.
Label: triaged

Title: Starting Atom from a folder containing a directory named 'package.json' causes a crash
Body:
I've just installed the latest update, which came to me via an alert in atom. When I restarted atom, I got no window. Running `atom -f` renders this:

A JavaScript error occurred in the main process

Title: Dalek reports: "<unknown> is deprecated" issues
Body:
_From @Ben3eeE on April 18, 2018 12:58_

To reproduce:

1. Run `apm install tree-view`
1. Start Atom
1. Check the deprecation message. Dalek reports that `tree-view` is deprecated and asks to report issue
1. Click to report issue

**Expected:** The title of the issue is `tree-view is deprecated.`
**Actual:** The title of the issue is `<unknown> is deprecated.`

Refs: https://github.com/atom/spell-check/issues/248

_Copied from original issue: atom/dalek#10_
Label: packages/dalek

Title: sRGB no longer working in Mojave
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Color profile is no longer making any difference when set to sRGB, both the display color profile and the override setting in Atom produce the same colors. This happens in safe mode also

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use the standard color profile on mac
2. Open Atom and set the color profile to sRGB
3. You will notice no change between the two

**Expected behavior:** 
Previously on High Sierra switching to sRGB would make the colors more vibrant compared with the default system profile. After upgrading to Mojave the colors seem dull and there is no visible change between the two settings

**Actual behavior:**
There is no change between settings

**Reproduces how often:**
100%

### Versions
macOS 10.14 (18A391)
Atom    : 1.31.1
Electron: 2.0.7
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
apm  2.1.1
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.31.1
python 2.7.10
git 2.17.1

### Additional Information

![atom](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2401925/46351457-4eb4fc00-c64f-11e8-8be1-75a3dbb19c84.png)

Title: Mojave dark mode
Body:
## Summary

Dark mode support for Atom on macOS Mojave.

## Motivation

Many themes in Atom have both a light and dark variant. It would be nice if Atom could take advantage of the system-wide dark mode in macOS Mojave and switch between the light and dark variants of the user-selected theme according to the system setting in System Preferences > General > Appearance.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

Atom should at least change the theme of the title bar, if changing the whole theme is too much.

Title: Uncaught TypeError: this.grammar.onDidUpdate is not a function
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add repro steps via https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18133#issuecomment-437346066:

> 1. View Style Guide, access from menu or shortcut CTRL+SHIFT+G.
> 2. Leaving Style Guide open, close Atom.
> 3. Restart Atom, error raised as below.

If you close the style guide before restarting Atom, there's no error.

Title: WSL Ubuntu aliases stop working after update to 1.31
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

My aliases to open Atom in Ubuntu Windows Subsystem for Linux stop working after updating from 1.30 to 1.31. Using commands like "atom ." instead give me the following error:

```
net.js:200
    this._handle.open(options.fd);
                 ^

Error: EINVAL: invalid argument, uv_pipe_open
    at new Socket (net.js:200:18)
    at createWritableStdioStream (internal/process/stdio.js:164:16)
    at process.getStdout [as stdout] (internal/process/stdio.js:14:14)
    at console.js:246:38
    at NativeModule.compile (bootstrap_node.js:596:7)
    at Function.NativeModule.require (bootstrap_node.js:541:18)
    at setupGlobalConsole (bootstrap_node.js:310:41)
    at startup (bootstrap_node.js:70:7)
    at bootstrap_node.js:608:3
```


my alias for opening atom in WSL Ubuntu is: `alias atom='/mnt/c/Windows/System32/cmd.exe /c "atom"'`. 

### Steps to Reproduce

Updating to 1.31 produces this issue. Rolling back to 1.30 resolves this until atom updates to 1.31.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.31.0
Electron: 2.0.7
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

I'm running Windows 10.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Display issues using Mojave through Parallels VM
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [instructions for starting in safe mode do not work. No such command ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Running macOS Mojave 10.14 through Parallels VM. (both Parallels 13 and 14)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download and install free trial of Parallels 14. 
2. Download Mojave from App store
3. Create new Parallels VM using Mojave install file
4. Download and install Atom
5. Open Atom

**Expected behavior:** Expected to be able to view welcome screen, open and view preferences, create and edit new documents

**Actual behavior:** Completely blank screen. Some of the contents of the welcome screen will appear as you move the mouse across the app window. But those areas disappear as soon as the mouse moves out of range.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time. I have never been able to get it to display correctly.

### Version is current one available from the site: https://atom.io/ and the version number cannot be displayed due to this issue.

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. (as mentioned previously, this does not work. command not found)

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Title: Change indicator overlaps tab text when using "Minimum" tab sizing
Body:
_From @thomasjo on April 11, 2017 16:58_

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When enabling the _Minimum_ tab sizing functionality, the pending change indicator overlaps the tab text. See screenshot below.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3622/24920612/28992a6a-1ee8-11e7-9d2b-e1fb4299791e.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set _Tab Sizing_ to _Minimum_
2. Open any file.
3. Make a change to the file, but do not save.

**Expected behavior:** Seeing the full text/title of tabs with the unsaved changes.

**Actual behavior:** The pending change indicator should not overlap the tab text.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.17.0-dev-99273a9d7
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

macOS 10.12.4.

### Additional Information

This issue is also present in [atom/one-light-ui](https://github.com/atom/one-light-ui).


_Copied from original issue: atom/one-dark-ui#200_
Label: packages/one-dark-ui

Title: Atom SIGBUS crash on CentOS
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm encountering ongoing crashes of Atom in my CentOS 7.5.1804 environment.  Atom will run for some time, then bring up the "close/reload/keep it open" dialog box. Happens fairly frequently, maybe every 5-10 minutes.

Continues to happen in safe mode, after blowing away the .atom directory, after uninstalling and reinstalling atom. Has happened across a number of Atom versions, current version in use being 1.29.0.

Here's the message in the system logs:
   localhost abrt-hook-ccpp: Process 3116 (atom) of user 501 killed by SIGBUS - dumping core

On the surface, this has some similarities to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10271, an issue that seems to be dormat and unresolved. In my case, this happens when files on a VMware Fusion shared folder are open.

### Steps to Reproduce


**Expected behavior:** 

Atom should not randomly crash.

**Actual behavior:** 

As described above, randomly crashes.

**Reproduces how often:** 

Every 5-10 minutes.

### Versions

CentOS 7.5.1804 
Atom 1.29.0.

### Additional Information

Happening in a VMware Fusion VM.

Title: Atom opens/reopens windows in bizarre locations
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When running with multiple displays, Atom makes some very strange choices about where to place new windows.

This is most pronounced when reloading an existing window with âŒ¥âŒ˜I âŒ˜R, which typically re-opens the window on display 0, regardless of where it was before.

It seems to vaguely seek out another place where there's an Atom windowâ€”in some cases, switching Mission Control Spaces to do so. It's hard to underscore how irritating this is.

### Steps to Reproduce

*Space switching:*
1. Have multiple Spaces
2. Open an Atom window in one space
3. Create or move to another space
4. Open Terminal
5. Run `atom .`
6. Behold! You have been transported back to the space you were trying to escape, a metaphor for the inescapability of oppression in a world of pervasive capitalism.

*Reloading a window:*
1. Have multiple displays
2. Put Atom on a secondary display
2. Open the dev console (âŒ¥âŒ˜I) 
3. Reload window with âŒ˜R
4. Where is it? Where's the window? *it's a bloody mystery*

**Expected behavior:** Atom should (re)open windows on the same display and Space that the last key window occupied.

When opening a new window, you can defend the behavior of opening on the same Space as an existing Atom window, provided the Space is visible. Switching Spaces seems always wrong, and is massively disorienting to boot.

**Actual behavior:** We seem to pick the Space / display with an active Atom window, switching to it if necessary. But sometimes we don't.

**Reproduces how often:** *So* often.

### Versions
macOS High Sierra
Atom    : 1.30.0-dev-a41a345de
Electron: 2.0.4
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

### Additional Information

I suspect we may need to kick this over to Electron; or, it might be inescapable garbage from macOS. Anyway, since we're talking papercuts, I wanted to capture this one.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Launching Atom on WSL fails with no window and no error messages
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have a fresh install of Atom on Windows Subsystem Linux, and running the `atom` command results in no behavior

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install Atom using instructions on: https://flight-manual.atom.io/getting-started/sections/installing-atom/#platform-linux (have tries both `apt install` and downloading the deb package)
2. Try to launch atom from the command line:
 ```
$ atom
$ atom .
$ atom -f
$ atom --safe
$ atom --clear-window-state
$ atom -l ~/atom-log.log    # <-- no file is produced
```
3. Remove `~/.atom`, try again

**Expected behavior:**
Atom launches

**Actual behavior:**
Nothing - no window, no error message, nothing happens

**Reproduces how often:**
Always

### Versions
```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.29.0
Electron: 2.0.5
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
$ apm --version
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.29.0
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
$ uname -a
Linux PWR 4.4.0-17134-Microsoft #137-Microsoft Thu Jun 14 18:46:00 PST 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS
Release:        16.04
Codename:       xenial
$ 
```

### Additional Information

If I have `top` running when I launch atom, I can see a bunch of atom-related processes start up, but they all disappear after a few seconds.

![atom-top-output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7400761/44234075-a7016e80-a173-11e8-93a6-e662f02072e7.png)
Label: needs-reproduction

Title: Migrate core package 'encoding-selector' into Atom repo
Body:
This issue tracks the steps necessary to migrate the [`encoding-selector`](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector) package into the core `atom/atom` repository under the `packages` path:

## Migration Checklist

### Phase 1 - Prepare repo for migration

- [ ] Merge or close existing pull requests on the [`atom/encoding-selector`](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector) repository

Some guidelines for merging vs closing PRs:

- **Merge** when the PR is small, useful, has no merge conflicts with `master`, and has passing tests
- **Close** when the changes are non-trivial, the PR has conflicts with `master`, or there are failing tests in CI

If you close a PR, let the user know that we are currently moving the repository over to `atom/atom` so they should feel free to reopen the pull request there once the package code has been migrated.

### Phase 2 - Migrate the package code

- [ ] Create a fresh branch off `master` in your local clone of `atom/atom` with the name `migrate-encoding-selector-package`
- [ ] Delete Atom's `node_modules` folder if you've built there before and make sure Atom's `package-lock.json` file is unmodified
- [ ] Clone the  [`atom/encoding-selector`](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector) repo into the `packages` path of your local Atom repository and then delete its `.git` subfolder
- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/encoding-selector` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Edit Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `encoding-selector` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "encoding-selector": "file:./packages/encoding-selector",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `encoding-selector` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
  - [ ] Change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Update the second column of the **encoding-selector** row in `packages/README.md` to reflect the new local path for the package:
  ```
  [`./packages/encoding-selector`](./encoding-selector)
  ```
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'encoding-selector' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Run the full suite of Atom tests with `script/test` and verify that they pass locally
- [ ] If any tests fail, investigate and fix them then commit the fixes to your branch
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` to verify that CI passes
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`encoding-selector`](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`encoding-selector`](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/encoding-selector` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/encoding-selector), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`encoding-selector`](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:
Label: package-migration

- [ ] Delete any unnecessary repo configuration files in the `packages/background-tips` folder like `appveyor.yml`, `.travis.yml`, `ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md`, and `PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md`
- [ ] Remove any information from the package's `README.md` which will be inaccurate after the migration is complete (e.g. CI status badges or contribution instructions)
- [ ] Edit Atom's `package.json` file to change the following:
  - [ ] Update the `background-tips` entry in `packageDependencies` to reflect the local path of the package:
    ```
    "background-tips": "file:./packages/background-tips",
    ```
  - [ ] Delete the `background-tips` entry in the `dependencies` section since it may contain a hardcoded tarball link.  This will help avoid issues in the next step
  - [ ] Change the `repository` field to point to the main repo URL `https://github.com/atom/atom`
- [ ] Run a full Atom build using `script/build` and verify that there are no unexpected build errors
- [ ] Launch the Atom binary in the `./out` folder and manually verify that the migrated package is working without any obvious issues.  For example, if you're migrating a color theme, turn on that theme to make sure that it changes the editor colors as expected.
- [ ] Open the Chrome Developer Tools console (<kbd>Ctrl+Shift+I</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd+Option+I</kbd>) and ensure that there are no errors written there.  If there are, add them to this issue and investigate.
- [ ] Update the second column of the **background-tips** row in `packages/README.md` to reflect the new local path for the package:
  ```
  [`./packages/background-tips`](./background-tips)
  ```
- [ ] Commit the migrated package code and any changes to Atom's `package-lock.json` files to your branch using this commit message:
  ```
  :arrow_right: Migrate core package 'background-tips' into ./packages
  ```

### Phase 3 - Make sure the package works and send a PR

- [ ] Run the full suite of Atom tests with `script/test` and verify that they pass locally
- [ ] If any tests fail, investigate and fix them then commit the fixes to your branch
- [ ] Create a PR against `atom/atom` to verify that CI passes
- [ ] Once CI is clean and the PR is approved, merge it

### Phase 4 - Archive the [`background-tips`](https://github.com/atom/background-tips) repo

- [ ] Move all existing issues from the  [`background-tips`](https://github.com/atom/background-tips) repo to `atom/atom` using [github-issue-mover](https://github-issue-mover.appspot.com/) or a script
- [ ] Add a label titled `packages/background-tips` to the migrated issues so that they can be found easily
- [ ] Edit the original package repo's README.md (don't commit directly) to point contributors to the code's new home in `atom/atom`.  You can use the following text:
  ```
  ### This package is now a part of the [core Atom repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/packages/background-tips), please direct all issues and pull requests there in the future!

  ---
  ```
- [ ] Send a PR to the [`background-tips`](https://github.com/atom/background-tips) repository with the updated README.md so that watchers will be notified of the change.  You do not need to wait for reviews, it can be merged immediately.
- [ ] Archive the package repository by going to its [Settings page](https://github.com/atom/background-tips/settings), scroll down to the "Danger Zone" section and click "Archive this Repository"

Migration is now complete! :tada:

Title: Inconsistent Keyboard Shortcut Humanization
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description & Steps to Reproduce

1. Right click a text file (on MacOS) and you'll see a context menu item "Reveal in Tree View âŒ˜|"
2. Use the command palette to find "Reveal Active File" and the shortcut is "âŒ˜â‡§\"

These are the same shortcut ("â‡§\" is "|"), spelled different ways. It looks like Atom and Electron are humanizing these differently. Seeing two different shortcuts is confusing for users. (Also, the pipe is especially confusing because it isn't clear if it's a capital i, lower case L, etc.)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Consistency (:

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Inconsistency ):

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

OSX

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.29.0
Electron: 2.0.5
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
$ apm --version
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.29.0
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.5
```
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Atom doesn't open Preferences, About, Files, and more
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

For some reason, there are severeal things I cannot open in Atom anymore: Atom->About, Aom->Preferences, opening files, drag/drop files and probably more. I've tried anything: upgrading to 1.29, removing .atom and ~/Library and more, cheching leftover processes, running --safe, running as root, running as a new user. Nothing help: when I try to open the mentioned item, nothing happens, even running Atom from the command line doesn't show any message.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Open one of the items mentioned

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens the item as usually

**Actual behavior:** Anything whatsoever

**Reproduces how often:** always

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.29.0
Electron: 2.0.5
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

macOS 10.13.6
Label: stale

    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

A rapid, repeated keypress of a zoom command will "skip" by moving backwards to a prior scale. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a text buffer
2. Press ctrl/cmd-= or ctrl/cmd-- really, really quickly, as one might do while frantically trying to scale up the font size while presenting

**Expected behavior:**

The text size scales linearly, with each successive size larger than the last

**Actual behavior:**

A "skip" is witnessed, in which the text size actually moves backwards in size (i.e. it momentarily becomes smaller while trying to scale the text size up). This is best demonstrated visually:

![zooming](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/755844/43538186-2a78c880-9576-11e8-981b-42bef8d649f3.gif)

**Reproduces how often:**

90% of the time while rapidly scaling the text

### Versions
Atom 1.28 and Atom 1.29

### Additional Information

I have a feeling this is due to a race writing to and reading from the atom config while performing successive operations (i.e. a successive command reads from the config with `config.get` before the results of the prior command have been applied with a `config.set` call).
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Cannot See Atom Window with macOS 10.13.6
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom will startup but fail to load any windows when trying to use the program. This issue occurs both in safe mode and normal. I have downgraded to 1.27.2 where atom works fine again. Potentially a problem with the latest electron upgrade or the fact that I am using macOS 10.13.6 as the issue was noticed around the time the OS was updated. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom 
2. Applications boots but no windows are visible. I have tried opening files and using the command line to reset the view but to no prevail
3. Behaviour is repeated in safe mode
4. I have tried all three versions of 1.28 without any success

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Can see the editing screen

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
App boots but no screen loads, repeated in safe mode. Unable to use software

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
All the time, the application now unusable. 

### Versions
- 1.28.0
- 1.28.1
- 1.28.2

This is the second time I have posted this as the issue was closed with no success. Please let me know what other information I can provide to help replicate the bug.

Title: Migrate Atom's update distribution to Electron's update.electronjs.org service
Body:
Electron recently made the [update.electronjs.org](https://update.electronjs.org/) service available for open source Electron apps that use Squirrel for updates.  It would be great to move to this service so that we no longer need to maintain our own update service on atom.io.

I experimented with it briefly while working on PR #17538 but ran into a some issues that need to be resolved to support Atom's multiple release channels and 32/64-bit Windows:

- https://github.com/electron/update.electronjs.org/issues/58
- https://github.com/electron/update.electronjs.org/issues/59

I'll be working with them at some point in the near future to get these issues resolved.
Label: atom.io

Title: Atom UI Seems to be blurry over all for some reason??
Body:
Ok so this seems to happen randomly, but more recently its been consistent.
The Atom UI gets blurry, as you can see in the image. The code is shown crisp in the top part, but blurry in the bottom part. I tried changing the theme, but no difference (Default light and dark themes).

It gets clearer when I hover mouse over an element of the UI or a part of the code, and get blurrier and blurrier as I pull the mouse away from that element or part of code. 

I've check the windows display settings and the DPI is set to 100% only. 
 
![screenshot 78](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40825956/42272047-8f2dcc92-7fa2-11e8-989a-b0be5cd12cc0.png)


Running on Latest windows 10, 1080p 60hz screen. 
Asus ROG g751jy

UPDATE : 

Version ----
Atom    : 1.28.0
Electron: 2.0.3
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

Debugging -----
Safe Mode : Tried , getting the same result with UI elements, but code if fine. Then again as i said this issue seems to be pretty random.
Other debugging suggestions such as clearing saved state etc. didn't seem relevant to this issue.
There are no incompatible packages. And all packages are up to date


Disabling GPU seems to have done the trick, but I think its best to check it for a few days, as agagin, it a pretty random issue. Though it seems that This would be a permanent solution :)  
Thank you for directing me to the GPU debugging suggestion.

PS : Any specific reason that this is happening on my GPU? Its a pretty powerful card GTX 980M (4GB). At least for running atom it is. Can it be caused because of certain change in GPU settings?? because this is happening only since a few days. Previously, since the past year or so that I have been using Atom io, atom never had this issue on this machine. Any ideas?

Also, am I loosing anything by disabling GPU?

Thanks,
Bhavil Jain

Title: cannot search for packages inside atom editor GUI inside virtual box behind corporate proxy
Body:
I am unable to search for packages inside the atom editor GUI. Although `apm `via command line is running fine. I am able to install packages via `apm install` command. 
But with GUI it throws some error:
`getaddrinfo EAI_AGAIN atom.io:443`
The atom version I am using is
Atom    : 1.28.0
Electron: 2.0.3
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3 
I am working behind a proxy network and proxy settings are taken care off in the `~.apmrc `file.
One more thing that I am able to install featured packages via GUI but not search the new ones
I am working on 64-bit ubuntu 16.04 inside a virtual box with the host is Windows 10
Also, the atom is working fine with another Linux 32-bit machine in the same host inside a virtual box.

Title: Tree-sitter folding
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When a tree-sitter grammar contains a foldable construct with more than one line before the folding point, there are two folding arrows displayed. The first one one the line where the construct begins, and the second one on the line with the folding point. When folded, the first one does nothing.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable tree-sitter parsers and install language-python.
2. Open a python file with
```python
if True or \
   False:
    pass
```
3. Click one of the folding arrows
![unfolded](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/890465/42032224-28d2777c-7ad9-11e8-9d0b-0a1986d8a08d.png)
![folded](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/890465/42032234-2d9a7c46-7ad9-11e8-8dcd-825499ff1cdd.png)

**Expected behavior:** There should be only one folding arrow for each possible fold

**Actual behavior:** There are two arrows, and the first one does not work as expected

### Additional Information

The example is in python, but this is not a problem with language-python, and there probably are examples in other languages too.

### Versions

    Atom    : 1.28.0
    Electron: 2.0.3
    Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
    Node    : 8.9.3
Label: tree-sitter

Title: MacOS Inconsistent Text Selection shortcuts in save dialog
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The standard shortcut for selecting text to the beginning/end of the current word on macOS is Option-Shift-Left/Right (vs. Windows command of Ctrl-Shift-Left/Right). This works like normal in the editor window, but in the Save File dialog the macOS shortcut does not work (the Windows one is active instead).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Test behavior of Option-Shift-Left/Right and Ctrl-Shift-Left/Right in editor window
2. Save the file (or Save As...) so you get the save dialog
3. Compare the behavior here of Option-Shift-Left/Right and Ctrl-Shift-Left/Right 

**Expected behavior:**  The behavior is expected to be the same in both places (would expect Option-Shift-Left/Right to select to beginning/end of current word and Ctrl-Shift to do nothing).

**Actual behavior:** In the save dialog, Option-Shift-Left/Right seems to trigger something as the "Selection" menu flashes, but nothing happens to the cursor or selection. Ctrl-Shift-Left/Right does not make the selection menu flash, but does select and move cursor to beginning/end of the current word.  Oddly enough, Option-Left/Right moves the *cursor* to beginning/end of word, but Ctrl-Left/Right does not.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions
macOS 10.13.5

Atom    : 1.27.2
Electron: 1.7.15
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.27.2
python 3.6.5
git 2.15.2
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Ctrl-Shift-Left/Right does not make the selection menu flash, but does select and move cursor to beginning/end of the current word.  Oddly enough, Option-Left/Right moves the *cursor* to beginning/end of word, but Ctrl-Left/Right does not.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions
macOS 10.13.5

Atom    : 1.27.2
Electron: 1.7.15
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.27.2
python 3.6.5
git 2.15.2
Label: mac

### Description

Title: Atom is causing numerous taskgated errors on macOS
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When launching Atom from the Finder (or Alfred) it will cause many taskgated errors, per second: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93973/41479855-c75c6466-7089-11e8-8da7-6fb6260ba66a.png)

This causes the system to peg and the fans to turn on, which is hot and kills battery life.

Launching atom from the terminal (inside or outside of tmux) does _not_ reproduce the issue.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom from Dock
2. Observe numerous taskgated errors in Console.app, increased system load
3. Terminate Atom
4. Launch Atom from terminal
5. Observe that no excessive taskgated events are generated.

**Expected behavior:** Launching Atom should not cause my system to peg

**Actual behavior:** It pegs, many security events are generated

**Reproduces how often:** 100% (On my system)

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.27.2
Electron: 1.7.15
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.27.2
python 2.7.15
git 2.17.0

$ system_profiler SPSoftwareDataType
Software:

    System Software Overview:

      System Version: macOS 10.12.6 (16G1408)
      Kernel Version: Darwin 16.7.0
      Boot Volume: Macintosh HD
      Boot Mode: Normal
      Computer Name: Thneed
      User Name: Andrew Burns (aburns)
      Secure Virtual Memory: Enabled
      System Integrity Protection: Enabled
      Time since boot: 2:34
```

### Additional Information

I think this is related to atom/atom#13084 as I can mitigate the issue by adding the following section to my `Info.plist`:

```
<key>LSEnvironment</key>
<dict>
     <key>ATOM_DISABLE_SHELLING_OUT_FOR_ENVIRONMENT</key>
     <string>true</string>
</dict>
```

`/usr/local/bin/zsh -ilc 'command env'` does execute and returns the expected environment; however `ps aux | grep 'command env' | grep -v grep` does show that the task seems to hang when executed from Atom.
Label: mac

Title: FF has crisp(ish) and clear fonts. Atom editor/GUI has went throuh PS's blur filter.
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Entire atom GUI and editor blurry. Blurry fonts, blurry editor. Similar issues in VStudio.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download newest release from base page
2. Have LCD screen (DirectWrite issue?..) 

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Readable text. FF for me is pretty sharp.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Blurry screen everywhere.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
Newest.
Windows 10 x64 pro home, newest again.

### Additional Information
LCD Screen 2560x1400p,  at 120hz
AMD Radeon 7970
ClearType enabled
Have attempted many different atom startup flags, DPI scaling 'fixes', etc.
Using standard 100% DPI scaling, I don't use 125%+ etc.
Plenty of themes/fonts tried, did not solve. Nearly bricked computer with MacType xd


Any solutions would be stellar. Someway of changing to different antialiasing? No option I've done works etc. 
FF could be better but the editor is hands-down horrible.
![editorblurry](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13228731/41304599-295f93b2-6e60-11e8-8ff5-33749a060d40.PNG)
Label: needs-reproduction

Title: getVisibleRowRange() does not respect folded lines
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`getVisibleRowRange()` returns only all unfolded lines. When I fold something, the range gets messed up and no longer works reliably until I unfold everything.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open up the Atom developer console
2. Access the `getVisibleRowRange()` of the active editor
3. Fold and unfold lines and watch the range not changing.

**Expected behavior:** When I fold something, it should increase the range and match the start and end of the editor line count.

**Actual behavior:** It shows the start and end line count until I fold something, but then stays the same count, while it should increase to match the beginning and ending of the editor lines count.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time. It's probably intended (for earlier versions without code folding), but it should be changed now.

### Versions

Atom 1.27.2 x64
Windows 10 x64

### Additional Information

I also tried accessing
```
element.getFirstVisibleScreenRow()
element.getLastVisibleScreenRow()
```
but those commands above will show exactly the same wrong result as `getVisibleRowRange()`.

On top, my suggestion would be to maybe leave those function as they are (for backwards compatibility with packages) and add new ones which get all the visible lines (including the folded ones) and show the range reliably.

I was bugfixing a [package](https://github.com/camel-chased/editor-background) which has this exact issue mentioned above and I haven't found any functions to access all visible lines. Since those functions doesn't respect the folding, when something folds, the package missmatches lines and stuff get weird.

See [this](https://github.com/camel-chased/editor-background/blob/35f4d38cb57bf91dc89bb720dc4f72df7460c562/lib/editor-background.coffee#L781) for reference.

Title: Closing multiple unsaved files creates multiple unusable "Do you want to save" dialogues
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description


When closing multiple files with unsaved changes using the "Close all" or similar functionality creates multiple "Do you want to save this file before closing" dialogues. But only one of these dialogues can be used, because the other dialogues are opened "on top" of each other, so every other dialog is blocked until the they are resolved in order.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open multiple files and make changes to them without saving
   * <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>n</kbd>, Random letters, <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>n</kbd>, Random letters, <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>n</kbd>, Random letters, ...
2. Right click the tab-bar and select "Close all"

**Expected behavior:** Multiple dialogues are opened, but the order in which i resolve them does not matter. (The main Atom window stays blocked until all dialogues are resolved)

**Actual behavior:** Multiple dialogues are opened, but only one of them reacts to clicks.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
$ ./atom --version
Atom    : 1.27.2
Electron: 1.7.15
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```

```
$ uname -r
4.16.12-1-ARCH
```

Same issue as #17429, but this time with an official atom release... the issue was not fixed by using older versions of Electron, Chrome and Node, so i created [a new issue as requested by @rsese](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/17429#issuecomment-393263283)
Label: d â¬†ï¸?
