Same issue as #17429, but this time with an official atom release... the issue was not fixed by using older versions of Electron, Chrome and Node, so i created [a new issue as requested by @rsese](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/17429#issuecomment-393263283)
Label: v â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Unable to delete files on Fedora 28 (gvfs-trash is deprecated)
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

My issue is the same as in #15949 except it is not fixed. 

I am unable to delete file (or directory). When trying, the following message appears: `Is gvfs-trash installed?`

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Try to delete any file or directory
2. ???
3. Profit

**Expected behavior:** Deleting file should delete file

**Actual behavior:** The file is not deleted

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.27.1
Electron: 1.7.15
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```
```
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.27.1
python 2.7.15
git 2.17.1
```
```
OS: Fedora 28
```

### Additional Information
```
$ gvfs-trash
This tool has been deprecated, use 'gio trash' instead.
See 'gio help trash' for more info.
```
The `gio trash` is supposedly implemented since electron 1.7.2 and for some folks out there this problem was fixed with `Atom 1.25` (which included upgrade to `Electron 1.7.11`) but apparently I am on even newer Atom version, with even newer Electron and it still happens.

### EDIT1
#### More insight on the problem provided by @cutephoton:
> @Devligue This is a legit bug. The _tldr answer_ is that `_g_file_trash` may not be supported. In order for `_g_file_trash` to succeed, the following conditions must be met:
> 
> * The file being moved to trash is on the same partition as your home folder
>   **OR**
> * A trash folder already exists or can be created at the mount point and,
> * The trash folder is considered 'safe/secure' by verifying UID and restrictive permissions
> 
> **How this should probably be fixed...**
> 
> Atom does not have a fallback mechanism like offering the ability to permanently remove a file instead. This would address bring atom in line with gnome's graceful behaviour. The attached image show how Gnome Files (aka Nautilus) prompt the user to permanently delete the file (when trash not supported)
> 
> ![gnome's solution](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19512121/43511743-0dac32c0-952e-11e8-8af8-e0ef6cb916d0.png)
> 
> **Impact: Users with multiple disks and partitions**
> 
> Fedora/Redhat/etc: _Impacted_ due to default partition scheme that separates `/` and `/home` in to partitions. Files outside of the `/home` partition cannot be moved to trash.
> 
> Ubuntu: Less likely due to partition layout (`/home` is part of the `/` partition)
> 
> Conditions where users will be impacted:
> 
> * File systems with unix permissions:
>   
>   * _Impacted with workaround_ due to typical restrictive top-level directory permissions (root)
> * FAT/non-unix file systems:
>   
>   * User Session Mount (i.e. `/run/media/$USER/disk-label`): _No Impact_
>   * Fstab: _Impacted_ even with permissive umask. The default uid/gid is root. It will be unable to satisfy the requirements of a trash folder without additional options (uid/gid/umask).
> * Network shared folders: _Unknown/Did not test._
> 
> **Notes/Testing the Root Cause**
> 
> Note: Though I am confident that my analysis is decent enough, much of the code I was referencing was unfamiliar/new to me.
> 
> Initially I encountered this issue when I put files in a certain location like the reporter above. I created a delete-me file test as suggested above in the relevant directory, `/opt/cupenv`. I ran the command `strace gio trash delete-me.txt`. A abridged version of the output is here:
> 
> ```
> lstat("/opt/cupenv/delete-me.txt", {st_mode=S_IFREG|0664, st_size=6, ...}) = 0
> ...
> lstat("/.Trash-1000", 0x7ffde5ffb5b0)   = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
> mkdir("/.Trash-1000", 0700)             = -1 EACCES (Permission denied)
> ```
> That's unexpected. The API documentation for [g_file_trash](https://developer.gnome.org/gio/stable/GFile.html#g-file-trash) lacks some level of specificity.
> 
> > Sends file to the "Trashcan", if possible. This is similar to deleting it, but the user can recover it before emptying the trashcan. Not all file systems support trashing, so this call can return the G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED error.
> 
> One might assume (as I did): Given a path, if the user has permission to modify/delete the file, then GIO's g_file_trash API should succeed at removing the file in some manner. Perhaps, if trash functionality is not available, then there might be a fallback mechanism. In the case of `gio trash` I expected there to be a -f force option that would prioritize trash over permanently deleting the file. (`gio trash -f` only ignores files that don't exist)
> 
> Glib appears to implement GIO local file access using [glocalfile.c](https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/83a4cab12c2d00dbfe6013d071cff2da310109a4/gio/glocalfile.c#L1899). The trash algorithm looks like this:
> 
> * Is the path on the same partition as the user's home directory? If so, move the file to the home trash folder if possible and exit.
> * Given the path, locate the mount point top level directory (denoted as `$topdir` in source)
>   
>   * In my case, `/opt/cupenv/delete_me.txt` -> `/` (the primary partition)
>   * A more typical case: `/run/media/$USER/disk-label/a/b/c/d` would be `/run/media/$USER/disk-label`
> * If `$topdir` is found, pick one of `$topdir/.Trash/$UID` or `$topdir/.Trash-UID` folder.
>   
>   * If `$topdir/.Trash-UID` and `$topdir/.Trash/$UID` exists: Validate proper UID and file permission (or fail)
>   * Try to create folder `$topdir/.Trash-$UID`. Validate proper UID and file permission (or fail)
> 
> At the end of the function we find [`G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED` is returned](https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/83a4cab12c2d00dbfe6013d071cff2da310109a4/gio/glocalfile.c#L2059) when such a folder is not found and cannot be created.
> 
> ```
> if (trashdir == NULL)
> 	{
> 	  g_free (topdir);
>           g_set_io_error (error,
>                           _("Unable to find or create trash directory for %s"),
>                           file, G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED);
> 	  return FALSE;
> }
> ```
> I confirmed my understanding by creating a top level trash folder and using gio trash command.
> 
> ```
> sudo mkdir /.Trash-1000
> sudo chmod 0700 /.Trash-1000
> sudo chown fosterb:fosterb /.Trash-1000
> cd /opt/cupenv && echo hello > delete-me.txt; gio trash delete-me.txt
> ```
> Files located on the same partition as your home directory can always be moved to your user trash folder. On my operating system, the paths `/` and `/home` are separate partitions. I created a file `/home/tmp/x` where `tmp` and `x` are owned by my user. In this case, the files get moved to your `$HOME/.local/share/Trash` folder.
> 
> ```
> lstat("/home/tmp/x", {st_mode=S_IFREG|0644, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
> stat("/home/fosterb", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0700, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> access("/home", F_OK)                   = 0
> ....
> stat("/home/fosterb/.local/share", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> access("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash", F_OK) = 0
> stat("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0700, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> mkdir("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash/info", 0700) = -1 EEXIST (File exists)
> mkdir("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash/files", 0700) = -1 EEXIST (File exists)
> openat(AT_FDCWD, "/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash/info/x.trashinfo", O_RDONLY|O_CREAT|O_EXCL, 0666) = 7
> ```
> But when mounting disks (external or internal) using fstab or mount commands (as opposed to session-based mounting) issues can arise. I tested a FAT file system with umask=0000 and uid/gid set to root.
> 
> ```
> lstat("/mnt/giotest", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0777, st_size=8192, ...}) = 0
> lstat("/mnt", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> lstat("/mnt/giotest/.Trash", 0x7fffec5502c0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
> lstat("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000", 0x7fffec550230) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
> mkdir("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000", 0700) = 0
> lstat("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0777, st_size=8192, ...}) = 0
> unlink("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000")      = -1 EISDIR (Is a directory)
> rmdir("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000")       = 0
> file:///mnt/giotest/x: Unable to find or create trash directory for /mnt/giotest/x
> ```
> You can see gio trash going through the motions. The operations succeeds but the command still reports an error.
> 
> ```
> [fosterb@rose giotest]$ ls -lah
> total 12K
> drwxrwxrwx. 2 root root 8.0K Aug  1 00:36 .
> drwxr-xr-x. 4 root root 4.0K Aug  1 00:30 ..
> -rwxrwxrwx. 1 root root    0 Aug  1 01:23 x
> ```
> GLib/Gio will not write to a trash directory with incorrect permissions/ownership. (Security?) Without unix permissions, trash will always fail on these mount points. Modifying fstab to appear similar to options used during session mounts (UID/GID set to user vs root, umask is set appropriately). Conveniently the [source code](https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/83a4cab12c2d00dbfe6013d071cff2da310109a4/gio/glocalfile.c#L2046) has a comment that seems to strongly imply this is a known/expected.
> 
> ```
> 		  /* Ensure that the created dir has the right uid etc.
> 		     This might fail on e.g. a FAT dir */
> ```
> Most of this was unnecessary, but I figured I'd show my work.

### EDIT2
#### More insight, to not get confused as of the nature of the bug, and how to reproduce it (by @cutephoton as well):
> Yes, as reported, the ELECTRON_TRASH environment variable is needed. This is the issue referenced #15949 bug. The issue reported here is not related to #15949. The error message related to gvfs-trash is a blunt tool (even access denied errors produce the same error message) so I understand why people are responding here.
> 
> The reporter clarifies one of the key symptoms here:
> [#17452 (comment)](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/17452#issuecomment-396407349)
> 
> And that led to my deep dive. My deep dive details the specific cases where trash becomes unavailable (i.e. when a trash folder cannot be safely created).
> [#17452 (comment)](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/17452#issuecomment-409518547)
> 
> **I just revalidated my findings and unsurprisingly gio trash still fails.**
> 
> Anyhow, I wanted to clarify this so it doesn't get lost when/if atom devs look in to this issue.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Unable to delete files on Fedora 28 (gvfs-trash is deprecated)
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

My issue is the same as in #15949 except it is not fixed. 

I am unable to delete file (or directory). When trying, the following message appears: `Is gvfs-trash installed?`

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Try to delete any file or directory
2. ???
3. Profit

**Expected behavior:** Deleting file should delete file

**Actual behavior:** The file is not deleted

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.27.1
Electron: 1.7.15
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```
```
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.27.1
python 2.7.15
git 2.17.1
```
```
OS: Fedora 28
```

### Additional Information
```
$ gvfs-trash
This tool has been deprecated, use 'gio trash' instead.
See 'gio help trash' for more info.
```
The `gio trash` is supposedly implemented since electron 1.7.2 and for some folks out there this problem was fixed with `Atom 1.25` (which included upgrade to `Electron 1.7.11`) but apparently I am on even newer Atom version, with even newer Electron and it still happens.

### EDIT1
#### More insight on the problem provided by @cutephoton:
> @Devligue This is a legit bug. The _tldr answer_ is that `_g_file_trash` may not be supported. In order for `_g_file_trash` to succeed, the following conditions must be met:
> 
> * The file being moved to trash is on the same partition as your home folder
>   **OR**
> * A trash folder already exists or can be created at the mount point and,
> * The trash folder is considered 'safe/secure' by verifying UID and restrictive permissions
> 
> **How this should probably be fixed...**
> 
> Atom does not have a fallback mechanism like offering the ability to permanently remove a file instead. This would address bring atom in line with gnome's graceful behaviour. The attached image show how Gnome Files (aka Nautilus) prompt the user to permanently delete the file (when trash not supported)
> 
> ![gnome's solution](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19512121/43511743-0dac32c0-952e-11e8-8af8-e0ef6cb916d0.png)
> 
> **Impact: Users with multiple disks and partitions**
> 
> Fedora/Redhat/etc: _Impacted_ due to default partition scheme that separates `/` and `/home` in to partitions. Files outside of the `/home` partition cannot be moved to trash.
> 
> Ubuntu: Less likely due to partition layout (`/home` is part of the `/` partition)
> 
> Conditions where users will be impacted:
> 
> * File systems with unix permissions:
>   
>   * _Impacted with workaround_ due to typical restrictive top-level directory permissions (root)
> * FAT/non-unix file systems:
>   
>   * User Session Mount (i.e. `/run/media/$USER/disk-label`): _No Impact_
>   * Fstab: _Impacted_ even with permissive umask. The default uid/gid is root. It will be unable to satisfy the requirements of a trash folder without additional options (uid/gid/umask).
> * Network shared folders: _Unknown/Did not test._
> 
> **Notes/Testing the Root Cause**
> 
> Note: Though I am confident that my analysis is decent enough, much of the code I was referencing was unfamiliar/new to me.
> 
> Initially I encountered this issue when I put files in a certain location like the reporter above. I created a delete-me file test as suggested above in the relevant directory, `/opt/cupenv`. I ran the command `strace gio trash delete-me.txt`. A abridged version of the output is here:
> 
> ```
> lstat("/opt/cupenv/delete-me.txt", {st_mode=S_IFREG|0664, st_size=6, ...}) = 0
> ...
> lstat("/.Trash-1000", 0x7ffde5ffb5b0)   = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
> mkdir("/.Trash-1000", 0700)             = -1 EACCES (Permission denied)
> ```
> That's unexpected. The API documentation for [g_file_trash](https://developer.gnome.org/gio/stable/GFile.html#g-file-trash) lacks some level of specificity.
> 
> > Sends file to the "Trashcan", if possible. This is similar to deleting it, but the user can recover it before emptying the trashcan. Not all file systems support trashing, so this call can return the G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED error.
> 
> One might assume (as I did): Given a path, if the user has permission to modify/delete the file, then GIO's g_file_trash API should succeed at removing the file in some manner. Perhaps, if trash functionality is not available, then there might be a fallback mechanism. In the case of `gio trash` I expected there to be a -f force option that would prioritize trash over permanently deleting the file. (`gio trash -f` only ignores files that don't exist)
> 
> Glib appears to implement GIO local file access using [glocalfile.c](https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/83a4cab12c2d00dbfe6013d071cff2da310109a4/gio/glocalfile.c#L1899). The trash algorithm looks like this:
> 
> * Is the path on the same partition as the user's home directory? If so, move the file to the home trash folder if possible and exit.
> * Given the path, locate the mount point top level directory (denoted as `$topdir` in source)
>   
>   * In my case, `/opt/cupenv/delete_me.txt` -> `/` (the primary partition)
>   * A more typical case: `/run/media/$USER/disk-label/a/b/c/d` would be `/run/media/$USER/disk-label`
> * If `$topdir` is found, pick one of `$topdir/.Trash/$UID` or `$topdir/.Trash-UID` folder.
>   
>   * If `$topdir/.Trash-UID` and `$topdir/.Trash/$UID` exists: Validate proper UID and file permission (or fail)
>   * Try to create folder `$topdir/.Trash-$UID`. Validate proper UID and file permission (or fail)
> 
> At the end of the function we find [`G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED` is returned](https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/83a4cab12c2d00dbfe6013d071cff2da310109a4/gio/glocalfile.c#L2059) when such a folder is not found and cannot be created.
> 
> ```
> if (trashdir == NULL)
> 	{
> 	  g_free (topdir);
>           g_set_io_error (error,
>                           _("Unable to find or create trash directory for %s"),
>                           file, G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED);
> 	  return FALSE;
> }
> ```
> I confirmed my understanding by creating a top level trash folder and using gio trash command.
> 
> ```
> sudo mkdir /.Trash-1000
> sudo chmod 0700 /.Trash-1000
> sudo chown fosterb:fosterb /.Trash-1000
> cd /opt/cupenv && echo hello > delete-me.txt; gio trash delete-me.txt
> ```
> Files located on the same partition as your home directory can always be moved to your user trash folder. On my operating system, the paths `/` and `/home` are separate partitions. I created a file `/home/tmp/x` where `tmp` and `x` are owned by my user. In this case, the files get moved to your `$HOME/.local/share/Trash` folder.
> 
> ```
> lstat("/home/tmp/x", {st_mode=S_IFREG|0644, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
> stat("/home/fosterb", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0700, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> access("/home", F_OK)                   = 0
> ....
> stat("/home/fosterb/.local/share", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> access("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash", F_OK) = 0
> stat("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0700, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> mkdir("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash/info", 0700) = -1 EEXIST (File exists)
> mkdir("/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash/files", 0700) = -1 EEXIST (File exists)
> openat(AT_FDCWD, "/home/fosterb/.local/share/Trash/info/x.trashinfo", O_RDONLY|O_CREAT|O_EXCL, 0666) = 7
> ```
> But when mounting disks (external or internal) using fstab or mount commands (as opposed to session-based mounting) issues can arise. I tested a FAT file system with umask=0000 and uid/gid set to root.
> 
> ```
> lstat("/mnt/giotest", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0777, st_size=8192, ...}) = 0
> lstat("/mnt", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
> lstat("/mnt/giotest/.Trash", 0x7fffec5502c0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
> lstat("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000", 0x7fffec550230) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
> mkdir("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000", 0700) = 0
> lstat("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0777, st_size=8192, ...}) = 0
> unlink("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000")      = -1 EISDIR (Is a directory)
> rmdir("/mnt/giotest/.Trash-1000")       = 0
> file:///mnt/giotest/x: Unable to find or create trash directory for /mnt/giotest/x
> ```
> You can see gio trash going through the motions. The operations succeeds but the command still reports an error.
> 
> ```
> [fosterb@rose giotest]$ ls -lah
> total 12K
> drwxrwxrwx. 2 root root 8.0K Aug  1 00:36 .
> drwxr-xr-x. 4 root root 4.0K Aug  1 00:30 ..
> -rwxrwxrwx. 1 root root    0 Aug  1 01:23 x
> ```
> GLib/Gio will not write to a trash directory with incorrect permissions/ownership. (Security?) Without unix permissions, trash will always fail on these mount points. Modifying fstab to appear similar to options used during session mounts (UID/GID set to user vs root, umask is set appropriately). Conveniently the [source code](https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/83a4cab12c2d00dbfe6013d071cff2da310109a4/gio/glocalfile.c#L2046) has a comment that seems to strongly imply this is a known/expected.
> 
> ```
> 		  /* Ensure that the created dir has the right uid etc.
> 		     This might fail on e.g. a FAT dir */
> ```
> Most of this was unnecessary, but I figured I'd show my work.

### EDIT2
#### More insight, to not get confused as of the nature of the bug, and how to reproduce it (by @cutephoton as well):
> Yes, as reported, the ELECTRON_TRASH environment variable is needed. This is the issue referenced #15949 bug. The issue reported here is not related to #15949. The error message related to gvfs-trash is a blunt tool (even access denied errors produce the same error message) so I understand why people are responding here.
> 
> The reporter clarifies one of the key symptoms here:
> [#17452 (comment)](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/17452#issuecomment-396407349)
> 
> And that led to my deep dive. My deep dive details the specific cases where trash becomes unavailable (i.e. when a trash folder cannot be safely created).
> [#17452 (comment)](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/17452#issuecomment-409518547)
> 
> **I just revalidated my findings and unsurprisingly gio trash still fails.**
> 
> Anyhow, I wanted to clarify this so it doesn't get lost when/if atom devs look in to this issue.
Label: linux

Title: Unable to delete files on Fedora 28 (gvfs-trash is deprecated)
Body:

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

My issue is the same as in #15949 except it is not fixed. 

I am unable to delete file (or directory). When trying, the following message appears: `Is gvfs-trash installed?`

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Try to delete any file or directory
2. ???
3. Profit

**Actual behavior:** The file is not deleted

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

```
Atom    : 1.27.1
Electron: 1.7.15

Title: Atom crashes since 1.24.1 on Windows 10
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Atom crashes a few minutes (sometimes seconds) after start.

It always dumps the same error to the command line it was started from:
```
$ atom --safe
@ C:\Users\chuck\Desktop\Portables\atom 1.27.0-b1\Atom Beta x64
$
[33868:0501/052040.213:FATAL:layoutobject.cpp(1040)] Check failed: isRooted().
Backtrace:
        GetHandleVerifier [0x00007FF7B3468905+23093]
        GetHandleVerifier [0x00007FF7B34D8A63+482195]
        (No symbol) [0x00007FF7B3460554]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B54A401D+30342709]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B56AD474+32477836]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B54ED14B+30642019]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B54C9617+30495791]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B56BE8C9+32548577]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B56BFB0E+32553254]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B54A9C3A+30366290]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B54AA096+30367406]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B54AA0DF+30367479]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B56ABF1C+32472372]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B56AB78F+32470439]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B56A2FD3+32435691]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B53060F7+28647183]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B5305CD9+28646129]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B53594EC+28988164]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B53592E7+28987647]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B517C010+27033128]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B3D0C377+5603727]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B3924CD4+1510124]
        IsSandboxedProcess [0x00007FF7B3920998+1492912]

1. start atom
2. start working in it (do anything)
3. wait 5 minutes at most

**Expected behavior:** Not crashing.

**Actual behavior:** Crashing.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

I can reproduce this bug with every version of Atom (betas included) since  after 1.24.1. Actually I still use 1.24.1 as it works flawlessly and never crashes. I try periodically to update to a newer version - updating or making a standalone portable version, I tried both - with the same result (failure). The version of Atom used in this current report is:

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.27.0-beta1
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.24.1
python 2.7.13
git 2.14.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
OS versions:
```
Windows 10 Insider Preview 17134.1 (rs4_release) (and one or two previous IP versions before that)
Windows 10 Version 1803 for x64 (just upgraded a few hours ago)
```

### Additional Information

I use quite a lot of packages, but no matter that I can reproduce the crash with `atom --safe` too. (Actually it crashed after 3-4 secs after start last time I tried.) Anyway I attach the package list.
[package-list.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1962957/package-list.txt)

Additional details to add:
1. In the devtools console of Atom I get this message immediately after start:
`<embedded>:22786 'save-session.dataSaveFolder' could not set the default. Attempted default: undefined; Schema: {"type":"string","description":"The folder in which to save project states"}`
1. I believe that every time the crash occurs, it's when I move the mouse, like it's in a mouseover handler - of course I'm not sure, it's just a hunch.
1. I could report this bug in mid-march, but I thought it's a thing of the actual beta and it'll gone - it seems it chose to stay.
Label: blocked

Title: Missing GConf2 dependency in rpm package
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
The Atom rpm package is missing GConf2 dependency. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install Atom (using repository or directly with rpm package)
2. Try to launch atom

**Expected behavior:**
Atom gets launched correctly

**Actual behavior:**
Atom it's not launched because of the missing dependency. The error is:
$ /usr/share/atom/atom: error while loading shared libraries: libgconf-2.so.4: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

**Reproduces how often:** 
Always (until GConf2 is installed)

### Versions
All versions. Running on Fedora 27

### Additional Information
The missing dependency  doesn't get noticed when installing Atom on default Fedora Workstation
because some other package requires GConf2 which is already installed. However installing on a
customized environment highlights the problem. Altering the rpm with rpmrebuild and adding GConf2 as dependency solves the issue.
Label: linux

Title: Compound keybindings incorrectly displayed in menus
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Compound keybindings like `Ctrl-J Ctrl-K` are incorrectly displayed in menus and context menus:

![atom kbd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6735977/39300718-f777fa48-494c-11e8-9ae1-2946a81b1d1a.png)

I suspect this to be an Electron issue, but couldn't find anything about this, so I'm just opening this here.

### Steps to Reproduce
Execute the following code in the console or in your init script:
```
atom.keymaps.add('init', {'atom-workspace': {'ctrl-j ctrl-k': 'command-palette:show-hidden-commands'}}, 1)
atom.contextMenu.add({'atom-text-editor': [{label: 'keybinding test', command: 'command-palette:show-hidden-commands'}]})
``` 
and right click in a text editor.

**Expected behavior:** `Ctrl-J Ctrl-K` should be displayed next to the menu entry.

**Actual behavior:** `Ctrl-K` is displayed next to the menu entry.

**Reproduces how often:** Always.

### Versions
```
>atom --version

Atom    : 1.26.0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

>apm --version
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.26.0
python
git 2.16.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
### Additional Information
Also see https://github.com/JunoLab/Juno.jl/issues/79 and https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15903.
Label: triaged

Title: Data loss when editing symlinked project
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Atom fails to use proper filepath when a project is opened in a symlinked project and a file is opened using "Find File"

### Steps to Reproduce
1.
 ```
$ mkdir project
$ ln -s project linktoproject
$ cd linktoproject
$ echo hello > hi.txt
$ atom .
```

2. Click `hi.txt` on project sidebar. Make some edits without saving
3. `c-p` for find file and open `hi.txt`. Make changes and save
4. go back to first tab and save

**Expected behavior:**
I should have two views of the same file, with edits propagating to both. `c-p` should open `linktoproject/hi.txt`

**Actual behavior:**
Atom opens `linktoproject/hi.txt` on click but opens `project/hi.txt` from find file. Atom thinks these are two different files. After saving both files, there is no indication that one of the files now has unsaved information that will be forever lost if closed.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
Atom    : 1.23.3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.3
python 3.6.2
git 2.7.4

Ubuntu 16.04 4.4.0-119-generic

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Title: Atom can create files with reserved/invalid filenames in Windows 10
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

-->

### Description

Atom allows the user to create files with reserved filenames in Windows 10, which results in an unusable file that cannot be deleted, renamed, or moved. Reserved filenames in Windows 10 are as follows:

- CON
- PRN
- AUX
- NUL
- COM1, COM2, COM3, COM4, COM5, COM6, COM7, COM8, COM9, COM0
- LPT1, LPT2, LPT3, LPT4, LPT5, LPT6, LPT7, LPT8, LPT9, LPT0

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In Windows 10, open any directory in Atom
2. In the file tree pane, right-click and select "New File"
3. In the field that appears, enter "Aux.txt", or any of the other filenames listed above with any file extension, and press Enter
4. Observe that the newly created file cannot be opened, deleted, renamed, moved, or otherwise meaningfully interacted with

**Expected behavior:** Atom should throw an error when the user attempts to create a file with a reserved filename, and prohibit the creation of the file

**Actual behavior:** A file is created which cannot be deleted without first booting into a different operating system, such as Linux

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

1.25.0 x64 - Windows 10
1.26.0 x64 - Windows 10
Label: triaged

Title: Atom can create files with reserved/invalid filenames in Windows 10

### Description

Atom allows the user to create files with reserved filenames in Windows 10, which results in an unusable file that cannot be deleted, renamed, or moved. Reserved filenames in Windows 10 are as follows:

- CON
- PRN
- AUX
- NUL
- COM1, COM2, COM3, COM4, COM5, COM6, COM7, COM8, COM9, COM0
- LPT1, LPT2, LPT3, LPT4, LPT5, LPT6, LPT7, LPT8, LPT9, LPT0

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In Windows 10, open any directory in Atom
2. In the file tree pane, right-click and select "New File"
3. In the field that appears, enter "Aux.txt", or any of the other filenames listed above with any file extension, and press Enter
4. Observe that the newly created file cannot be opened, deleted, renamed, moved, or otherwise meaningfully interacted with

**Expected behavior:** Atom should throw an error when the user attempts to create a file with a reserved filename, and prohibit the creation of the file

**Actual behavior:** A file is created which cannot be deleted without first booting into a different operating system, such as Linux

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

1.25.0 x64 - Windows 10
1.26.0 x64 - Windows 10
Label: windows

Title: Writing to config in deactivate can wipe settings
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When a package writes to the configuration during it's `deactivate` step there is a chance it can cause Atom to wipe the user's settings when Atom is restarted (such as during updating packages).

![2018-03-31_00-35-59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/38161341-2b3940a6-3482-11e8-988d-5da8625af9da.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an empty folder and set the `ATOM_HOME` environment variable to this folder's path
2. Download [settings-wiper.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1865268/settings-wiper.zip), extract it, and run `apm link` from that folder in the environment from step 1
3. Launch Atom, you should get an information notification saying the current value is `0, 0, 0, 0, 0`, as well as Atom's regular first run screens
4. Set the Welcome screen to disabled in order to make it obvious when this bug hits you.
5. Launch "enough" Atom windows to trigger this bug on restarting, I found 10 windows to be a good number
6. Close one of the windows and launch a replacement
7. Note that the number increments
8. Open the developer tools and run `atom.restartApplication()` to restart Atom
9. Either the configuration will save and you will simply see an incremented number, or Atom's configuration will reset and you will see all `0`s again, and the Welcome screen will show in all windows
10. If the settings _didn't_ reset, simply run the command again until it does.

**Expected behavior:** Atom's configuration doesn't get wiped.

**Actual behavior:** Atom's configuration occasionally gets completely reset.

**Reproduces how often:** This is somewhat hard to tell, initially it was around 80%, but it can take many calls to `atom.restartApplication()` to reproduce this. Atom v1.26.0-beta0 reproduces this more often than Atom v1.25.0 does, but both versions _do_ reproduce this.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.26.0-beta0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.26.0-beta0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

This bug has not been seen to reproduce in Atom v1.24.1.

### Additional Information

This is a split out of the remaining part of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14909.

The common packages in all 24 package lists posted to that issue was the following:
```csv
"package name", "min", "max"

"busy-signal","1.4.3",""
"intentions","1.1.2","1.1.5"
"linter","2.2.0",""
"linter-ui-default","1.6.2","1.7.1"
```

`linter-ui-default` has the possibility to call `atom.config.set` during `deactivate`, leading to the guess in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14909#issuecomment-371251700 that lead to the test package in this issue.

The change to writing the configuration file in a single process was made in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16628.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Writing to config in deactivate can wipe settings
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When a package writes to the configuration during it's `deactivate` step there is a chance it can cause Atom to wipe the user's settings when Atom is restarted (such as during updating packages).

![2018-03-31_00-35-59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/38161341-2b3940a6-3482-11e8-988d-5da8625af9da.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an empty folder and set the `ATOM_HOME` environment variable to this folder's path
2. Download [settings-wiper.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1865268/settings-wiper.zip), extract it, and run `apm link` from that folder in the environment from step 1
3. Launch Atom, you should get an information notification saying the current value is `0, 0, 0, 0, 0`, as well as Atom's regular first run screens
4. Set the Welcome screen to disabled in order to make it obvious when this bug hits you.
5. Launch "enough" Atom windows to trigger this bug on restarting, I found 10 windows to be a good number
6. Close one of the windows and launch a replacement
7. Note that the number increments
8. Open the developer tools and run `atom.restartApplication()` to restart Atom
9. Either the configuration will save and you will simply see an incremented number, or Atom's configuration will reset and you will see all `0`s again, and the Welcome screen will show in all windows
10. If the settings _didn't_ reset, simply run the command again until it does.

**Expected behavior:** Atom's configuration doesn't get wiped.

**Actual behavior:** Atom's configuration occasionally gets completely reset.

**Reproduces how often:** This is somewhat hard to tell, initially it was around 80%, but it can take many calls to `atom.restartApplication()` to reproduce this. Atom v1.26.0-beta0 reproduces this more often than Atom v1.25.0 does, but both versions _do_ reproduce this.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.26.0-beta0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.26.0-beta0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

This bug has not been seen to reproduce in Atom v1.24.1.

### Additional Information

This is a split out of the remaining part of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14909.

The common packages in all 24 package lists posted to that issue was the following:
```csv
"package name", "min", "max"

"busy-signal","1.4.3",""
"intentions","1.1.2","1.1.5"
"linter","2.2.0",""
"linter-ui-default","1.6.2","1.7.1"
```

`linter-ui-default` has the possibility to call `atom.config.set` during `deactivate`, leading to the guess in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14909#issuecomment-371251700 that lead to the test package in this issue.

The change to writing the configuration file in a single process was made in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16628.
Label: data-loss

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an empty folder and set the `ATOM_HOME` environment variable to this folder's path
2. Download [settings-wiper.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1865268/settings-wiper.zip), extract it, and run `apm link` from that folder in the environment from step 1
3. Launch Atom, you should get an information notification saying the current value is `0, 0, 0, 0, 0`, as well as Atom's regular first run screens
4. Set the Welcome screen to disabled in order to make it obvious when this bug hits you.
5. Launch "enough" Atom windows to trigger this bug on restarting, I found 10 windows to be a good number
6. Close one of the windows and launch a replacement
7. Note that the number increments
8. Open the developer tools and run `atom.restartApplication()` to restart Atom
9. Either the configuration will save and you will simply see an incremented number, or Atom's configuration will reset and you will see all `0`s again, and the Welcome screen will show in all windows
10. If the settings _didn't_ reset, simply run the command again until it does.

**Expected behavior:** Atom's configuration doesn't get wiped.

**Actual behavior:** Atom's configuration occasionally gets completely reset.

**Reproduces how often:** This is somewhat hard to tell, initially it was around 80%, but it can take many calls to `atom.restartApplication()` to reproduce this. Atom v1.26.0-beta0 reproduces this more often than Atom v1.25.0 does, but both versions _do_ reproduce this.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.26.0-beta0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.26.0-beta0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

This bug has not been seen to reproduce in Atom v1.24.1.

### Additional Information

This is a split out of the remaining part of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14909.

The common packages in all 24 package lists posted to that issue was the following:
```csv
"package name", "min", "max"

"busy-signal","1.4.3",""
"intentions","1.1.2","1.1.5"
"linter","2.2.0",""
"linter-ui-default","1.6.2","1.7.1"
```

`linter-ui-default` has the possibility to call `atom.config.set` during `deactivate`, leading to the guess in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14909#issuecomment-371251700 that lead to the test package in this issue.

The change to writing the configuration file in a single process was made in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16628.
Label: v â¬†ï¸?

### Description
The official snap package listed on the snapstore always lags the release by up to a week or more:

This documentation seems to indicate you can setup an automatic deployment from the Git releases:

It appears from your issue tracking that you already have travis-ci working from this repo.

Title: awful anti-aliasing and hinting, and no sub-pixel rendering; on linux
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom does an inexcusably terrible job of anti-aliasing and hinting, and doesn't use sub-pixel rendering.

![atom-garbage-font-rendering](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/620722/37737758-22751a5c-2d2b-11e8-9ac5-b10b0dd0d99a.png)

The issue is present at any font size, but a small font size, as the screenshot above, makes the problem obvious.

No other application on this system does this, including other Electrons applications, like Slack and Discord.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have an up to date install of Arch Linux.
2. Install Atom.
3. Open any file containing text.
4. Reduce the font size to make the effect more noticable.

**Expected behavior:** Decent anti-aliasing, hinting, and sub-pixel rendering.

**Actual behavior:** Garbage.

**Reproduces how often:** Always.

### Versions

atom --version
```
Atom    : 1.24.0
Electron: 1.8.4
Chrome  : 59.0.3071.115
Node    : 8.2.1
```

apm --version
```
apm  1.19.0
npm  5.7.1
node 9.9.0 x64
atom 1.24.0
python 2.7.14
git  2.16.2
```

uname -a
```
Linux PowerMAP 4.15.4-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Feb 17 16:01:38 UTC 2018 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Additional Information

I don't know which additional Linux package version might be relevant. If you need more information, I'd be happy to provide it.

Title: Scrollbar disappearing/flickering when styled to increase width/height
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom

### Description

With Update to version 1.25.0 After start the file-scrollbar disappear or flickering or stay. Its little random. Same in Safe-mode.

I can click on fileA in tabs there is no scrollbar change to another file and go back to fileA and scrollbar appear and go next file and come back its again disapeared or flickering and disapeared.

The scrollbar in treeview working always fine.

_Edited by @ben3eee to include steps to reproduce:_

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open your personal Stylesheet
1. Add the following contents:
```less
::-webkit-scrollbar {
width: 25px !important;
height: 25px !important;
}
```
3. Reload Atom

**Expected:** Scrollbar to have more width and height

**Actual:** Scrollbar has more width and height but is flickering

### Versions

Atom    : 1.25.0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0
python
git 2.7.0.windows.1
visual studio
Label: regression

Title: Remove the bundled TypeScript transpiler
Body:
The bundled TypeScript transpiler is well over a major version old.

We can't sustainably upgrade it in-place; it's too risky to force upgrades on the entire package ecosystem like that. Instead, I'd prefer to encourage the use of custom transpilers that allow each package to keep up with dependencies at their own pace.

To move us toward that, I'd like to remove the TypeScript transpiler altogether. The last time that @thomasjo looked, there were about ten packages that would be impacted - we should be able to easily send PRs to help those packages transition to atom-ts-transpiler.

- [ ] Allow custom transpilers to add arbitrary extensions to `require.extensions`.
- [ ] Find community packages that are using the built-in TypeScript transpiler, and send them pull requests to use atom-ts-transpiler instead. (This should be a very small number of packages. If it is not, or if more packages have been using TypeScript recently, investigate a deprecation path instead).
- [ ] Remove the built-in TypeScript transpiler.
- [ ] Update any and all references to TypeScript in the documentation or the Flight Manual with pointers to using the custom transpiler pipeline instead.

Ref: #16944 which was my hacky way to get atom-ts-transpilers set up to work with `.tsx` files; especially see [the discussion in the comments](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16944#issuecomment-373007070):

> For the record, I completely agree with not upgrading bundled transpilers, but only if that means we are planning on removing all bundled transpilers. It's better to not ship anything, than to ship old, outdated bits (with known performance issues, and what not).

Ref: #16209 which is @thomasjo's effort toward an upgrade.
Label: proposal

Title: [minor ui bug] Project folder icon incorrect for git worktree
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * ~~Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/~~
    * ~~Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq~~
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * ~~Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages~~

### Description

Normal project folder icon is a plain folder, while git-ed project folder icon is a book.
However, a git-worktree project folder display as a plain folder, while it should be a book by its nature.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `git init && git commit --allow-empty -m Init`
2. `git worktree add --detach ../another master`
3. `atom` and add `../another` to the project folder

**Expected behavior:** Project folder `another` should looks like a normal git-ed project.

**Actual behavior:** Project folder `another` looks like a non-git-ed project.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.25.0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```

```
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0
python 3.6.4
git 2.16.2.windows.1
visual studio
```

```
Major  Minor  Build  Revision
-----  -----  -----  --------
10     0      16299  0
```

### Additional Information

This should be a minor and non-urgent bug which only involves UI consistency.
Label: triaged

Title: ssl cert error after upgrade to 1.25.0
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Upgraded from `1.24.1` to `1.25.0` and now I can't get past `self signed certificate in certificate chain` error when searching to install packages.

`strict-ssl=false` is already in my `.apmrc` file and works as expected in `1.24.1`, which is able to search for packages properly - however if I launch `1.25.0` (with no other config changes) then I see the certificate error.

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Be behind a proxy that injects self-signed SSL certificates
1. Install version `1.24.1` on windows
2. Set `strict-ssl=false` in `.apmrc` config file
3. See that packages installs work
4. Upgrade to `1.25.0`
4. See that packages installs **fail**

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Expect to have `strict-ssl` parameter continue to be usable in version `1.25.0`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

It appears that version `1.25.0` does not see this parameter

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Reproduces every time, I can launch `1.24.1` side-by-side with `1.25.0` and see the different behavior.

### Versions

#### Working version
```
> atom -v
Atom    : 1.24.1
Electron: 1.6.16
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

#### Failing version
```
> atom -v
Atom    : 1.25.0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```

```
> apm -v
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0
python
git 2.7.3.windows.1
visual studio
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Here is the output from `apm config list` (with `MY_USER` replacing my username) showing that `strict-ssl=false` is in my `.apmrc` file
```
>apm config list
; cli configs
globalconfig = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\.atom\\.apm\\.apmrc"
user-agent = "npm/3.10.10 node/v6.9.5 win32 x64"
userconfig = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\.atom\\.apmrc"

; environment configs
node-gyp = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.25.0\\resources\\app\\apm\\bin\\\\..\\node_modules\\node-gyp\\bin\\node-gyp.js"

; userconfig C:\Users\MY_USER\.atom\.apmrc
strict-ssl = false

; globalconfig C:\Users\MY_USER\.atom\.apm\.apmrc
cache = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\.atom\\.apm"
progress = false

; node bin location = C:\Users\MY_USER\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.25.0\resources\app\apm\bin\node.exe
; cwd = C:\Users\MY_USER\AppData\Local\atom\bin
; HOME = C:\Users\MY_USER
; "npm config ls -l" to show all defaults.
```
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Upgraded from `1.24.1` to `1.25.0` and now I can't get past `self signed certificate in certificate chain` error when searching to install packages.

`strict-ssl=false` is already in my `.apmrc` file and works as expected in `1.24.1`, which is able to search for packages properly - however if I launch `1.25.0` (with no other config changes) then I see the certificate error.

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Be behind a proxy that injects self-signed SSL certificates
1. Install version `1.24.1` on windows
2. Set `strict-ssl=false` in `.apmrc` config file
3. See that packages installs work
4. Upgrade to `1.25.0`
4. See that packages installs **fail**

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Expect to have `strict-ssl` parameter continue to be usable in version `1.25.0`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

It appears that version `1.25.0` does not see this parameter

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Reproduces every time, I can launch `1.24.1` side-by-side with `1.25.0` and see the different behavior.

### Versions

#### Working version
```
> atom -v
Atom    : 1.24.1
Electron: 1.6.16
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

#### Failing version
```
> atom -v
Atom    : 1.25.0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```

```
> apm -v
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0
python
git 2.7.3.windows.1
visual studio
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Here is the output from `apm config list` (with `MY_USER` replacing my username) showing that `strict-ssl=false` is in my `.apmrc` file
```
>apm config list
; cli configs
globalconfig = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\.atom\\.apm\\.apmrc"
user-agent = "npm/3.10.10 node/v6.9.5 win32 x64"
userconfig = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\.atom\\.apmrc"

; environment configs
node-gyp = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.25.0\\resources\\app\\apm\\bin\\\\..\\node_modules\\node-gyp\\bin\\node-gyp.js"

; userconfig C:\Users\MY_USER\.atom\.apmrc
strict-ssl = false

; globalconfig C:\Users\MY_USER\.atom\.apm\.apmrc
cache = "C:\\Users\\MY_USER\\.atom\\.apm"
progress = false

; node bin location = C:\Users\MY_USER\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.25.0\resources\app\apm\bin\node.exe
; cwd = C:\Users\MY_USER\AppData\Local\atom\bin
; HOME = C:\Users\MY_USER
; "npm config ls -l" to show all defaults.
```
Label: v â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Workspace.scan doesn't include all leading context lines for matches at the beginning of a file
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom

### Description

This is pretty specific: when searching for files with find-and-replace, or any tool using Workspace.scan, the context lines that are supposed to appear before the first line don't appear correctly above the line nÂ°[options.leadingContextLineCount] (so, by default, above line nÂ°3).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open the settings panel for "find-and-replace", and set "Search Line Count Before" to 3 (its default value)

2. Copy-paste the following text into a file:

```
abc
def
ghi
ghi
```

3. Use "Find in project" with the string `ghi`

4. Increase the number of leading context rows as much as you can.

**Expected behavior:** The lines `abc` and `def` should be shown as context (and indeed, they are shown above the second result).

**Actual behavior:** Only `def` is shown. (also, the spacing gets weird, but that's an issue with find-and-replace, not Workspace.scan)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

![screenshot_20180314_223515](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8573618/37405576-5900a72e-27d8-11e8-9662-b7715b68e7da.png)

### Versions

Atom    : 1.23.3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: Arch Linux.
Atom installed from "aur/atom-editor-bin" package.

### Additional Information

I am 90% sure this is a problem with Workspace.scan and not find-and-replace, since I was able to reproduce the bug both on the default find-and-replace and a refactored version I'm working on.

If I were to venture a guess, I'd say the bug probably comes from some piece of code where `!myObject.someValue` is used to check the existence of someValue, which behaves incorrectly when someValue is 0.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Segmentation fault when I open the source file of the HTML standard
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I wanted to work on the HTML standard (https://github.com/whatwg/html) and checked out the source locally. Then I opened the `source` file that is in the root directory. At this point, the editor opened, locked up and eventually reported "Editor is not responding". When I forced a close, eventually a segmentation fault was reported in the terminal.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone the HTML standard source (https://github.com/whatwg/html)
2. Invoke `atom --safe source` from the directory you just cloned
3. Force close the editor when the popup is shown

**Expected behavior:** The editor is forcibly closed and I can keep on using Atom for the other files.

**Actual behavior:** A segmentation fault is reported and Atom fully crashes:

```
/usr/bin/atom: line 129: 19078 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) nohup "$ATOM_PATH" --executed-from="$(pwd)" --pid=$$ "$@" > "$ATOM_HOME/nohup.out" 2>&1
```

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.24.0
Electron: 1.6.16
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.24.0
python 2.7.12
git 2.16.2
```

### Additional Information

I am running Ubuntu 16.04, e.g. a Linux distribution. I am running `atom` from the command line.
Label: triaged

Title: Linux only: editor crashes with rm -r node_modules
Body:
I have the editor open, no tabs from node_modules showing.

If I sudo rm -r node_modules/

The editor crashes.   Also I have to do sudo, so not sure if atom has these files open when it shouldn't?  Windows and other systems didn't need sudo to remove node_modules.

I'm on Debian now.

Title: Atom and Apm commands not being initialized by script/build --install
Body:
**Description**
The build process on Linux for atom v1.26.0-dev is terminating prematurely due to a permissions error:
```
Error: EACCES: permission denied, mkdir '/usr/share/icons/hicolor/1024x1024'
```
This results in the commands apm and atom not being created.

**Steps to Reproduce**
Follow the following instructions for making a clean Linux build
We used a clean Linux Virtual Box (Ubuntu 16.04.3)
```
$wget -qO- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/v0.33.6/install.sh | bash
--reopen terminal
$nvm install v8.9.0
$npm install -g npm
$npm config set python /usr/bin/python2 â€“g
$sudo apt-get install build-essential git libsecret-1-dev fakeroot rpm libx11-dev libxkbfile-dev
$git clone https://github.com/odoyle71/atom.git
$cd atom
$script/bootstrap
$script/clean
$script/build --install ~
```

**Expected behavior:** 
The build completes with the following terminal messages:
```
Installing "atom-1.26.0-dev-75ba994-amd64" at "/home/atom/share/atom-dev"
Installing icons at "/usr/share/icons/hicolor"
Updating icon cache for "/usr/share/icons/hicolor"
gtk-update-icon-cache: Cache file created successfully.
Writing desktop entry file at "/home/atom/share/applications/atom-dev.desktop"
Copying atom.sh to "/home/atom/bin/atom-dev"
Symlinking apm to "/home/atom/bin/apm-dev"
Changing permissions to 755 for "/home/atom/share/atom-dev"
```

**Actual behavior:** 
The build terminates with the following terminal messages:
```
Installing "atom-1.26.0-dev-75ba994-amd64" at "/home/atom/share/atom-dev"
Installing icons at "/usr/share/icons/hicolor"
Error: EACCES: permission denied, mkdir '/usr/share/icons/hicolor/1024x1024'
     at Object.fs.mkdirSync (fs.js:885:18)
     at mkdirsSync (/home/atom/atom/script/node_modules/fs-extra/lib/mkdirs/mkdirs-sync.js:29:9)
     at Object.mkdirsSync (/home/atom/atom/script/node_modules/fs-extra/lib/mkdirs/mkdirs-sync.js:35:16)
     at Object.copySync (/home/atom/atom/script/node_modules/fs-extra/lib/copy-sync/copy-sync.js:31:36)
     at fs.readdirSync.forEach.imageName (/home/atom/atom/script/lib/install-application.js:103:14)
     at Array.forEach (<anonymous>:null:null)
     at module.exports (/home/atom/atom/script/lib/install-application.js:99:36)
     at binariesPromise.then.then.then.then.packagedAppPath (/home/atom/atom/script/build:132:7)
     at <anonymous>:null:null
```

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time

**Versions**
```
atom@atom-VirtualBox:~$ atom-dev -v
Atom    : 1.26.0-dev-75ba994
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
atom@atom-VirtualBox:~$ apm-dev -v
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.26.0-dev-75ba994
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

**Additional Information**
This issue has to do with the fact that the installer is trying to copy icons into the `/usr/share/icons/hicolor` directory. The installer runs with user privilleges, but modifications to this directory requires root privilleges. 

This issue is a result of code added to install-application.js in PR [15498](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/15498)

The error has to do with the following code in `atom/script/lib/install-application.js`:
```
const baseIconThemeDirPath = findBaseIconThemeDirPath()
const fullIconName = atomExecutableName + '.png'
let existingIconsFound = false
fs.readdirSync(baseIconThemeDirPath).forEach(size => {
     const iconPath = path.join(baseIconThemeDirPath, size, 'apps', fullIconName)
     if (fs.existsSync(iconPath)) {
          if (!existingIconsFound) {
               console.log(`Removing existing icons from "${baseIconThemeDirPath}"`)
          }
          existingIconsFound = true
          fs.removeSync(iconPath)
     }
})
```
Since `baseIconThemeDirPath` is set by the following
```
function findBaseIconThemeDirPath () {
     const defaultBaseIconThemeDir = '/usr/share/icons/hicolor'
     const dataDirsString = process.env.XDG_DATA_DIRS
     if (dataDirsString) {
          const dataDirs = dataDirsString.split(path.delimiter)
          if (dataDirs.includes('/usr/share/') || dataDirs.includes('/usr/share')) {
               return defaultBaseIconThemeDir
          } else {
               return path.join(dataDirs[0], 'icons', 'hicolor')
          }
     } else {
          return defaultBaseIconThemeDir
     }
}
```
In particular, since our  `$XDG_DATA_DIRS` is:
```
 /usr/share/ubuntu:/usr/share/gnome:/usr/local/share/:/usr/share/:/var/lib/snapd/desktop
```
A  workaround suggested by Spotter (Slack name) which was to change `$XDR_DATA_DIRS` to `~/local/share`. However, this will mess up other applications using this environment variable.
Label: build-error

Body:
**Description**
The build process on Linux for atom v1.26.0-dev is terminating prematurely due to a permissions error:
```
Error: EACCES: permission denied, mkdir '/usr/share/icons/hicolor/1024x1024'
```
This results in the commands apm and atom not being created.

**Steps to Reproduce**
Follow the following instructions for making a clean Linux build

Installing "atom-1.26.0-dev-75ba994-amd64" at "/home/atom/share/atom-dev"

     at binariesPromise.then.then.then.then.packagedAppPath (/home/atom/atom/script/build:132:7)

**Versions**
```
atom@atom-VirtualBox:~$ atom-dev -v
Atom    : 1.26.0-dev-75ba994
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64

python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

const baseIconThemeDirPath = findBaseIconThemeDirPath()
const fullIconName = atomExecutableName + '.png'
let existingIconsFound = false

     const iconPath = path.join(baseIconThemeDirPath, size, 'apps', fullIconName)

          }

     if (dataDirsString) {
          const dataDirs = dataDirsString.split(path.delimiter)
          if (dataDirs.includes('/usr/share/') || dataDirs.includes('/usr/share')) {
               return defaultBaseIconThemeDir

```

**Additional Information**
This issue has to do with the fact that the installer is trying to copy icons into the `/usr/share/icons/hicolor` directory. The installer runs with user privilleges, but modifications to this directory requires root privilleges. 

This issue is a result of code added to install-application.js in PR [15498](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/15498)

The error has to do with the following code in `atom/script/lib/install-application.js`:
```
const baseIconThemeDirPath = findBaseIconThemeDirPath()
const fullIconName = atomExecutableName + '.png'
let existingIconsFound = false
fs.readdirSync(baseIconThemeDirPath).forEach(size => {
     const iconPath = path.join(baseIconThemeDirPath, size, 'apps', fullIconName)
     if (fs.existsSync(iconPath)) {
          if (!existingIconsFound) {
               console.log(`Removing existing icons from "${baseIconThemeDirPath}"`)
          }
          existingIconsFound = true
          fs.removeSync(iconPath)
     }
})
```
Since `baseIconThemeDirPath` is set by the following
```
function findBaseIconThemeDirPath () {
     const defaultBaseIconThemeDir = '/usr/share/icons/hicolor'
     const dataDirsString = process.env.XDG_DATA_DIRS
     if (dataDirsString) {
          const dataDirs = dataDirsString.split(path.delimiter)
          if (dataDirs.includes('/usr/share/') || dataDirs.includes('/usr/share')) {
               return defaultBaseIconThemeDir
          } else {
               return path.join(dataDirs[0], 'icons', 'hicolor')
          }
     } else {
          return defaultBaseIconThemeDir
     }
}
```
In particular, since our  `$XDG_DATA_DIRS` is:
```
 /usr/share/ubuntu:/usr/share/gnome:/usr/local/share/:/usr/share/:/var/lib/snapd/desktop
```
A  workaround suggested by Spotter (Slack name) which was to change `$XDR_DATA_DIRS` to `~/local/share`. However, this will mess up other applications using this environment variable.
Label: v â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Markdown breaks syntax highlighting and code folding
Body:
### Description

Code folding does not work for Markdown code blocks [as previously reported](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8879) which means Atom is not a good choice for [coding in literate programming style](https://github.com/vijithassar/lit). Hoping this can be fixed now that [v1.25.0](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.25.0-beta0) introduces [a new parser](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16299).

### Steps to Reproduce

Code in Markdown code blocks cannot be syntax highlighted or folded reliably. Markdown code blocks which do not completely contain a function with all brackets balanced break syntax highlighting and code folding.

**Expected behavior:** accurate syntax highlighting with functions that fold according to actual code structure

**Actual behavior:** syntax highlighting breaks and code folding is disabled

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Mac OS 10.13, all versions of Atom
Label: d â¬†ï¸?
