Title: Cannot open existing or new files
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

As of yesterday (2018-01-29), Atom fails to open new files or create files in a new tab when started normally. I can open Settings and other panels such as Timecop etc.. I have not made any updates to Atom recently; I did run my daily `dnf update` but don't recall any packages of note that came through. I don't remember if this issue began before or after that update. 

Pressing Ctrl+n or double-clicking in an open spot on the tab bar does not result in a new, unsaved document opening in a new tab. Ctrl+o brings up the window to browse for a file to open, but double-clicking or selecting "Open" fails to open the highlighted file (tried with GFM as well as plain text files).

No errors are displayed, Atom just fails to open the new tab/file. Files which are already open when I launch the program can be edited normally, and there are no issues with saving. At no point is Atom unresponsive.

If I launch Atom with the --clear-window-state option, then I am able to open existing and new files in the editor as expected, but once I close that session and reopen Atom normally, I am no longer to open files unless I launch it **again** with --clear-window-state, and so on.

I have attempted reinstalling Atom from the latest .rpm downloaded from atom.io, completely removing and then installing it once more, adding the Fedora repository and installing Atom from there, and even installing the most recent beta, all of which exhibit the same behavior. Even on first launch, with the welcome screen etc. visible, I cannot open a new file.

I have also removed/renamed the .atom settings folder and disabled all added extensions, as well as run the program in safe mode, and the issue still persists.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Attempt to open an existing file with Ctrl+o or through the File menu, **or** attempt to open a new, blank file with Ctrl+n or through the file menu

**Expected behavior:** Atom should open the selected file in a new tab or a blank file in a new tab.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time I open Atom (when not using the --clear-window-state option) since 2018-01-29.

### Versions
**Atom 1.23**
`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.23.3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

`apm --version`
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.3
python 2.7.14
git 2.14.3

**Atom 1.24 beta**
`atom-beta --version`
Atom    : 1.24.0-beta3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

`apm-beta --version`
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.24.0-beta3
python 2.7.14
git 2.14.3


Computer is a Lenovo Thinkpad X230 running Fedora 27 and the i3 window manager.
`uname -a`

`Linux Unit-03 4.14.14-300.fc27.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Jan 19 13:19:54 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`

### Additional Information

None presently.
Label: linux

Title: Atom crashes when installing module via NPM
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On Linux Mint 18.3, Atom crashes when installing/uninstalling a module via NPM while sitting on the app's root directory.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Opened Bash terminal at app root directory
2. Typed `atom .` to open Atom
3. Typed `cd client && npm i -S react-slick` 
4. Atom will crash while the module is being downloaded/installed 

**Expected behavior:** Not to crash.

**Actual behavior:** It will either succeed or crash.

**Reproduces how often:** Crashes about 50% of the time.

### Versions

Linux Mint 18.3 4.13.0-26-generic x86_64

- **Atom**: 1.23.3
- **apm**: 1.18.12
- **Electron**: 1.6.15
- **Chrome**: 56.0.2924.87
- **git**: 2.7.4
- **Node**: 8.9.3
- **npm**: 5.6.0
- **python**: 2.7.12

### Additional Information

Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GGF_xElWxbw

Checked and made sure node_modules wasn't being tracked:
![gitcached](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22607722/35186997-18088104-fdd2-11e7-8604-8a0d223dbfb1.png)

Extra steps:

- Renamed ~./atom to ~./atom_backup (still crashes)
- Started app with atom --safe (still crashes)
- Cleared atom window state (still crashes)

Happens randomly, as you can see here (I installed, uninstalled, reinstalled, then it crashed)
![crashpersist](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22607722/35186990-0f416aea-fdd2-11e7-8735-c42b94d12a4e.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

Title: Bad rendering after ~1 million lines
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In Atom 1.23.3 the rendering stops after around ~800k lines and nothing is displayed. On a recent master Atom can render ~1 million lines and then the rendering looks really bad.

@ungb This might be due to the electron upgrade. We should add large files to the testing docs.

![bad renderer](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/35113772-f2ffceda-fc82-11e7-81b6-6419c42ef3b4.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open this file in Atom https://gist.github.com/Ben3eeE/22ad32cbd9106bad16648d1c23f85709
2. Scroll to the bottom

**Expected behavior:** All lines to render correctly

Title: Bad rendering after ~1 million lines
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In Atom 1.23.3 the rendering stops after around ~800k lines and nothing is displayed. On a recent master Atom can render ~1 million lines and then the rendering looks really bad.

@ungb This might be due to the electron upgrade. We should add large files to the testing docs.

![bad renderer](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/35113772-f2ffceda-fc82-11e7-81b6-6419c42ef3b4.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open this file in Atom https://gist.github.com/Ben3eeE/22ad32cbd9106bad16648d1c23f85709
2. Scroll to the bottom

**Expected behavior:** All lines to render correctly

**Actual behavior:** Bad rendering

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

**Atom**: 1.25.0-dev-3d8902d x64
**Electron**: 1.7.10
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 7 Professional

### Additional Information

/cc: @nathansobo @as-cii

Title: [Regression] Pasting code with docblock comments does not auto indent second and subsequent lines
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When copying code that includes a docblock style comment, the indentation gets broken on pasting. This used to [not work so well](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11995), then got fixed, but now is even worse. 

The indentation for the second and subsequent lines of code stays the same and doesn't get auto-indented anymore:

![paste fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/490562/34916342-cedb0d42-f99b-11e7-893e-38660e0dd5fa.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Copy some code that is indented two spaces and which includes a docblock comment, e.g.:

```
  /**
   * Find first matching fee structure for a mode and member
   */
  Activity.prototype.findFeeForMember = function(mode, member) {

    //No member?
    if (!member) {
      return null;
    }
```
2. Paste this code at various indentations
3. Observe that it only pastes correctly when you past it back on the same indendation

**Expected behavior:** Correct indentation

**Actual behavior:** Incorrect indentation

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.25.0-dev-390ab7449
Electron: 1.7.10
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0-dev-390ab7449
python 2.7.10
git 2.14.1

OS X 10.11.5

### Additional information
These issues around docblock comments have been plaguing Atom since I started using it. It would be nice if they could be addressed in one of the next releases.

See also  and https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5362
Label: regression

Title: Support protocol handlers on Linux
Body: Electron is getting protocol handlers on Linux via xdg-open in https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/10670. We should support Linux (by changing code in atom/atom and atom/settings-view) once we're using a version of Electron that supports this.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Atom 1.23.2 doesn't copy the dot-atom directory to a new .atom directory
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom 1.23.2 doesn't copy the [dot-atom](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/dot-atom) directory to a new .atom directory on Ubuntu 16.04 (Atom installed via deb package).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Move aside your `.atom` directory with Atom closed.
2. Open Atom.
3. Look at the new `.atom` directory.

**Expected behavior:** It should contain the template files from [dot-atom](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/dot-atom).

**Actual behavior:** It doesn't. The config files start out empty.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Ubuntu 16.04.3 x64

Atom    : 1.23.2
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.2
python 2.7.12
git 2.15.1
```

### Additional Information
Atom was installed from `atom-amd64.deb`.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Atom RPM packages should be GPG signed for use in package repositories
Body: We currently do not GPG sign our RPM installer packages for Atom.  This can cause warnings on RPM-based distributions since we ask the user to configure the official Atom RPM repository to not use GPG signature checks.  It should be fairly straightforward to add GPG signing to our Linux build process to enable this.
Label: installer

Title: Atom RPM packages should be GPG signed for use in package repositories
Body: We currently do not GPG sign our RPM installer packages for Atom.  This can cause warnings on RPM-based distributions since we ask the user to configure the official Atom RPM repository to not use GPG signature checks.  It should be fairly straightforward to add GPG signing to our Linux build process to enable this.
Label: linux

Title: Feature requests: add primitives for multi-window-aware packages
Body:
I'm trying to write a package that needs to:

1. Be able to manipulate config and settings on a per-window basis
2. Be able to constrain which packages are loaded on a per-window basis
3. Be able to intercept and rewire config changes done by packages
4. Be able to intercept and realign packages with their proper serialization

And for that:

- I need a way to identify a window.
- I need a way to know when a single window is created/closed.
- I need a way to know when a single window receives focus.
- I need a way to restrict the packages loaded for a window.
    - This could be either whitelist (easier) or blacklist (not hard to compute from [this](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.23.1/PackageManager#instance-getAvailablePackagePaths))
- I need a way to read and alter config settings (across packages) per-window.
- I need a way to control the serialized state used when creating a window.
    - I do *not* need a way to inspect it or otherwise modify its integrity.
    - I do *not* need to handle state separately from its package (and I wouldn't want to).

What I'm wanting to do is more or less an expanded, fuller version of [this](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5168), but I'm wanting to do it in userland where I have better flexibility.

Also, if any of these exist already, I'd like to know, so I can go ahead and strike them out.

------

Here's an incomplete high-level API proposal for all but serialized state control and "on window startup":

- `atom.window` - A self-reference to this window instance (not the DOM global).
- `atom.onDidOpenWindow(callback: (window) => any)` - Called with a new `AtomWindow` instance to control the other window.
- `AtomWindow::onDidClose(callback: () => any)` - Called when the window is closed.
- `AtomWindow::onDidReceiveFocus(callback: () => any)` - Called when the window receives focus.
- `AtomWindow::send(scope, message, ...args)` - Send an IPC message with a given scope.
- `AtomWindow::onDidReceiveMessage(scope, message, callback: (...args) => any)` - Receive a message with a given scope.
- `PackageManager::enablePackageForWindow(name)` - Does what it says.
- `PackageManager::disablePackageForWindow(name)` - Does what it says.
- `PackageManager::isPackageDisabledForWindow(name)` - Checks what it says.
- `Config::setForWindow(key, value)` - Set config for window
- `Config::getForWindow(key, value)` - Get config for window
- `Config::unsetForWindow(key, value)` - Unset config for window
- `Config::observeAll(options, callback: (value) => any)` - Observe all key changes.
    - I can detect nesting easily enough.

I can use IPC to control config settings and package disabling across windows using the above methods.

Title: Update flow on mac poor ux
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Updating atom (installed with brew) has been broken on mac for a while now (currently on high sierra, but same for sierra). 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click the blue squirrel
2. Click restart and install
3. Atom closes but doesn't quit
4. Wait for a while
5. What's going on? Is it stuck?
5. Force quit
6. Start atom
7. Update failed
8. Repeat

**Expected behavior:**
As a user I expect the update process to work as follows:

1. Click the blue squirrel
2. Click restart and install
3. Atom immediately restarts and shows me a progress bar of the new version downloading and then installing
4. Done

**Actual behavior:**

See step to reproduce.

**Reproduces how often:**

All the time so far.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.11
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.1
python 2.7.10
git 2.15.1
macos high sierra 10.13.1
```

### Additional Information

I understand that I shouldn't force quit atom while updating, but as a user it's frustrating to not know if it's hanging or actually doing something. Plus, besides that, I've also gotten [this error](https://discuss.atom.io/t/i-am-unable-to-update-to-the-latest-version-of-atom-on-macos-how-do-i-fix-this/40054) and encountered other snags while updating.

It seems like the update flow needs some attention. The current flow feels broken, even though it might be working well, as a user you just don't know because there's no indication of what's happening.
Label: auto-updater

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When using Atom to open a WSL file, Atom for Windows opens the file as blank and the System 32 folder is added as a Project Folder instead of the current WSL folder.

I apologize if I am using the wrong terminology for this. Please ask for any clarifications and I'll be happy to provide them. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Bash on Ubuntu on Windows (or any other bash shell)
2. Type atom [your file]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Atom opens file with its contents and adds the current WSL folder as the project folder.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Atom opens the file but it is blank and the System 32 folder is added as the project folder.

The file path in Atom says "C:\WINDOWS\system32\[name of file] which is wrong.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Constant.

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

This occurred on latest stable Atom for Windows version and latest beta (1.23.0-beta1 x64)

OS is Windows 10 Pro with latest updates.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

This seems to have started after updating Ubuntu last night.
Label: windows

Title: German keyboard layouts break some vim-mode-plus-commands
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have a bug using the vim-mode-plus package with the normal German Keyboard layout OR the Neo2-Keyboard-Layout which is a special german layout awesomizing programming, as all important coding symbols are on one layer.
https://wiki.neo-layout.org/wiki/Tastaturbelegung#Ebene3

However it causes some bugs when using atom.

```
if(cookie == 1){
		do_awesome_stuff(5);
}

```
Let's say I wanted to edit the condition of the if, I would type "change inner
(" â‡’ ci(

When doing so it causes Atom to delete everything left from the cursor. For 
example if the cursor was on the second 'o', the vim-mode-edit would create:

```
okie == 1){
		do_awesome_stuff(5);
}
```

Or, when using "ci)":
```
if(co
		do_awesome_stuff(5);
}
```

I have a hard time understanding this as â€“ from my understanding â€“ the desktop
environment pushes the layouted keycodes to the userspace-programs, doesn't it? However one could presume that it's the position of the brackets on the german layout which cause this error and explains why the other commands work. As if Atom would grep the keycodes directly and compare them with the english layout.

As far as I can tell at this point the change-inner-commands are  the only vi-commands Atom doesn't execute correctly.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [Use the German (Neo2) Layout]
2. [Try to use the vi-command to change the content between two brackets]

**Expected behavior:** [Delete the content between the brackets and let me type new content]

**Actual behavior:** [Delete everything left from the cursor when using ci(, everything right from the cursor when using ci), delete the whole line when using ci[, same with ci{ and let me type new content]

**Reproduces how often:** [100% of the time]

### Versions

Atom        : 1.22.0
Electron   : 1.6.15
Chrome    : 56.0.2924.87
Node        : 7.4.0

Debian 9 "Stretch", Kernel 4.9, Gnome-Desktop

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: triaged

Title: Atom not opening files
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [ ] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If I open Atom via the GUI I can't open any files or preferences .etc.
Although if I open a file via terminal, atom works as intended even in safe mode.

I have tried running the command `atom --clear-window-state`

**Expected behavior:** Open a file

**Actual behavior:** Atom stays in the same state that it opened in.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
Atom: 1.22.1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome: 56.0.2924.87
Node: 7.4.0
OSX: 10.13.1

Title: Code folding artifacts in some cases (repeated fold line)
Body: *Edit by @rsese to clean up issue body and add latest details* ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * [Reproduced after resetting to factory defaults but in safe mode since repro steps require a community package] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description There have been a number of reports of duplicated code fold lines since around Atom 1.21.2 but with some trouble coming up with specific steps to reproduce (e.g. no specific common community packages though a couple of folks mentioned it happened commonly for them in large files). In https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16078#issuecomment-421336384 we did get specific reproduction steps though. ### Steps to Reproduce via https://github.com/elpollodiablo84/language-matlab-plus/issues/1#issue-332767387 h/t @elpollodiablo84 (I couldn't reproduce with other packages installed so ended up temporarily resetting to [factory defaults](https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#reset-to-factory-defaults) first): 1. `apm install language-matlab-plus` 2. Save and open https://github.com/elpollodiablo84/language-matlab-plus/blob/ffba8d71775e392b68882876bd877fb8f78206f8/test/test2.m 3. `atom test2.m` 4. Fold the function `new_fun` 5. Fold the function `secondaryFunction`. 6. Unfold `secondaryFunction` **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] `secondaryFunction` function unfolds with no effect on the folded `new_fun` function. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] The first line of the folded `new_fun` will duplicate each time you fold/unfold `secondaryFunction`. ![fold-dupe](https://github-slack.s3.amazonaws.com/monosnap/test2.m__sandboxlanguage-matlab-plus_2018-09-17_15-44-23.png) GIF-age: ![fold-dupe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/734194/45649399-d2d48480-ba90-11e8-84e9-1ed0bd37796a.gif) **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100% ### Versions Atom 1.30.0 and 1.32.0-nightly11. macOS 10.12.6 ### Additional Information Additional comments from https://github.com/elpollodiablo84/language-matlab-plus/issues/1#issue-332767387 related to language-matlab-plus: > The issue disappears in the following cases: > > * Disabling the decoration of persistent variables, commenting the line in `../lib/main.js`: > `editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: 'text', class: 'variable-persistent'});` > * Changing the type of the decoration in the previous line (Ex: `highlight` or `line`). > * Disabling the function scope check , commenting `functionNames.includes(v[0])` out of its `if` block. --- *Edited by @rsese to consolidate description in the issue body* Atom Version 1.21.2 latest Mac Sierra 10.12.6, NVIDIA GeForce GT 750M 2048 MB, 2.5 GHz Intel Core i7, 16 GB 1600 MHz DDR3 Does not reproduce in safe mode (no linting) Atom Core (editor) intermittent behavior --- If I Show Invisibles I cannot reproduce. It seems to be a specific file. I cannot find any invisible item. --- if you fold all functions, if you make an error typing functions show up multiple times on the same line. i.e. someFunc(){ = someFunc(){ = someFunc() { = where = is the marker that the function is folded --- This time it occurred by simply flicking the scroll up and down quickly. Mac, magic mouse. --- I seems to be a redraw issue. If you scroll to where all of the folded functions are out of view, when scrolling them back into view they return to normal. --- This is difficult to reproduce. I am linting and sometimes if I add a space after a }, wait for it to lint and error, then backspace and remove the space it will happen. It is very intermittent. Latest version of atom, editing react javascript jsx files, with linting.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Fold the function `secondaryFunction`. 6. Unfold `secondaryFunction` **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] `secondaryFunction` function unfolds with no effect on the folded `new_fun` function. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] The first line of the folded `new_fun` will duplicate each time you fold/unfold `secondaryFunction`. ![fold-dupe](https://github-slack.s3.amazonaws.com/monosnap/test2.m__sandboxlanguage-matlab-plus_2018-09-17_15-44-23.png) GIF-age: ![fold-dupe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/734194/45649399-d2d48480-ba90-11e8-84e9-1ed0bd37796a.gif) **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100% ### Versions Atom 1.30.0 and 1.32.0-nightly11. macOS 10.12.6 ### Additional Information Additional comments from https://github.com/elpollodiablo84/language-matlab-plus/issues/1#issue-332767387 related to language-matlab-plus: > The issue disappears in the following cases: > > * Disabling the decoration of persistent variables, commenting the line in `../lib/main.js`: > `editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: 'text', class: 'variable-persistent'});` > * Changing the type of the decoration in the previous line (Ex: `highlight` or `line`). > * Disabling the function scope check , commenting `functionNames.includes(v[0])` out of its `if` block. --- *Edited by @rsese to consolidate description in the issue body* Atom Version 1.21.2 latest Mac Sierra 10.12.6, NVIDIA GeForce GT 750M 2048 MB, 2.5 GHz Intel Core i7, 16 GB 1600 MHz DDR3 Does not reproduce in safe mode (no linting) Atom Core (editor) intermittent behavior --- If I Show Invisibles I cannot reproduce. It seems to be a specific file. I cannot find any invisible item. --- if you fold all functions, if you make an error typing functions show up multiple times on the same line. i.e. someFunc(){ = someFunc(){ = someFunc() { = where = is the marker that the function is folded --- This time it occurred by simply flicking the scroll up and down quickly. Mac, magic mouse. --- I seems to be a redraw issue. If you scroll to where all of the folded functions are out of view, when scrolling them back into view they return to normal. --- This is difficult to reproduce. I am linting and sometimes if I add a space after a }, wait for it to lint and error, then backspace and remove the space it will happen. It is very intermittent. Latest version of atom, editing react javascript jsx files, with linting.
Label: editor-rendering

Title: fails to build on Linux because 'python' references 'python3', and `python-interceptor.sh` hardwires calls to `python`
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

This is still a problem on ubuntu (but probably generically):

I solved, and the issue seems to be centered in `apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager` in the shell script `python-interceptor.sh`  lines 37 & 40  (explicit call of `python`).

The problem is `python` is the default python, which increasingly will be python3  (currently python3.6, python3.6.3), and _not_ python2.

To quickly hack / see that this is the issue, changing those as shown here:
```
$ pwd; grep -n -i python python-interceptor.sh 
/home/yarko/workspace/atom/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin
7:    export PYTHONPATH="${PYTHONPATH:-}:${SCRIPT_DIR}/../src/generator/"
37:    exec python2 "${ARGS[@]}"
40:    exec python2 "$@"
```
results in a successful build.

It would seem that one possible solution is to (somewhere) set an environment variable, e.g.
```
$ export PYTHON=python2
```
and fix `python-interceptor.sh` lines (above) to call $PYTHON.

Alternatively, and simply, `python-interceptor.sh`  can set PYTHON (by default) to be `python2`, since that should be valid for any installation with a python version 2 installation.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. This was a build on Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, with locally built pythons - 3.6 and 3.7a in /usr/local/bin
2. attempt build per instructions, including `npm config set python /usr/local/bin/python2 -g`

**Expected behavior:**
Successful build;

**Actual behavior:**
Error in python-intercept.sh (complaint about python version 3.6.3).

**Reproduces how often:**
Always.

### Versions
master / HEAD
Label: build-error

Title: fails to build on Linux because 'python' references 'python3', and `python-interceptor.sh` hardwires calls to `python`
Body:

### Description

This is still a problem on ubuntu (but probably generically):

I solved, and the issue seems to be centered in `apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager` in the shell script `python-interceptor.sh`  lines 37 & 40  (explicit call of `python`).

The problem is `python` is the default python, which increasingly will be python3  (currently python3.6, python3.6.3), and _not_ python2.

To quickly hack / see that this is the issue, changing those as shown here:
```
$ pwd; grep -n -i python python-interceptor.sh 
/home/yarko/workspace/atom/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin
7:    export PYTHONPATH="${PYTHONPATH:-}:${SCRIPT_DIR}/../src/generator/"
37:    exec python2 "${ARGS[@]}"
40:    exec python2 "$@"
```
results in a successful build.

It would seem that one possible solution is to (somewhere) set an environment variable, e.g.
```
$ export PYTHON=python2
```
and fix `python-interceptor.sh` lines (above) to call $PYTHON.

Alternatively, and simply, `python-interceptor.sh`  can set PYTHON (by default) to be `python2`, since that should be valid for any installation with a python version 2 installation.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. This was a build on Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, with locally built pythons - 3.6 and 3.7a in /usr/local/bin
2. attempt build per instructions, including `npm config set python /usr/local/bin/python2 -g`

**Expected behavior:**
Successful build;

**Actual behavior:**
Error in python-intercept.sh (complaint about python version 3.6.3).

**Reproduces how often:**
Always.

### Versions
master / HEAD
Label: linux

Title: spellchecker thread crashes atom (losing unsaved input) when using multiple locales
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add more details based on ongoing comments* Based on multiple comments (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342109220, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-368338661), the people experiencing the crash are also using multiple locales in `Settings > Packages > Spell Check > Locales` e.g. `en-US, de-DE`. There are some macOS settings talked about around https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442620099 as well. Suggested steps to reproduce where others can reproduce consistently but I was unable to on macOS 10.12.6 (tried most recently with 1.35.0-nightly7 but also tried 1.33.0): https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442997225, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-445068189 Crash logs at: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-339603930, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-351392619, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18322#issuecomment-440809127 --- ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description The spellchecker thread crashes atom on mac os fairly regularly. I reproduced this with current stable (1.21.1) and beta (1.22.0-beta1) in safe mode. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open markdown file. 2. Start typing. 3. After a while atom crashes. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Not crashing. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Atom crashes loosing unsaved changes:

Label: crash

Title: spellchecker thread crashes atom (losing unsaved input) when using multiple locales
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add more details based on ongoing comments* Based on multiple comments (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342109220, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-368338661), the people experiencing the crash are also using multiple locales in `Settings > Packages > Spell Check > Locales` e.g. `en-US, de-DE`. There are some macOS settings talked about around https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442620099 as well. Suggested steps to reproduce where others can reproduce consistently but I was unable to on macOS 10.12.6 (tried most recently with 1.35.0-nightly7 but also tried 1.33.0): https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442997225, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-445068189 Crash logs at: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-339603930, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-351392619, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18322#issuecomment-440809127 --- ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description The spellchecker thread crashes atom on mac os fairly regularly. I reproduced this with current stable (1.21.1) and beta (1.22.0-beta1) in safe mode. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open markdown file. 2. Start typing. 3. After a while atom crashes. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Not crashing. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Atom crashes loosing unsaved changes:

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] Every 5 to 10 minutes when editing markdown files. ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.21.1 Electron: 1.6.15 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 apm 1.18.5 npm 3.10.10 node 6.9.5 x64 python 2.7.10 git 2.14.2 ``` ### Additional Information Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: spellchecker thread crashes atom (losing unsaved input) when using multiple locales
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add more details based on ongoing comments* Based on multiple comments (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342109220, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-368338661), the people experiencing the crash are also using multiple locales in `Settings > Packages > Spell Check > Locales` e.g. `en-US, de-DE`. There are some macOS settings talked about around https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442620099 as well. Suggested steps to reproduce where others can reproduce consistently but I was unable to on macOS 10.12.6 (tried most recently with 1.35.0-nightly7 but also tried 1.33.0): https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442997225, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-445068189 Crash logs at: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-339603930, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-351392619, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18322#issuecomment-440809127 --- ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description The spellchecker thread crashes atom on mac os fairly regularly. I reproduced this with current stable (1.21.1) and beta (1.22.0-beta1) in safe mode. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open markdown file. 2. Start typing. 3. After a while atom crashes. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Not crashing. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Atom crashes loosing unsaved changes:

Title: spellchecker thread crashes atom (losing unsaved input) when using multiple locales
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add more details based on ongoing comments* Based on multiple comments (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342109220, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-368338661), the people experiencing the crash are also using multiple locales in `Settings > Packages > Spell Check > Locales` e.g. `en-US, de-DE`. There are some macOS settings talked about around https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442620099 as well. Suggested steps to reproduce where others can reproduce consistently but I was unable to on macOS 10.12.6 (tried most recently with 1.35.0-nightly7 but also tried 1.33.0): https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-442997225, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-445068189 Crash logs at: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-339603930, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-342528451, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15912#issuecomment-351392619, https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18322#issuecomment-440809127 --- ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description The spellchecker thread crashes atom on mac os fairly regularly. I reproduced this with current stable (1.21.1) and beta (1.22.0-beta1) in safe mode. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open markdown file. 2. Start typing. 3. After a while atom crashes. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Not crashing. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Atom crashes loosing unsaved changes:
Crash Report ``` Process: Atom Helper [68095] Path: /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom Helper Identifier: com.github.atom.helper Version: 1.21.1 (1.21.1) Title: missing "Show Tab Bar" on MacOS 10.13
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

There is no "Show Tab Bar" option under `macOS > Menu > View` with` Atom > Settings > Core > Title Bar`  set to `native`;

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Upgrade to Atom 1.21.0

2. Open `Menu > View`

![2017-10-06 12 42 42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17921180/31263350-4b32a2fc-aa27-11e7-8d5a-2cf6e712f07f.png)

![2017-10-06 12 47 23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17921180/31263412-9d079b6e-aa27-11e7-9fa3-cc63dbdf16fb.png)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] show "Show Tab Bar" button under `View`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] no "Show Tab Bar" button

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100%

### Versions

MacOS: 10.13
Atom    : 1.21.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
Label: mac

Title: Unknown Unicode characters written back as different hex than they are read in as
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Unknown Unicode characters written back as different hex than they are read in as.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a UTF-8 file with unicode U+0091 in it.
2. Open file in Atom to have it displayed as ï¿½
3. Make change somewhere in file other than the hex 91 character and save file
4. Open in notepad++ to see the character is now different as the hex in the file for U+0091 has been rewritten as ï¿½ (0xEFBFBD) from the 0x91 it was previously.

**Expected behavior:** When you open a file with Unicode characters, U+0091 in particular, it renders as the ï¿½ character. If you change ANYTHING but that character, and save the file, unaltered character values should not change. When opening in another editor, that supports said Unicode character, it should render it fine. That character value should not be changed on save when the character was never altered during the edit.

**Actual behavior:** When you open a file with Unicode characters U+0091 in particular, it renders as the ï¿½ character. If you change ANYTHING but that character, and save the file, the hex value for what should be U+0091 is changed to 0xEFBFBD.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom     : 1.20.0
Electron : 1.6.9
Chrome : 56.0.2924.87
Node     : 7.4.0
OS         : Windows 7 Pro

### Additional Information

None
Label: triaged

Title: Atom scrolls even when not focused
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

*  Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
   * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
   * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
   * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
   * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
   * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The text-editor window does not seem to lose focus on alt-tabbing in Fedora 26, Gnome 3.24. This seems to be a regression introduced in Atom 1.19.0 (reproducible in 1.19.4). This was once fixed in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12591 but the issue reappeared with the newest Atom version.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a document open in Atom, notice the position of the scroll bar
2. Alt+Tab to a window over Atom
3. Scroll down a lot
4. Alt+Tab back to Atom
5. Scroll down

**Expected behavior:**
The editor window scrolls down a bit

**Actual behavior:**
The editor windows scrolls by the sum of the scroll amounts in step 3. + 5.

**Reproduces how often:**
100%

### Versions
OS: Fedora 26

`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.19.4
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

`gnome-shell --version`
GNOME Shell 3.24.3
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: cli: `atom` command not found, occasionally
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

**I did not put an X, as I was unable to reproduce the problem in Safe Mode. How would I do that for this problem? I did check all of the other FAQs, and issues.**

### Description

Occasionally, I get an `atom: command not found` in Bash when I open a new tab or window in iTerm. This only happens for `atom`, as far as I can tell, and for no other programs. Running

       rm /usr/local/bin/atom
       ln -s /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/atom.sh /usr/local/bin/atom

Always fixes the issue. I am unable to figure out when this happens, or why, as my path or environment does not change in between sessions, at all. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open your terminal.
2. Type `atom`.
3. Sometimes - but not at all times - it may fail appropriately.

**Expected behavior:** `atom` should always be found in my PATH.

**Actual behavior:** It isn't.

**Reproduces how often:** 5%~

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: OS X 10.12 Sierra

### Additional Information

I'm not sure how to diagnose this, at all. Any suggestions for more information would be great. Here are [my dotfiles](https://github.com/RichardLitt/dotfiles).
Label: installer

Title: Dark scrollbars over dark syntax themes in macOS (only in editor)
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When using a dark syntax theme, the scrollbars in macOS are too dark to be seen correctly. This only happens in the editor (1). For the tree view (2), for example, the color of the scrollbars is as expected (light themed).

![complete](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9105693/29528771-797e14b4-869d-11e7-9120-54fdc09cebe4.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Select **When scrolling** setting in *macOS Preferences > General > Show scroll bars*.
2. Select a **dark syntax theme** in Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Editor uses light scrollbar on syntax themes with dark backgrounds.

**Actual behavior:** Editor uses dark scrollbar on syntax themes with dark backgrounds, rendering them almost invisible.

**Reproduces how often:** I've test it with all default UI and syntax themes combinations and problem persists.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.6
Label: mac

### Description

When using a dark syntax theme, the scrollbars in macOS are too dark to be seen correctly. This only happens in the editor (1). For the tree view (2), for example, the color of the scrollbars is as expected (light themed).

![complete](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9105693/29528771-797e14b4-869d-11e7-9120-54fdc09cebe4.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Select **When scrolling** setting in *macOS Preferences > General > Show scroll bars*.
2. Select a **dark syntax theme** in Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Editor uses light scrollbar on syntax themes with dark backgrounds.

**Actual behavior:** Editor uses dark scrollbar on syntax themes with dark backgrounds, rendering them almost invisible.

**Reproduces how often:** I've test it with all default UI and syntax themes combinations and problem persists.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.6
Label: triaged

### Description

Scrollbars are quite prominent (unstyled?) in Linux version. I don't recall it being this way in Atom 1.18. I'm now using 1.19.2

Title: Tree View crashes Atom when opening file on remounted disk volume
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages


### Description

The editor crashes when using "tree view" to open a file in a "project folder" that is located on a **re**mounted drive.

Please note that it is not necessary to actually access the volume (by e.g. opening a file). It seems that the volume disappearing/reappearing is enough for the editor to crash.

Also note that this behavior is **not** present when using File -> Open on the volume. Hence I believe it is related to the "tree view".

Crash logs from _Scenario 2_ has been attached.


[e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1138162/e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.txt)
[operation_log.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1138163/operation_log.txt)
[e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1138171/e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.zip)


### Steps to Reproduce

Note that this crash is reproducible in both _safe_ and _regular_ mode.

#### Scenario 1:

1. Make sure the volume is **not** already a "project folder" in Atom.
2. Mount the volume in DiskCryptor.
3. Start Atom.
3. Add a "project folder" pointing to the mounted volume.
4. Unmount the volume in DiskCryptor.
5. Remount the volume in DiskCryptor.
6. Open any file from the mounted volume.

#### Scenario 2:

1. Make sure the volume **is** already a "project folder" in Atom.
2. Mount the volume in DiskCryptor.
3. Start Atom.
4. Unmount the volume in DiskCryptor.
5. Remount the volume in DiskCryptor.
6. Open any file from the mounted volume.

#### Scenario 3:

This is my daily usage scenario.
The volume has been automatically unmounted the the end of the day.
At the beginning of each work day, I wake the computer from sleep mode.

1. Make sure the volume **is** already a "project folder" in Atom.
2. Mount the volume in DiskCryptor.
3. Start Atom.
4. Unmount the volume in DiskCryptor.
5. Put the computer to sleep (and go home for the day).
6. Wake up the computer.
7. Remount the volume in DiskCryptor.
8. Open any file from the mounted volume.

#### Expected behavior:

The editor should not crash when opening a file on a volume that was first mounted, then unmounted and finally remounted.

#### Actual behavior:

The editor crashes when trying to open any file on a **re**mounted volume.
This is regardless of whether any file (on any volume) was opened or not.

#### Reproduces how often:

Every time the scenario is repeated.


### Versions

`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

This is the current version I'm using, but this problem has been present much, much longer than this. Perhaps for years? I'm not certain.

`apm --version`
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 3.6.1
git 2.10.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015

Windows 10 Enterprise


### Additional Information

This happens on Windows 10 using [DiskCryptor](https://diskcryptor.net/wiki/Main_Page) to simulate an unplugged volume. Presumably, it is related to a volume being remounted, but it **could** also be related to network shares, as described in [ticket 14760](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14760).

**Prerequisite**
Use e.g. DiskCryptor to create a new volume.
Place a text file in that volume (in order to have content that can be opened by Atom).

Title: Docs do not mention getAllowedLocations() for Pane Items
Body:
So ``getAllowedLocations`` is mentioned in the [Atom flight manual](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/package-active-editor-info/#constraining-our-items-locations), but it's not mentioned elsewhere in the docs. I thought I could implement just ``getDefaultLocation`` without having to also implement ``getAllowedLocations``, but I get the following in the developer tools:

`C:\Users\Owner\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.18.0\resources\app\node_modules\tabs\lib\layout.js:159 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'getAllowedLocations' of undefined`

It's also not clear to me if I can simply return ``'all'`` from ``getAllowedLocations``. The docs should explain both of these functions and specify that you have to provide both if you provide the other.
Label: d â¬‡ï¸?

Title: Atom does not detect the correct PATH.
Body:
### Description

Atom is not inheriting the correct `PATH` for my system.

Terminal:
```
$ echo $PATH
/Applications/Zed.app/bin:/Users/ryan.mcquen/.local/bin:/usr/local/php5/bin:/usr/local/php5-5.6.30-20170506-093822/bin:/usr/local/Homebrew/bin:/opt/X11/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/opt/X11/bin:/Library/TeX/texbin:/Applications/Zed.app/bin:/Users/ryan.mcquen/.local/bin:/Users/ryan.mcquen/bin:/usr/local/php5/bin:/usr/local/php5-5.6.30-20170506-093822/bin:/usr/local/Homebrew/bin
```
Atom:
```
process.env.PATH
"/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin"
```
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run Atom.
2. Check your `PATH` (`process.env.PATH` in the Dev Tools Console).
3. See the lack of your `PATH`.

**Expected behavior:** Atom would report the same `PATH` as `echo $PATH` in my terminal.

**Actual behavior:** Atom seems to be using the default system `PATH`.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.17.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```

Mac OS 10.11.6.

### Additional Information

I'm using `tmux`.
Label: help-wanted

Title: Docker/Kubernetes support
Body:
Often a developer could use the editor on the host and mounting source volumes inside a docker container to compile, debug and run code there.
Instead of mounting a portable atom volume inside the container to run the editor in docker could be possible to run plugins command (build, make etc..) inside a container (cause generally they suppose run tools locally)? 
I don't really know if could be introduced some global feature in Atom for this.
I thought this cause I'm supposing that there could be some sensible informations in the .atom directory that could not be the best practice to have that exposed in every container mounting a "atom volume".

Body:

### Description

Opening atom after updating to 1.18 results in a window without any panes or the dir tree. It is not a new window, it was opened with `atom .` with `pwd` set to a project dir.

### Steps to Reproduce

- update to 1.18.0
- `atom .` in project dir

**Expected behavior:**

**Actual behavior:**

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Invalid Point: (NaN, 0)
Body:

Title: Feature Request: Integrated Shell/Terminal Access
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Windows 10 now has a bash terminal running on an Ubuntu underpinning. I want to access this terminal using Atom. There are some packages which report to do this on Mac and/or Linux, but nothing that I've found for Windows. I think Atom should have shell functionality built in like Sublime Text or Microsoft Visual Studio Code. The later even allows you to choose which shell to use based on which shells are installed, including windows power shell, CMD, or bash.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom
2. Write Code
3. Go to commit
4. Nowhere to commit
5. Have to open separate terminal window
6. Be sad

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
1. Press some sort of key combo (whether ctrl+` or ctrl+Shift+P and type Terminal)
2. get access to terminal in window or pane
3. Terminal automatically changes directory to current directory of file that you're working on

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
1. Nothing (currently)
2. Have to open terminal app seperately an change directory manually

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
1.17

### Additional Information
Please consult Microsoft's Visual Studio Code editor for how to implement an integrated terminal well

Title: The editor is not responding.
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In many different cases the Atom editor will report "The editor is not responding" shortly after launch.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Upgrade Atom
2. Launch Atom

or

1. Update Windows
2. Launch Atom

or

1. Update packages
2. Restart Atom

**Expected behavior:**
Atom should open properly

**Actual behavior:**
Atom freezes during the load and then says "The editor is not responding."

**Reproduces how often:**
Probably 50-75% of Atom upgrades. 100% of major Windows upgrades (Creators Update was the last one that caused it). 10% of package upgrades.

### Versions
Atom 1.16.0
Windows 10 Pro x64 (Creator's Update)

### Additional Information

atom --clear-window-state resolves this 100% of the time for me when it occurs.
Label: stale

Title: Reloading when running atom --clear-window-state causes data loss
Body:
### Prerequisites

*  Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

[Description of the issue]

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project with `atom --safe --clear-window-state`
2. Make some changes to a file but don't save
3. Open command palette and run `reload`

**Expected behavior:** 
Atom should reload like regular

**Actual behavior:**
Atom shows a empty window and when you reopen the project your unsaved changes are lost
**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.0-dev-03be10414
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0


### Additional Information
I'm pretty certain this has been there for a while.  


Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: triaged

Title: Atom not appearing on Start Menu (or anywhere) on Windows 10 after first install.
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom not appearing on Start Menu on Windows 10 after first install. Atom.exe does not exist anywhere on my system. The program, however, can be uninstalled through the control panel.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download and install Atom
2. Acknowledge and close the welcome window
3. Go to start menu and wonder why Atom is not there
5. Go to C:\users\me\ .atom\ and wonder why atom.exe is not there
6. Go to C:\Program Files (x86)\ and wonder why atom.exe is not there
7. Go to Control Panel >> uninstall a program, and wonder why atom.exe is there
8. Restart computer
9. Repeat steps 3 through 7

**Expected behavior:** Atom in start menu.

**Actual behavior:** Atom not in start menu.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

atom does not work on command line. Latest version of Atom installed on 15 March 2017.

### Additional Information

I'm using a 2 month old laptop with minimal bloatware. The machine seems to be in pretty good shape.
Label: installer

Title: Assigning editor's height explicitly via position: 'absolute' deprecation when pane split right with new editor
Body:
### Description

Hi, @franklinrt logged https://github.com/mupchrch/split-diff/issues/91. Atom core is throwing a deprecation warning when running `atom.workspace.paneForItem(atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()).splitRight({items:[atom.workspace.buildTextEditor()]})` in my package. This seems like a reasonable bit of code to run, so I am logging this issue.

### Steps to Reproduce

I just updated Atom to 1.13.1 and I am getting a deprecation warning from Atom API code that seems reasonable.

Step 1: Open Atom
Step 2: run `atom.workspace.paneForItem(atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()).splitRight({items:[atom.workspace.buildTextEditor()]})` in dev tools console

At this point I receive the following deprecation warning:

```atom core (1 deprecation)

Assigning editor 302's height explicitly via position: 'absolute' and an assigned top and bottom implicitly assigns the autoHeight property to false on the editor. This behavior is deprecated and will not be supported in the future. Please explicitly assign autoHeight on this editor.

TextEditorComponent.measureDimensions - /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:1011:20

TextEditorComponent.becameVisible - /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:295:12

TextEditorComponent.checkForVisibilityChange - /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:993:16

atom-text-editor.attachedCallback - /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-element.js:87:22

atom-pane-axis.childAdded - /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/pane-axis-element.js:95:12

Function.module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch - /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:25:14
```
Label: triaged

Title: App icons look washed out
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Apparently the added zopflipng compression in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/12916 makes the icon look "washed out".

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Follow this  [link](https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/b91768a923958154a486937ad07fa8a4e2ddc660#diff-5919b4a98ec4eca9558f5144de7c8029). You might have to adjust the scroll position to `resources/app-icons/stable/png/1024.png`.
2. See if the two version looks different

**Expected behavior:** 

They should look the same.

**Actual behavior:**  

The right icon looks "washed out/faded".

![screen shot 2017-01-16 at 9 28 15 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/772937/21993315/09ca9436-dbcf-11e6-9116-58720b905123.png)

**Reproduces how often:**  

I can't reproduce it with my setup. This issue is moved over from https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13634#issuecomment-272922681


### Versions

- OS: macOS Sierra `10.12.2 (16C67)`
- Graphics: Intel Iris Graphics 6100 1536 MB
- Monitor: Apple 27" Thunderbolt
- Browser: Chrome 55.0.2883.95


### Additional Information

We could revert [that PR](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/12916), but it would be great if more could confirm the issue. Especially on Linux since macOS and Windows use their own icon format.

Initially reported here: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13634#issuecomment-272922681
Label: linux
