Title: Copy-paste line with multi-cursor.
Body:
### Description

Copy-paste line with multi-cursor creates number of lines same as number of cursors.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set some number of cursors on line with Ctrl+LClick (for example, 2).
2. Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V

**Expected behavior:** **one** new line with cursors on same position as in copied line.

**Actual behavior:** Copy-paste creates **two** (same as number of cursors) lines with cursors on same position as in copied line.

**Reproduces how often:** Stable always.

### Versions

Ubuntu 14.04

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
Label: triaged

Title: Preserve --disable-gpu flag on Atom restart
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom preserves some command line flags when it restarts as can be seen in this merged PR #12733. 

But the --disable-gpu flag is not among them and my VM config produces black screen glitches when I don't use it.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch atom with --disable-gpu and use ps or system monitor to find the command line with the flag
2. Update extensions and click the restart button or use the developer tools console and call atom.restartApplication()
3. Once restarted check the command line again and the --disable-gpu is no longer there (you can see the glitch in my case because of the gpu bug).

**Expected behavior:** GPU acceleration remains disabled after restart.

**Actual behavior:** GPU acceleration is enabled after restart.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

The GPU issue is this #12461 but seems to affect all electron/chromium related apps and it's probably a hardware vendor/VirtualBox problem.
Label: triaged

Title: RPM build does not respect existing RPM setup with custom topdir
Body:
RPM build does not respect existing RPM setup with custom topdir.

Reproducible: yes

Output of './build --create-rpm-package'

```
Creating rpm package for "/home/philwyett/Development/hemisphere/build/atom/out/atom-1.14.0-dev-ad77c31-amd64"

RPM build errors:

+ rm -rf /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64
++ dirname /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64
+ mkdir -p /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT
+ mkdir /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64
+ mkdir -p /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64//usr/share/atom/
+ cp -r 'Atom/*' /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64//usr/share/atom/
cp: cannot stat 'Atom/*': No such file or directory
error: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.iKpvKG (%install)
    Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.iKpvKG (%install)

Error: Command rpmbuild -ba --clean /home/philwyett/rpmbuild/SPECS/atom.spec exited with code "1"
    at module.exports (/home/philwyett/Development/hemisphere/build/atom/script/lib/spawn-sync.js:16:11)
    at module.exports (/home/philwyett/Development/hemisphere/build/atom/script/lib/create-rpm-package.js:74:3)
    at dumpSymbols.then.then.packagedAppPath (/home/philwyett/Development/hemisphere/build/atom/script/build:86:9)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:103:7)
```

Setting from my '.rpmmacos' file: %_topdir %(echo $HOME)/Development/rpmbuild

Workaround: Temporarily 'mv .rpmmacros .rpmmacros.orig' in $HOME.
Label: build-error

+ mkdir -p /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64//usr/share/atom/
+ cp -r 'Atom/*' /home/philwyett/Development/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/atom-1.14.0.dev.ad77c31-0.1.el7.centos.x86_64//usr/share/atom/
cp: cannot stat 'Atom/*': No such file or directory
error: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.iKpvKG (%install)
    Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.iKpvKG (%install)

Error: Command rpmbuild -ba --clean /home/philwyett/rpmbuild/SPECS/atom.spec exited with code "1"
    at module.exports (/home/philwyett/Development/hemisphere/build/atom/script/lib/spawn-sync.js:16:11)

Title: RPM build does not respect existing RPM setup with custom topdir

Title: Atom Startup Time
Body:
The following is a summary of a CPU profile taken during startup. The aim of this issue is to explicitly state what the bottlenecks are and, where possible, suggest ideas on how to solve them. Profiles were taken after disabling all the 3rd party packages. * Bootstrap Node.
**Cost:** ~ 100ms.
**Savings:** N/A.
**Difficulty:** Medium/Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 13 53 58](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20390197/ff02edee-accd-11e6-890e-d5fbde25e2d9.png) This section involves setting up Node and is standard for all the projects. The bottom line is that it would require a change in Electron, hence why I chose Medium/Hard as the difficulty. It might be worth exploring solutions with the Electron team as well as talking to the Node team, understanding if there are plans to improve this in the future. An interesting observation is that most of it is spent in requiring modules, so maybe Electron/Node could employ some of the techniques we plan to use for userland requires (see below). * Requiring modules.
**Cost:** ~ 350-400 ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%.
**Difficulty:** Medium/Hard. This sections concerns the time spent in searching, compiling and executing JavaScript files. I haven't provided a screenshot of the CPU profile because this cost is spread across many function calls. So long as modules don't access Node core modules or DOM APIs at require-time, we should be able to use v8 snapshots to do most of the work during `script/build`. This means we would need to restructure some packages to stop using those APIs, but it should be doable. Last week we have been working on proving the feasibility of this approach and it seems like we could apply it to Atom. * Constructing `AtomEnvironment`.
**Cost:** ~ 100-110ms.
**Savings:** 75-80%.
**Difficulty:** Medium. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 08 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20390488/6c9aceca-accf-11e6-8630-5da169a2a984.png) The above chart breaks down into several sub-tasks. Some of them can be executed upfront in the snapshotting phase: * Creating objects like `Workspace`, `TextEditorRegistry`, etc.(~ 10ms). * `Config.setSchema` (~ 7ms). * `ThemeManager.loadBaseStylesheets` (~ 19ms). * `KeymapManager.loadBundledKeymaps` (~ 11ms) Others need to happen at runtime, although we can make them asynchronous and avoid blocking the main thread: * `ApplicationDelegate.disableZoom` (~ 9ms). * `AtomEnvironment.registerDefaultCommands` (~ 7ms). * `AtomEnvironment.installWindowEventHandler` (~ 7ms). * `HistoryManager.loadState` (~ 25ms). * `Config.loadUserConfig` (~ 5ms). * Loading Packages.
**Cost:** ~ 50-60ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%.
**Difficulty:** Medium. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 13 15 15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20390867/f4c94866-acd0-11e6-8626-bff3f7d54513.png) Loading packages involves reading their style sheets and their configuration schemas. The image above is the typical chart of a single `Package.load` call. At least for bundled packages, we have all the information at compile-time and we should be able to bake it into the snapshot. * Environment Deserialization.
**Cost:** ~ 50-60ms.
**Savings:** 70%.
**Difficulty:** N/A. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 13 16 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391116/463b8d7a-acd2-11e6-9e05-4077e194acb9.png) Deserializing the environment is something that needs to happen at runtime but, as the chart above shows, the dominator in that stack trace is `GitRepository`. In particular, it might be worth revisiting `openSubmodules` and `refreshStatus`: the former can probably be deferred at a later moment in time, while the latter is already asynchronous and is probably slow because of the overhead of creating a `Task`. * Activating Packages.
**Cost:** ~ 300ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** Medium/Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 39 47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391597/6a1adc30-acd4-11e6-93bf-aa929f773678.png) Estimating savings for this section is somewhat tricky, as a considerable amount of time is spent in requiring modules (which has been accounted for in a previous section). However, we think we could further reduce the cost of it by splitting core packages activation into two phases (snapshot and runtime), offloading as much work as possible to the snapshot one. * Refreshing less cache and reloading base style sheets.
**Cost:** ~ 20ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%
**Difficulty:** N/A. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 55 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391951/04a732c0-acd6-11e6-9e21-41c2bd840d7c.png) The first thing that is suspicious is that this stack trace feels redundant, as we do a similar thing when instantiating `AtomEnvironment`. Anyways, this is all information we have at compile time, so the only cost we should pay at runtime is to add the proper CSS to the `` element. * First Layout
**Cost:** ~ 250ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 59 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20392134/c837d6e0-acd6-11e6-8404-97abc06feaf1.png) This is the first layout that Atom performs after loading and it takes a pretty huge amount of time. Unfortunately, we cannot inspect what is happening under the hood that causes this layout to be slow. We suspect it might be due to our use of flexbox, but at the same time we feel like it might be worth capturing a native profile of Electron and inspecting the actual native calls that are being executed. * Main Process.
**Cost:** ~ 600ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** N/A. Profiling the main process is somewhat trickier than profiling the renderer process, as we don't have direct access to the dev tools. However, I have estimated that we spend `~ 600ms` to get from the first line of code in the main process to the first line of code in the renderer process. This section probably deserves an entire issue, as we are aware that the main process needs a overhaul. However it's worth noting that it significantly contributes to startup time, although it's unclear how much of it is Atom's fault and how much of it is due to Electron. /cc: @atom/maintainers
Label: FY2019Q5 atom perf

However, we think we could further reduce the cost of it by splitting core packages activation into two phases (snapshot and runtime), offloading as much work as possible to the snapshot one. * Refreshing less cache and reloading base style sheets.
**Cost:** ~ 20ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%
**Difficulty:** N/A. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 55 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391951/04a732c0-acd6-11e6-9e21-41c2bd840d7c.png) The first thing that is suspicious is that this stack trace feels redundant, as we do a similar thing when instantiating `AtomEnvironment`. Anyways, this is all information we have at compile time, so the only cost we should pay at runtime is to add the proper CSS to the `` element. * First Layout
**Cost:** ~ 250ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 59 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20392134/c837d6e0-acd6-11e6-8404-97abc06feaf1.png) This is the first layout that Atom performs after loading and it takes a pretty huge amount of time. Unfortunately, we cannot inspect what is happening under the hood that causes this layout to be slow. We suspect it might be due to our use of flexbox, but at the same time we feel like it might be worth capturing a native profile of Electron and inspecting the actual native calls that are being executed. * Main Process.
**Cost:** ~ 600ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** N/A. Profiling the main process is somewhat trickier than profiling the renderer process, as we don't have direct access to the dev tools. However, I have estimated that we spend `~ 600ms` to get from the first line of code in the main process to the first line of code in the renderer process. This section probably deserves an entire issue, as we are aware that the main process needs a overhaul. However it's worth noting that it significantly contributes to startup time, although it's unclear how much of it is Atom's fault and how much of it is due to Electron. /cc: @atom/maintainers
Label: triaged

Title: Atom crashes when trying to add a project folder with a corrupt .git/index
Body:
### Description

Atom crashes when trying to add a project folder with a corrupt .git/index.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a local git repo with a corrupt `.git/index`
2. [Clear all Atom settings](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-completely-uninstall-atom-for-mac/9084/34) to reset Atom to a factory default state
3. Run `atom --safe`
4. Add said git repo to Atom as a project folder

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Atom should add the folder as a project folder.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Atom crashes immediately: the window turns completely white and an alert appears asking if I want to reload or close the window.

### Versions
Atom v1.12.3, OSX 10.12.1
Label: crash

Title: Allow to specify a prefix for installation
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

Installing Atom, it should be possible to configure the prefix for the installation. By default itâ€™s `/usr/local`, but distribution people normally want to change that. For example, they want to install Atom in `/usr/bin`, and not `/usr/local/bin`.

That was possible in Atom 1.9.0.

```
$ script/grunt install --build-dir /something --install-dir /my/prefix/dir
```

Itâ€™s not anymore, as itâ€™s hard coded in `src/command-installer.coffee`.
Label: triaged

Title: Soft tabs on a line after hard tabs advance to wrong position
Body:
### Description

With soft tabs enabled I try to align text on the right of some other text. Since I am using soft tabs I expect the tab key to insert a number of spaces sufficient to move the cursor on the screen to the next tab stop.  This works if the line does not have any hard tabs on it already.  But it is wrong when there are hard tabs to the left of the cursor position on the same line.

This problem is surely caused by two different interpretations of the cursor column position.  One interpretation is the byte position in the buffer, and the other is the screen position as rendered.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new file.
2. Enable hard tabs, tab spacing 8.
3. Insert this text using the TAB key for <TAB>s:
```
     <TAB>buf =<TAB>nullptr;
     <TAB>a =<TAB>zero;
```
The zero and the nullptr should line up, as expected.
![With all tabs, text aligns correctly](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123908/20231736/cf05447a-a818-11e6-816c-da5e16b8d2fd.png)

4. Change the editor settings to soft tabs.
5. Delete the last tab just before `zero` and press <TAB> again.

**Expected behavior:** The 2nd line should have three spaces before `zero`, and the `zero` and `nullptr` text should be visually aligned on the screen.
![Expected behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123908/20231747/dd43e15e-a818-11e6-9022-34f076957000.png)


**Actual behavior:** Only two spaces were inserted by the soft tab and the text does not align.
![Actual behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123908/20231753/e988ead6-a818-11e6-839b-bcd34742c1b1.png)

### Versions

Running Ubuntu Linux 16.10 with Atom 1.11.2.

    $ atom --version
    Atom    : 1.11.2
    Electron: 0.37.8
    Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
    Node    : 5.10.0

    $ apm --version
    apm  1.12.5
    npm  3.10.5
    node 4.4.5
    python 2.7.12
    git 2.7.4

    $ uname -a
    Linux phord-X1 4.7.6-040706-generic #201609300531 SMP Fri Sep 30 09:33:47 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
Label: d â¬†ï¸?

Title: Race between type-specific settings and third-party packages that update settings dynamically
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?

This bug is about a bad interaction between Atom core and a third-party package, <https://github.com/jtokoph/auto-detect-indentation>. I've already filed a bug on the package, <https://github.com/jtokoph/auto-detect-indentation/issues/23>, but it occurs to me that a proper fix for this might involve changing Atom core as well, hence this report!

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

The core code which manages per-type editor settings races with third-party code that also tries to manage editor settings. This can lead to surprising / counterintuitive results.

I ran into this with the `auto-detect-indentation` package, which tries to manage the settings of `softTabs` and `tabLength`. The steps-to-repro below are with respect to that package, and you can refer to the bug I mentioned above for a description of what I'd expect to be the interaction between the core's idea of per-type settings and what the package is trying to achieve.

I _think_ the problem boils down to the fact that <https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/text-editor-registry.js#L333-L343> often (always?) ends up running _after_ third-party packages are `activate`d (or something along those lines). In addition, it may make sense to distinguish the act of calling `editor.update` as "action taken by the core" vs. other reasons. In this case, the package in question might want to behave differently in these different cases. (But please take this all with a big grain of salt, as I'm not super-familiar with the Atom codebase.)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install the package `auto-detect-indentation`.
2. Put the following in your `config.cson`:
   
   ```
   ".js.source":
    editor:
      tabLength: 8
      tabType: "hard"
   ```

3. Open up a `.js` file with blatant two-space indentation.

**Expected behavior:**

The editor is set to two-space indentation.

**Actual behavior:**

The editor is set to eight-space hard tab indentation. If you watch carefully, you can sometimes see the indentation status briefly flash "2 Spaces" before getting thwacked to "Tabs (8 wide)".

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.3.8
```

macOS 10.11.6
Label: triaged

Body:

- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Originally reported to me by @Ben3eeE.  Running `script\clean` twice in a row will fail with `Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'` and the usual traceback that occurs with that.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. `script\clean` (make sure it succeeds...doesn't always happen on Windows)
2. `script\clean`
3. `Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'`

**Expected behavior:** Usual cleaning output to occur

**Actual behavior:** `Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'`
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

This really isn't relevant to this issue, but:

```
Atom    : 1.12.0-dev-9df5253
Electron: 1.4.2
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.113
Node    : 6.5.0
```

I can't log the apm version because of some module version mismatches that I'm trying to solve right now (by cleaning and rebuilding!).

Windows 10 x64.

/cc @nathansobo
Label: build-error

- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Originally reported to me by @Ben3eeE.  Running `script\clean` twice in a row will fail with `Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'` and the usual traceback that occurs with that.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. `script\clean` (make sure it succeeds...doesn't always happen on Windows)
2. `script\clean`
3. `Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'`

**Expected behavior:** Usual cleaning output to occur

**Actual behavior:** `Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'`
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

This really isn't relevant to this issue, but:

```
Atom    : 1.12.0-dev-9df5253
Electron: 1.4.2
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.113
Node    : 6.5.0
```

I can't log the apm version because of some module version mismatches that I'm trying to solve right now (by cleaning and rebuilding!).

Windows 10 x64.

/cc @nathansobo
Label: triaged

Title: Add an option to disable smooth scrolling
Body: I was using Atom 1.8.8 previously which did not include smooth scrolling. Today I updated to 1.10 which has smooth scrolling enabled by default, but I cannot figure out how to turn it off. There do not seem to any plugins or tutorials on how to disable it either. In Chrome, the user can open chrome://flags and manually disable it, but I could not figure out how. [This post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-access-chrome-flags-in-electron/16470/6) gives me a few hints, but not much else unfortunately.

Title: "Restart and Install" does not restart Atom after update on Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When Squirrel notifies about new Atom release, after clicking "Restart and Install" button on about view, Atom exits, update completes with some errors logged to SquirrelSetup.log but Atom is not restarted.
This has been happening during every update since I installed Atom 1.8.0 or one version before that.

Here is the whole [SquirrelSetup.log](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/426153/SquirrelSetup.log.txt) containing every line since update to 1.8.0 on 2016-07-03.

Possible cause:

```
System.IO.IOException: The process cannot access the file 'C:\Users\User\AppData\Local\SquirrelTemp\tempe\lib\net45\atom.exe' because it is being used by another process.
```

Might be caused by security software locking the file druring scanning.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open about view when a new release is available
2. Wait for download to finish
3. Click "Restart and Install" button

**Expected behavior:**
Atom restarting after Squirrel completes updating to latest release

**Actual behavior:**
Atom is not restarting after updates have been applied
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.7
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
Squirrel: 1.2.4.0

OS: Windows 10 Pro, version 1607, build 14393.51

Title: Saving a file with CTRL+S consistently crashes Atom (Windows 7 Enterprise Service Pack 1)
Body:
### Description

I downloaded a fresh installation of Atom and edited my first (Markdown) file with it.
Saving the file with CTRL+S consistently crashes Atom.
Not a very good first interaction with the editor on Windows...
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Download Atom
2. Install on Windows
3. Edit file
4. Press CTRL+S (In both 'normal' and 'safe' mode)

**Expected behavior:** The file is saved

**Actual behavior:** The editor crashes
### Versions

![clipboard01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1651235/15818611/ae874164-2bde-11e6-851e-c050a49694f4.jpg)
![clipboard02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1651235/15818610/ae86e8ae-2bde-11e6-99d7-9ae4128d4127.jpg)
Label: crash

Title: Allow for sublime style "Paste and Indent"
Body:
I can't seem to find any packages or settings in atom that can replicate Sublime's "Paste and Indent" behavior. What I want atom to do is to truncate the whitespace ahead of the content on the line and paste where my cursor is at. In both cases I triple click each line to select the entire contents.

Here are two gifs showing the difference, and in the atom gif I have the settings `autoIndentOnPaste: false` and `normalizeIndentOnPaste: false`
# Atom

![alt tag](http://i.imgur.com/6X33KhA.gif)
# Sublime (Paste and Indent)

![alt tag](http://i.imgur.com/t1Dg82a.gif)

Is there a way to get the same kind of behavior in Atom?
Label: question

Title: Auto indent not correct when moving lines up or down
Body: When you move a group of selected lines up or down, Atom auto indents them to where it thinks they should fit in the code and it is not always correct. It should have the option to disable this flavor of auto indent.
Label: auto-indent

Title: Atom launch story is complicated and confusing
Body:
How to launch Atom in specific states is a bit of magic that is only known to a few. Some features are more obvious like Dev Mode and Safe Mode, but even then the full effects of each of these modes are not fully documented anywhere and therefore they are often misunderstood even by people who use these modes often. The purpose of this Issue initially is to capture the list of initial states that people want to launch Atom into. Eventually we will create a plan and design for making each of them easy, well understood and as obvious as possible to newcomers to Atom. If possible, I'll add links to other Issues, PRs, Discuss topics and other sources to illustrate.
## Atom Launch Modes

These are the modes that Atom more-or-less supports or are implied by the modes that Atom does support.
- Project (whether with single or multiple roots)
- No project — Open specific files with no tree view
- Restore last state (project or no project)
- Restore specific project state
- Dev Mode — Since this is designed as an aid for Atom development, it mostly only makes sense in combination with the project mode (but perhaps I'm overlooking something)
- Safe Mode — Can be combined with any of the above modes (other than Dev Mode)

Each of these should have an obvious and unambiguous way of launching them both from the command line and from the GUI.
### Additional Command Line Thoughts

Sometimes people want to modify the state of Atom from the command line and sometimes they don't. Some consideration should be given to these scenarios:
- Add a file to an open session of Atom
- Add a project root to an open session of Atom
- Launch Atom in any mode when an open session of Atom is running (even when it may seem the user may want one of the two above but doesn't ... for instance "open a file that exists in the project that is open in the current session of Atom, but I want it in a new Atom session with **no** project")
## Mode State

There are things that are serialized and stored when Atom exits. It is completely non-obvious what items belong to this set and what items do not as well as how to restore the saved items when next launching Atom. Decisions should be made about whether some of these items belong to the specific mode that Atom is in or if they are more global state that people expect to be in place the next time Atom is launched (or even an individual file is opened post-launch) no matter what mode Atom is launched in.
- List of open tabs
- Editor state — Where the cursor is in the file, etc
- Unsaved changes to files
- Untitled buffers
- Per file indentation settings
- Per file line ending settings
- Per file encoding settings
- [Pane configuration](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10545)
Label: proposal

Title: OSX 10.10.5 - Files locking up on smb connection
Body:
I'm editing files on a mounted volume (connected via SMB). 

When I try to discard changes on a file w/ Git the file locks up and i get a "Permission Denied" message in atom. I can not delete the file in finder as well. 

I then need to disconnect from the mounted volume or reboot to get the file back.

Please help.
Label: network

Title: Atom cause issues in files when switching between branches of a git repository
Body:
When switching between branches of a git repository and a file is open in current branch that does not exists in switched branch, because that file does not exists in switched branch when closing that file Atom wants to save it, and when I leave it without saving after switching later branch that has those files I saw that those files content lost!
For more information please note that you have branches "branch_a", and "branch_b" that "branch_a" has file "file_a" but "branch_b" has not "file_a", if you open "file_a" in "branch_a" and after checkout to "branch_b" and "file_a" is open in atom editor because "file_a" does not exists in "branch_b" when I want to close that file "file_a" Atom wants to save that and when I leave it without saving when I come back to "branch_a" saw that "file_a" content lost!

My system is : Ubuntu 14.4 x86_64 with Atom 1.1 installed on it.
Label: needs-reproduction

Title: AtomEditor always opens on default display when X11 Forwarding
Body:
Steps to dupe:
- Install Atom on Linux (1.1.0)
- Enable X11 Forwarding on your SSH server
- SSH to your "host" (ssh -X host.blah.blah.blah) from a "remote laptop"
- While ssh'd into your "host" type `atom` in the terminal.
- Watch SSH open on the "host's" default/physical display.
- (expected X11 Session to open on "remote laptop")
Label: electron

Title: Editor window startup is slow
Body:
Hi, i have used Textmate for a loong long time. But also as a big fan of new things, i decided to try Atom for curiosity purposes.

It turns out that i found Atom a great platform for day-by-day development, and im using it Atom now. But theres one thing annoying me:

I usually open Atom using the Shell command "atom [filename]", and compared to "mate [filename]" (the same command Textmate use for open files using Shell), Atom is incredible slow (i feel i have to wait twice of the time, like 1s~2s).
I know this performance also is related to machine specs, processors, memory and etc. But its the exactly same task executed for different tools. 

I can record a video showing that behavior if you like.
Also, if this is a un-prioritize known issue, i can submit a pull request if theres noone working on it. I just need to know where to start looking.

][`s
Label: performance

Title: Accessing files on network drives is slow
Body:
Reported via Halp:
- support/6290a694aa0611e38d8242e11b72b07d

> Accessing files on network drives appears to be much slower than Sublime for the same mount & file. Additionally, the "Keep Waiting" decision box pops up almost every time.

I don't have a network drive, so I didn't verify this. :car: 

Edit: more reports:
- support/4e6fe392af5a11e38b62f01b0c57459b
Label: network
